nationalteam-update = 21:00, 1 October 2018 (UTC) }} '''Andros Darryl Townsend''' (born 16 July 1991) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for {{English football updater|CrystalP}} club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]].
A graduate of the [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C. Reserves and Academy|academy]] and featuring in various England youth teams, Townsend was initially loaned out to several [[EFL League One|League One]] and then [[EFL Championship|Championship]] clubs alongside limited Tottenham appearances, before gaining his Premier League debut on 16 September 2012. After further limited appearances and then a half-season loan to Premier League club [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], Townsend established himself as a Tottenham player for the 2013–14 and 2014–15 seasons. He subsequently fell out of favour at Tottenham, and following a short spell at Newcastle United in the 2015–16 season, he transferred to Crystal Palace in the summer of 2016.
In his senior international career, Townsend earned his first England cap on 11 October 2013, and has gone on to make thirteen appearances, scoring three goals.
==Early career== Townsend joined the [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] academy at the age of eight.<ref name=brief>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2456592/Andros-Townsend-dedicated-England-debut-memory-late-brother.html |title=Tragedy that drives England's new star – Townsend dedicates Wembley heroics to memory of his brother Kurtis |author1=Higgs, Peter |author2=Miller, Alex |last-author-amp=yes |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=12 October 2013 |accessdate=16 October 2013}}{{Unreliable source?|date=June 2018}}</ref> In March 2009, he went on loan to [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/y/yeovil/7952653.stm |title=Yeovil sign teenage Tottenham duo |date=19 March 2009 |accessdate=21 March 2009 |publisher=BBC Sport| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090322135753/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/y/yeovil/7952653.stm| archivedate= 22 March 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref> making his football league debut against [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] alongside fellow Spurs academy player [[Jonathan Obika]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7937330.stm |title=Yeovil 0–0 MK Dons |date=21 March 2009 |accessdate=21 March 2009 |publisher=BBC Sport | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090323074638/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7937330.stm| archivedate= 23 March 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref> He made ten appearances and scored one goal for Yeovil as they avoided relegation.<ref name=THFCResProfile>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106142845/http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/players/reserves/androstownsend.html |title=Professional Player Profiles: Andros Townsend |archivedate=6 January 2011 |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/players/reserves/androstownsend.html}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Tottenham Hotspur=== ====Initial loans==== Townsend entered the senior Tottenham team under manager [[Harry Redknapp]].{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} In August 2009, he went on a month's loan to [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]], extended at the end of the month to the end of December, after which he returned to Tottenham.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808145732/http://www.leytonorient.com/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10439~1745442%2C00.html |url=http://www.leytonorient.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10439~1745442,00.html |title=O's take Spurs youngster on loan |date=6 August 2009 |archivedate= 8 August 2009 |publisher=Leyton Orient F.C |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/andros-extends-loan-310809/ |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |title=Andros extends loan |accessdate=12 October 2013 |date=31 August 2009}}</ref> In 26 appearances for Orient, Townsend scored twice, including a "great goal" in a 3–3 draw against Yeovil, passing three opposing players with a run that began in his own half, leading the opposition manager to lament that his players had not been more ruthless and taken him down with a professional foul.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8207704.stm |title=Yeovil 3–3 Leyton Orient |date=22 March 2009 |accessdate=24 March 2009 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
Having not yet made his Tottenham debut, on 14 January 2010, Townsend was again taken on loan by a League One club, Milton Keynes Dons, until the end of the season, although he was recalled after just two months due to injuries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/andros-recalled-050310/ |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |title=Andros recalled |accessdate=12 October 2013 |date=5 March 2010}}</ref> In nine matches for the Dons he had scored twice.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} The season ended without Townsend having made his debut for Tottenham.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
On 12 August 2010, Townsend signed another season-long loan, moving up to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] level with [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], but this was terminated on 20 December, as Redknapp believed he had not been playing regularly enough.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/Tottenham-pull-Andros-Townsend-out-of-his-Ipswich-loan-because-of-a-lack-of-game-time-article654939.html |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |title=Redknapp pulls youngster out of Ipswich loan |date=20 December 2010 |accessdate=20 December 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/andros-loan-to-ipswich-120810/ |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |title=Andros loan to Ipswich |date=12 August 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> He had played 16 times, scoring once.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
====Tottenham debut and further loans==== [[File:Andros Townsend - July 2010 USA tour.jpg|thumb|upright|Townsend with [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in 2010]] [[File:Andros Townsend.jpg|thumb|upright|Townsend playing for [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] in 2011]] On 9 January 2011, Townsend marked his senior Tottenham debut in a third round FA Cup tie at [[White Hart Lane]] against [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], scoring the first goal and being voted [[Man of the Match]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/8786154.Watford_still_hope_to_sign_Spurs__Townsend/ |newspaper=Watford Observer |first=Frank |last=Smith |title=Watford still hopeful of signing Tottenham winger Andros Townsend |date=12 January 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref> This proved to be his only appearance for Tottenham for the rest of the season, with two further loan spells occurring.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He joined Championship club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 20 January 2011 on loan until the end of the season, but this was terminated early, on 23 February, with Townsend having made three appearances.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/andros-in-watford-loan-200111/ |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |title=Andros in Watford loan |accessdate=12 October 2013 |date=20 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wycombe_wanderers/9405798.stm |title=Watford's Kiernan joins Wycombe, Townsend leaves |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=24 February 2011}}</ref> On 7 March, Townsend again went on loan to a Championship club until the end of the season, this time [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/millwall/9417132.stm |title=Millwall sign Tottenham Hotspur winger Andros Townsend |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 March 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref> By April he said he would be happy to stay at the club beyond his loan spell.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/millwall/8441390/Tottenham-Hotspur-winger-Andros-Townsend-keen-to-stay-at-Millwall-after-fine-display-in-victory-over-Leeds.html |title=Tottenham Hotspur winger Andros Townsend keen to stay at Millwall after fine display in victory over Leeds |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=10 April 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref> In 11 appearances he scored twice.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
====European football and further loans==== For the first half of Tottenham's [[2011–12 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2011–12 season]], Townsend was a regular in their [[2011-12 UEFA Europa League|Europa League campaign]], making six appearances in the competition, scoring his second goal for the club in their final match in the competition against [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]] on 15 December 2011, curling in a shot from outside the box.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/dec/15/tottenham-hotspur-shamrock-rovers-europa-league| title=Tottenham thrash Shamrock Rovers but exit Europa League| first=Declan |last=Warrington|newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=15 December 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref> On 23 December, he signed a contract extension, making him a Tottenham player until the end of the 2016 season.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11675/7391922/Townsend-signs-Spurs-extension| title=Townsend signs Spurs extension| publisher=Sky Sports| date=22 December 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref>
With only one other appearance for Tottenham, in the League Cup, on 1 January 2012, Townsend joined Championship club [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] on loan until the end of the season, but with his agent claiming he was unhappy at the club, he switched the loan to their Championship rivals [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in February.<ref>{{cite web| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107201730/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120101/tottenham-star-joins-united_2247585_2562839| url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120101/tottenham-star-joins-united_2247585_2562839| title=Tottenham star joins United| publisher=Leeds United F.C| date=1 January 2012 |archivedate=7 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2622625,00.html |title=Andros wings in |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |date=24 February 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227080705/http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10412~2622625%2C00.html |archivedate=27 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17157791 |title=Andros Townsend joins Birmingham on loan after leaving Leeds |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 February 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref> At Leeds, he made seven appearances, including a Man of the Match performance on his debut, and scored one goal.<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108054655/http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120104/leeds-decision-was-no-brainer-for-andros_2247585_2565206| url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/20120104/leeds-decision-was-no-brainer-for-andros_2247585_2565206| title=Leeds decision was 'no brainer' for Andros| publisher=Leeds United F.C| date=4 January 2012 |archivedate=8 January 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.leedsunited.com/match-report/match/1120008| title=Luc's late, late winner for Leeds!| publisher=Leeds United F.C| date=18 February 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref> At Birmingham, he made 16 league appearances, including in their second leg tie in the [[2012 Football League play-offs|unsuccessful Championship promotion playoff]] against Blackpool.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
====Premier League debut==== Townsend remained with Tottenham for the first half of their [[2012–13 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2012–13 season]], with the club now under a new manager, [[André Villas-Boas]], who replaced Redknapp in the summer. He made his Premier League debut with a late substitution appearance on 16 September.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Although appearing a further four times in the Premier League, these were all still late substitute appearances.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Outside the league he made a further five appearances, once in the League Cup and FA Cup respectively, and three times in the Europa League.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He scored his third Tottenham goal in the League Cup, a fine individual effort in a 3–0 victory against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] in the third round.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/sep/26/tottenham-hotspur-carlisle |title=Tottenham's understudies excel in audition and outclass bold Carlisle |first=Louise |last=Taylor |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=27 September 2012}}</ref>
====Loan to Queens Park Rangers==== On 31 January 2013, Townsend followed Redknapp to Premier League club [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on a loan deal until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21285005 |title=Jermaine Jenas completes move from Tottenham to QPR |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> He made twelve appearances for the club, including a Man of the Match performance on his debut, scoring two goals in March, a dipping volley from outside the penalty area in a 3–1 win at home to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], and an equalising deflection in a 3–2 away loss to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/9842206/QPR-v-Norwich-City-live.html |title=QPR v Norwich City: live |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=2 February 2013|accessdate=2 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21639329 |title=QPR 3–1 Sunderland |author=Sanghera, Mandeep |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 March 2013 |accessdate=9 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21724358 |title=Aston Villa 3–2 QPR | last = Monaghan | first = Matt |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 March 2013 |accessdate=16 March 2013}}</ref> QPR were ultimately relegated, and Townsend returned to his parent club.
====Established in the first team==== Now back at Tottenham, Townsend started the second Premier League match of their [[2013–14 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2013–14 season]], and went on to make a total of 33 appearances, including 25 in the league.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} He scored twice, in a 5–0 away victory over [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]] in the Europa League (his first match of the season), and his first in the Premier League in a 2–0 victory away to Aston Villa on 20 October 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23707596 |title=Dinamo Tbilisi 0–5 Tottenham | last = Magowan | first = Alistair |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 August 2013 |accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24510366 | title = Aston Villa 0–2 Tottenham | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 20 October 2013 | accessdate = 9 November 2013 | first = Phil | last = McNulty}}</ref> In the middle of the season, Townsend came under the management of his third Tottenham boss, after Villas-Boas was replaced by [[Tim Sherwood]].
With Sherwood's contract terminated at the end of the season, Townsend started the club's [[2014–15 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2014–15 season]] under new manager [[Mauricio Pochettino]]. He made a total of 35 appearances, scoring 5 goals, but was reduced to just 17 appearances in the league, having been unable to hold down a starting place until the second half of the season.<ref name=espn>{{cite news |title=Merson tells Andros Townsend to 'win some medals' as Twitter fallout rolls on|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/tottenham-hotspur/story/2376873/paul-merson-tells-andros-townsend-to-win-some-medals-as-twitter-fallout-continues |publisher=ESPN |date=2 April 2015 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref> He started as Tottenham lost 2–0 to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|2015 League Cup Final]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] on 1 March.<ref name=2015LC>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31572594 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
====Out of favour==== On 4 November 2015, having not started a league match of the [[2015–16 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2015–16 season]], Townsend was dropped from the squad following a touchline argument with the club's fitness coach.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34725197 | title = Spurs drop Andros Townsend after row with coach Nathan Gardiner | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 4 November 2015 | accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref> Having apologised, Pochettino allowed Townsend to return to the squad by 17 November, and stated the matter was over and he was available for selection again.<ref>{{Cite web|title='We feel sorry for him' Pochettino's injury set-back ahead of West Ham |url=http://www.london24.com/sport/football/clubs/tottenham/we_feel_sorry_for_him_pochettino_s_injury_set_back_ahead_of_west_ham_1_4319706 |work=London 24 |accessdate=26 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202180057/http://www.london24.com/sport/football/clubs/tottenham/we_feel_sorry_for_him_pochettino_s_injury_set_back_ahead_of_west_ham_1_4319706 |archivedate=2 February 2016 }}</ref> He never made a first team appearance for Tottenham following the incident, being an unused substitute three times, the last time on 10 December.<ref name=newcastle>{{Cite news|title = Andros Townsend completes £12m Newcastle move from Tottenham|url = http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11678/10145700/andros-townsend-completes-newcastle-medical-ahead-of-16312m-move-from-tottenham|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate = 27 January 2016}}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== [[File:Townsend 2016.jpg|thumb|upright|Townsend playing for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in 2016]]
On 26 January 2016, having still not started a league match, Tottenham agreed a transfer fee with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] for Townsend, reportedly £12 million.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35409021 | title = Andros Townsend: Newcastle agree fee with Tottenham | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 26 January 2016 | accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref> Before the fee had been announced, Townsend had already tweeted a goodbye message, and stated "As soon as I knew of Newcastle's interest they were the only club I wanted to join...Two of the best positions you can play in football are centre-forward and left wing at Newcastle. I've got the chance. I could never turn that down. I can't wait to play my first game at [[St James' Park]]".<ref>{{Cite news|title = Townsend to Newcastle: 'They were the only club I wanted to join'|url = https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/andros-townsend-to-newcastle-they-were-the-only-club-i-wanted-to-join-says-departing-tottenham-a3165371.html|newspaper=London Evening Standard|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref> The transfer was confirmed the following day, a five-and-a-half-year contract but with the club declining to disclose the fee. On signing, his new manager, Newcastle head coach [[Steve McClaren]], said of Townsend that he is a "winger with an old-fashioned style. He can play on the right or the left, is two-footed, quick, very direct and loves taking on defenders and crossing the ball."<ref>{{Cite web|title =Newcastle sign Andros Townsend|url = http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20160127/newcastle-sign-andros-townsend_2281670_5304402|publisher=Newcastle United F.C. |accessdate = 27 January 2016}}</ref> According to Sky Sports, the transfer had been under negotiation for a week and Newcastle had initially wanted Townsend on loan, and then had a transfer offer of £10.5m rejected.<ref name=newcastle/>
Despite his debut for Newcastle being in a disappointing team performance in an away defeat, at the next match, his home debut, he was given a standing ovation after a Man of the Match performance which saw Newcastle climb out of the relegation places.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Everton 3–0 Newcastle United|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35416325|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate = 6 February 2016|first = Patrick Jennings BBC|last = Sport}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = Newcastle United 1–0 West Bromwich Albion|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35447662|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate = 6 February 2016|first = Saj Chowdhury BBC|last = Sport}}</ref> His first goal for the club came in his third match, a shot from just outside the area, but it was just a 90th minute consolation goal in a 5–1 away defeat to Chelsea.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Chelsea 5–1 Newcastle United|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35510139|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate = 13 February 2016|first = Chris|last = Bevan}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== [[File:Andros Townsend 16-07-2016 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Townsend playing for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in 2016]]
On 1 July 2016, Townsend joined Premier League club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on a five-year contract from Newcastle following their relegation to the Championship.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36680273 |title=Crystal Palace sign Andros Townsend and Steve Mandanda |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 July 2016 |accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> Palace triggered his £13 million release clause just six months after he joined from Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12691/10329590/andros-townsend-set-for-crystal-palace-medical-after-16313m-newcastle-release-clause-triggered |title=Andros Townsend set for Crystal Palace medical after £13m Newcastle release clause triggered |publisher=Sky Sports |date=30 June 2016 |accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> He was originally assigned the number 17 shirt for his first season with Palace, however after Bolasie left for Everton, it was announced that Townsend had been reassigned the vacant number 10 shirt previously worn by Bolasie.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2016/august/townsend-changes-shirt-number/ | title=Townsend Changes Shirt Number | publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. | date=19 August 2016 | accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref>
==Role within the loan system== Having had nine loan spells, Townsend's career path to regular first team football for Tottenham is often discussed in the context of a wider debate in English football about the best way to develop young talent, contrasting the loan route with Premier League players being developed in Under-21 leagues, or being brought to the Premier League level via transfers from lower league clubs. According to his father, the loan spells were the making of his son's career, while Tottenham's former Director of Football [[Damien Comolli]] who was dismissed in October 2008 believes Townsend succeeded in spite of the way Tottenham handled him.<ref>{{cite news |first=Alistair |last=Magowan |title=Premier League: Is the loan system being abused by clubs? |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34125476 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 September 2015 |accessdate=8 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title = Harry Kane: Rise of Tottenham striker shows loaning out is increasingly the way to develop young players - Glenn Moore|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/glenn-moore-rise-of-kane-shows-loaning-out-is-increasingly-the-way-to-develop-young-players-10124360.html|newspaper=The Independent |location=London|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth levels=== Townsend represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]] and [[England national under-19 football team|under-19 level]]. He played three times for the under-16s between 2006 and 2007, making his debut in a 1–1 draw away with [[Wales national under-16 football team|Wales]] on 20 October 2006 and his last appearance in a 2–0 away loss to [[Germany national under-16 football team|Germany]] in April 2007.<ref name=TheFAprofile>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/All-Teams/Players/T/Andros-Townsend |title=Andros Townsend |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref> He scored twice on his under-17 debut, in a 6–1 win over [[Northern Ireland national under-17 football team|Northern Ireland]] in August 2007,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U17s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2007/08/England17_vNIReport.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20080312021738/http://www.thefa.com/England/U17s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2007/08/England17_vNIReport.htm |dead-url=yes |archivedate=12 March 2008 |title=Noel's boys hit six |author=Hunt, Ben |publisher=The Football Association |date=29 August 2007 |df= }}</ref> and went on to make six appearances, the last in a 0–0 draw with [[Portugal national under-17 football team|Portugal]] on 5 February 2008.<ref name=TheFAprofile/>
Townsend received his first call up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 team]] in October 2012 for the [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification play-offs|Euro 2013 play-off]] matches against [[Serbia national under-21 football team|Serbia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/2012/under-21s-squad-v-serbia.aspx |title=Sterling selected for U21s |publisher=The Football Association |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref> He made his debut in the first leg as a 65th-minute substitute for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]'s [[Raheem Sterling]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2012/england-v-serbia |title=Craig gives England the edge |author=Bradbury, Jamie |publisher=The Football Association |date=12 October 2012 |accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref>
In May 2013, Townsend was charged by [[The Football Association]] over alleged breaches of its rules on betting. He subsequently voluntarily withdrew from England's squad for the upcoming European Under-21 Championship finals.<ref name=BBC22658711>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22658711 |title=Andros Townsend: Spurs midfielder fined over betting |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 June 2013 |accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref> He later admitted to charges under the FA's rules for breaching football betting regulations. After a personal hearing, he was fined £18,000 and suspended for four months backdated to 23 May 2013, with three months suspended until 1 July 2016.<ref name=BBC22658711/>
===Senior team=== Townsend's first call-up to the senior [[England national football team|England squad]] came in September 2013, for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group H|World Cup qualifiers]] against [[Moldova national football team|Moldova]] and [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Andros Townsend and Ross Barkley in England squad|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23853555|accessdate=27 August 2013|publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 October 2013}}</ref> He made his senior debut in the starting eleven against [[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]] in the World Cup qualifier on 11 October, aged 22 years 87 days. He was involved in England's first goal in a 4–1 win, scored the third with a "low swerving finish" from outside the penalty area after 78 minutes, two minutes before being substituted, and was named man of the match.<ref name="England 4–1 Montenegro">{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 4–1 Montenegro |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24393746 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 October 2013 |accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> He earned a second cap in the World Cup qualifier against [[Poland national football team|Poland]], a playing almost all of the 2–0 home win, on 15 October 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|title = englandstats.com {{!}} A Complete Database of England Internationals Since 1872|url = http://englandstats.com/matches.php?mid=925|publisher=Englandstats.com|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref> Two further appearances came in the November friendlies, a 57th minute sub appearance in the 2–0 home defeat to [[Chile national football team|Chile]], and a full match in the 1–0 loss to [[Germany national football team|Germany]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = englandstats.com {{!}} A Complete Database of England Internationals Since 1872|url = http://englandstats.com/matches.php?mid=926|publisher=Englandstats.com|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = englandstats.com {{!}} A Complete Database of England Internationals Since 1872|url = http://englandstats.com/matches.php?mid=927|publisher=Englandstats.com|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref> His fifth cap came as a very late substitute in a March 2014 friendly, a 1–0 home win over [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = englandstats.com {{!}} A Complete Database of England Internationals Since 1872|url = http://englandstats.com/matches.php?mid=928|publisher=Englandstats.com|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref>
A second England goal came in the Euro 2016 qualification campaign in a 5–0 win over [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] on 9 October 2014, as he came on for the final third of the match.<ref name="England 5–0 San Marino">{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 5–0 San Marino |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29454223 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 October 2014 |accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> His next appearance marked his third England goal; on 31 March 2015 he scored the equaliser in the 79th minute against [[Italy national football team|Italy]], having come on as a 70th minute sub in a friendly match which ended 1–1.<ref name="Italy 1–1 England">{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Italy 1–1 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32028730 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 March 2015 |accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> The 20-yard strike was described as a "sweet right-foot drive into the bottom corner"; Townsend took to Twitter immediately after the match to respond to [[Paul Merson]] after he had said Townsend's club form did not justify him being anywhere near the England team.<ref name=espn/> His eighth and ninth caps came in June 2015, first as a 66th minute sub in the 0–0 away draw to [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Ireland]] in a friendly on 7 June 2015, before playing for the first two-thirds of a 3–2 away win over [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]] on 14 June 2015 in the Euro 2016 qualifiers.<ref>{{Cite web|title = englandstats.com {{!}} A Complete Database of England Internationals Since 1872|url = http://englandstats.com/matches.php?mid=943|publisher=Englandstats.com|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = englandstats.com {{!}} A Complete Database of England Internationals Since 1872|url = http://englandstats.com/matches.php?mid=944|publisher=Englandstats.com|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref> His tenth cap was in another Euro 2016 qualifier, this time as a 73rd minute sub in the 3–0 away win over [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]] on 12 October.<ref>{{Cite web|title = englandstats.com {{!}} A Complete Database of England Internationals Since 1872|url = http://englandstats.com/matches.php?mid=948|publisher=Englandstats.com|accessdate = 26 January 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== Townsend was born in [[Leytonstone]], London.<ref name=brief/> He is of paternal [[Jamaican people|Jamaican]] and maternal [[Greek Cypriots|Greek Cypriot]] descent.<ref>{{cite web|title=First Greek Cypriot selected for the full England squad for world cup qualifiers|url=http://www.parikiaki.com/2013/08/first-greek-cypriot-selected-for-the-full-england-squad-for-world-cup-qualifiers|website=Parikiaki|date=August 2013|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> He was brought up in [[Chingford]], and is a lifelong Tottenham fan.<ref name=brief/> He attended [[Rush Croft Sports College]].<ref name=THFCResProfile/>
When he was 10 years old, his older brother Kurtis was killed in a car crash at the age of 18.<ref name=brief/>
Townsend was filmed singing the song ''[[Stand by Me (Ben E. King song)|Stand By Me]]'' by [[Ben E. King]] with the rest of the Tottenham youth players in the dressing room, which became a popular internet video.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.talksport.co.uk/magazine/virals/2011-12-22/video-most-embarrassing-spurs-video-ever-players-sing-stand-me-changing-room| title=Video: Most embarrassing Spurs video ever? Players sing 'Stand By Me' in the changing room!| publisher=Talksport| date=22 December 2011 |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref>

Zaha playing for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in 2016 | fullname = Dazet Wilfried Armel Zaha<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|11|10|df=y}}<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Hugman |editor1-first=Barry J. |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 |publisher=Mainstream Publishing |location=Edinburgh|year=2010 |isbn=978-1-84596-601-0 |page=450}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Abidjan]], Ivory Coast | height = {{convert|1.80|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/teams/first-team/forward/wilfried-zaha/ |title=Wilfried Zaha |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | clubnumber = 11 | youthyears1 = 2004–2010 |youthclubs1 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | years1 = 2010–2013 |clubs1 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] |caps1 = 110 |goals1 = 12 | years2 = 2013–2015 |clubs2 = [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] |caps2 = 2 |goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2013 |clubs3 = → [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (loan) |caps3 = 16 |goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2014 |clubs4 = → [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] (loan) |caps4 = 12 |goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2014–2015 |clubs5 = → [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (loan) |caps5 = 16 |goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2015– |clubs6 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] |caps6 = 139 |goals6 = 29 | nationalyears1 = 2011 |nationalteam1 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] |nationalcaps1 = 2 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2012–2013 |nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] |nationalcaps2 = 13 |nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2012–2013 |nationalteam3 = [[England national football team|England]] |nationalcaps3 = 2 |nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2017– |nationalteam4 = [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] |nationalcaps4 = 9 |nationalgoals4 = 2 | club-update = 19:29, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 12 October 2019 }} '''Dazet Wilfried Armel Zaha''' (born 10 November 1992) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and the [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivorian national team]].
Zaha advanced into the Crystal Palace first team from their academy, in 2010. In January 2013, he transferred to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] for an initial fee of £10 million, [[Alex Ferguson]]'s last transfer before his retirement at the end of the season. Zaha remained on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] at Palace until the end of the season, helping them return to the Premier League. After an unsuccessful 2013–14 season with Manchester United (partly spent on loan at [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]), Zaha returned to Palace in August 2014 on a season-long loan, before rejoining the club on a permanent basis in February 2015.
Born in the Ivory Coast, Zaha grew up in England from the age of four. He made his debut for the [[England national football team|England national team]] in 2012. He made two non-competitive appearances for England, the latter of which came in 2013, before switching his allegiances to the Ivory Coast ahead of the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]].
==Early life== Born in [[Abidjan]], Ivory Coast,<ref>{{Hugman|25842|accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref> Zaha moved with his family – including his eight siblings – to [[Thornton Heath]] in the [[London Borough of Croydon]], at the age of four.<ref name=2012g>{{cite news |last1=Fifield |first1=Dominic |title=Wilfried Zaha agrees to join England squad for Sweden friendly |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/nov/11/wilfried-zaha-england-sweden-friendly |accessdate=11 November 2012 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=11 November 2012 |last2=Taylor |first2=Daniel |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |title=Wilfried Zaha – prince from the Palace now mixing with England royalty |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/nov/12/wilfried-zaha-prince-palace-england |accessdate=12 November 2012 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=12 November 2012 |location=London}}</ref><ref name="Wilfried Zaha: To Manchester United from Ivory Coast">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/20295005 |title=Wilfried Zaha: To Manchester United from Ivory Coast |first1=Frank |last1=Keogh |first2=Gary |last2=Rose |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 January 2013 |accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> He was educated at [[List of schools in the London Borough of Croydon#Primary schools|Whitehorse Manor Junior School]], Thornton Heath and [[List of schools in the London Borough of Croydon#Secondary schools|Selsdon High School]], [[Selsdon]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Lidbetter |first=Ross |title=Wilfried Zaha was always destined to be star, say former teachers |url=http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/Wilfried-Zaha-best-ve-seen-PE-teacher/story-17337578-detail/story.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130505122907/http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/Wilfried-Zaha-best-ve-seen-PE-teacher/story-17337578-detail/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 May 2013 |accessdate=17 November 2012 |newspaper=Croydon Advertiser |date=11 November 2012 }}</ref>
He played football at school, and joined the [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] academy aged 12.<ref name="Wilfried Zaha: To Manchester United from Ivory Coast"/>
==Club career== ===Crystal Palace=== ====2009–10 season==== Zaha was given his Crystal Palace first-team debut at home to [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 27 March 2010 by [[caretaker manager]] [[Paul Hart]] as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Stern John]] with 10 minutes remaining in the 2–1 loss.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8585135.stm |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Cardiff |date=27 March 2010 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=12 August 2010}}</ref> He signed a two-year professional contract with Palace in April.<ref>{{cite news|title=Zaha commits to Eagles|url=http://www.crystalpalace-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/zaha_commits_to_eagles_514538/index.shtml|publisher=Crystal Palace Mad|date=8 April 2010|accessdate=3 February 2013}}</ref>
====2010–11 season==== He quickly progressed through the ranks at Palace and became a key member of the first team during the [[2010–11 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2010–11]] pre-season friendlies.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} On 7 August 2010, he scored his first senior goal in a 3–2 win over [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref name=BBC289590>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8881475.stm |title=Crystal Palace 3–2 Leicester |date=7 August 2010 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=12 August 2010}}</ref> Zaha assisted [[Kieron Cadogan]] in the home match against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] and [[James Vaughan (footballer, born 1988)|James Vaughan]] in the away match against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Kay |title=Wilfred Zaha gives Eagles reason to believe |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1301377/Crystal-Palace-3-Leicester-2-Wilfred-Zaha-gives-Eagles-reason-believe.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=8 August 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2010}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> On 12 April 2011, he was sent off in the 95th minute against Leicester City for an alleged stamp on [[Patrick van Aanholt]] but it was later rescinded.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/12968157 "Leicester 1–1 Crystal Palace"]. BBC Sport. 12 April 2011. Retrieved 21 April 2012.</ref> Zaha ended the season playing a total of 44 matches, while scoring 1 goal and having 2 assists in all competitions.<ref name="Crystal Palace Appearance 2010-11 Statistics">{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Appearances/0,,10794~201010323~7,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121223133747/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Appearances/0,,10794~201010323~7,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 December 2012 |title=Crystal Palace 2010–11 appearance statistics |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=5 September 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Crystal Palace Goal 2010-11 Statistics">{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Goalscorers/0,,10794~201010323~7,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121223143201/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Goalscorers/0,,10794~201010323~7,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 December 2012 |title=Crystal Palace 2010–11 goal statistics |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=5 September 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Crystal Palace 2010-11 Assist Statistics">{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Assists/0,,10794~201010323~7,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121223112657/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Assists/0,,10794~201010323~7,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 December 2012 |title=Crystal Palace 2010–11 assist statistics |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=5 September 2012 }}</ref>
====2011–12 season==== [[File:Wilfried Zaha 2012.jpg|thumb|upright|Zaha with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in 2012]]
Zaha started the 2011–12 season by scoring two goals in a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] match on 23 August 2011 at home to [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Crystal Palace 2–0 Crawley Town|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14539053|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> On 30 November, Zaha impressed in Crystal Palace's 2–1 shock win over Manchester United in the League Cup, constantly sneaking through the United defence and in January, attracting interest from Liverpool and Manchester United.{{Citation needed|date=November 2012}}
In March 2012, Zaha was voted [[English Football League|The Football League]]'s Young Player of the Year.<ref>[http://www.football-league.co.uk/flawards/news/20120311/football-league-award-winners-announced_2293338_2644425 "Football League Awards winners announced"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314204318/http://www.football-league.co.uk/flawards/news/20120311/football-league-award-winners-announced_2293338_2644425 |date=14 March 2012 }}. The Football League. 11 March 2012.</ref>
In the latter part of the season, manager [[Dougie Freedman]] opted to play Zaha as a striker and on 21 April he scored in a 2–2 draw with [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], in a match that saw Reading secure the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] title.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17711652 "Reading 2–2 Crystal Palace"]. BBC Sport. 21 April 2012. Retrieved 21 April 2012.</ref> At the end of the 2011–12 season, Zaha was voted Crystal Palace Young Player of the Year for a second time in a row.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} During this season, he made 48 appearances while scoring 9 goals and recording 5 assists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Appearances/0,,10794~201110323~7,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121223111532/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Appearances/0,,10794~201110323~7,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 December 2012 |title=Crystal Palace 2011–12 appearance statistics |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=5 September 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Crystal Palace Goal 2011–12 Statistics">{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Goalscorers/0,,10794~201110323~7,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121224070741/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Goalscorers/0,,10794~201110323~7,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 December 2012 |title=Crystal Palace 2011–12 goal statistics |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=5 September 2012 }}</ref><ref name="Crystal Palace 2011–12 Assist Statistics">{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Assists/0,,10794~201110323~7,00.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121223142120/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Assists/0,,10794~201110323~7,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 December 2012 |title=Crystal Palace 2011–12 assist statistics |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=5 September 2012 }}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== [[File:Zaha-Cardiff-v-Crystal-Palace-Carling-Cup-SF.jpg|thumb|upright|Zaha in [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] action for Palace against future loan club Cardiff, 2012]] Zaha started the 2012–13 season brightly, getting an assist in the League Cup against [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] and winning a penalty in the first league match against Watford.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Zaha scored his first two goals of the season against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on 2 October 2012.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He then scored two goals in a match again, four days later, in a 4–3 win over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
On 5 March 2013, Zaha scored his first goal for Crystal Palace since being loaned back from Manchester United, in a 4–2 victory against promotion rivals [[Hull City F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21583879 |title=Crystal Palace 4–2 Hull |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 March 2013}}</ref> On 13 May 2013, in the second leg of the [[2013 Football League play-offs#Championship|play-off semi-final]] against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]], Zaha scored two goals in the second half to put Crystal Palace into the play-off final at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Brighton 0 Crystal Palace 2 (agg 0–2): Zaha shows Premier League class to fire Eagles into Wembley showdown with Watford |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2324000/Brighton-0-Crystal-Palace-2--Match-report-Wilfried-Zaha-scores-set-Wembley-date-Watford.html |date=13 May 2013 |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |accessdate=14 May 2013}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> In the [[2013 Football League Championship play-off Final|play-off final]] on 27 May 2013, Zaha won a penalty that was converted to secure Crystal Palace a Premier League spot for 2013–14.<ref>{{cite news |title=Crystal Palace v Watford: Championship play-off final: live |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/championship/10082272/Crystal-Palace-v-Watford-Championship-play-off-final-live.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=27 May 2013 |accessdate=6 June 2013 |location=London |first=Thom |last=Gibbs}}</ref>
===Manchester United=== [[File:Wilfried Zaha 01-02-2014 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Zaha playing on [[loan (sports)|loan]] for [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2014]] On 25 January 2013, Zaha agreed to join [[Premier League]] club [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], and would immediately be loaned back to Crystal Palace for the remainder of the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2013/january/zahas-united-move-agreed/|title=Zaha's United Move Agreed|date=25 January 2013|accessdate=25 January 2013|publisher=Crystal Palace F.C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2013/Jan/zaha-agreement-reached-manchester-united-crystal-palace.aspx|title=Deal agreed for Wilfried Zaha|date=25 January 2013|accessdate=25 January 2013|publisher=Manchester United F.C.}}</ref> Palace tried to delay the transfer and agree the transfer in the summer of 2013, but Football League rules prevented this with the player having to join United and be loaned back to Palace.<ref>{{cite news|title=Manchester United agree £17m Zaha deal|url=http://zeenews.india.com/sports/football/epl-2012/manchester-united/manchester-united-agree-17m-zaha-deal_755557.html|publisher=ZeeNews|date=25 January 2013|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref> Zaha passed the medical at Manchester United, signing a five-and-a-half-year contract on 26 January 2013 for a reported £10m rising to £15m with performance-related add-ons.<ref>{{cite news|title=Exciting youngster Wilfried Zaha has passed his medical at Manchester United|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11667/8439587/Exciting-youngster-Wilfried-Zaha-has-passed-his-medical-at-Manchester-United|publisher=Sky Sports|date=26 January 2013|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref>
On 11 August 2013, Zaha made his debut for Manchester United in the [[2013 FA Community Shield]] against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref name=sb1314/> He was included in the starting line-up and played 61 minutes before being replaced by [[Antonio Valencia]] as he won his first major honour in football.<ref name=FACS>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23565298 |title=Community Shield: Man Utd 2–0 Wigan |first=Tom |last=Rostance |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704152704/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23565298 |archivedate=4 July 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> He did not play again until 29 October, starting in a 4–0 win over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in the third round of the League Cup at [[Old Trafford]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester United 4–0 Norwich City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24619369 |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 October 2013}}</ref> His [[Premier League]] debut was on 7 December in a 1–0 home loss to [[Newcastle United]], as a substitute for [[Nani]] shortly after his team conceded.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bevan |first1=Chris |title=Manchester United 0–1 Newcastle United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25164173 |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2013}}</ref>
On 31 January 2014, Zaha completed a loan move to Cardiff City for the remainder of the [[2013–14 Premier League|2013–14]] season after being left out of favour by manager [[David Moyes]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Transfer deadline day: Man Utd's Zaha joins Cardiff City on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25973209 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2014 |accessdate=2 February 2014}}</ref>
At the end of the season, following Moyes' sacking, Zaha said that he was never given a chance by the Scot. He contrasted his experience with that of [[Raheem Sterling]], another young attacker who was given a chance by [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] after a difficult start. He also said that he was upset by false and malicious online rumours about his personal life.<ref>{{cite news |title=Zaha: Moyes never trusted me |url=http://en.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/306745.html |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=ESPN FC |date=11 May 2014}}</ref>
===Return to Crystal Palace=== ====2014–15 season==== On 28 August 2014, Zaha agreed to a season-long loan deal with Crystal Palace.<ref>{{cite web |title=Wilfried Zaha rejoins Crystal Palace on loan from Man Utd |url=http://www.espnfc.us/story/2007971/wilfried-zaha-rejoins-crystal-palace-on-loan-from-man-utd |publisher=ESPN FC |date=28 August 2014 |accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref> Two days later, in the first match of his loan, he scored a stoppage-time equaliser in a 3–3 draw at [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Taylor |first=Louise |title=Crystal Palace's Wilfried Zaha scores last-gasp equaliser at Newcastle |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/30/newcastle-crystal-palace-premier-league-match-report |accessdate=30 August 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=30 August 2014 |location=London}}</ref> On 2 February 2015, the final day of the winter transfer window, Zaha's move to Palace was made permanent with the signing of a five-and-a-half-year contract for an undisclosed fee. It also included a buy back clause,<ref>{{cite web |title=Wilf returns home |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/february/wilf-returns-home/ |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |date=2 February 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref> believed to be in the region of £3 million, rising to £6 million with add-ons; Manchester United will also receive a percentage of the fee if Palace sell Zaha in the future.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wilfried Zaha 'glad to be back permanently' at Crystal Palace |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31099507 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 February 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref>
Zaha played regularly for Crystal Palace throughout the season, finishing the season with four goals and two assists as Crystal Palace finished the league in 10th place.<ref>{{cite web |title=Wilfried Zaha statistics |url=https://www.whoscored.com/Players/85059/History/Wilfried-Zaha |publisher=Whoscored |date=10 December 2016 |accessdate=10 December 2016}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== Again, Zaha was a regular for Crystal Palace in this season, making 34 appearances, scoring two goals and recording one assist, while Crystal Palace finished in 15th place.<ref name=sb1516/> He helped Crystal Palace reach the [[2016 FA Cup Final]], by playing in every match since the third round entry and scoring two goals along the way.<ref name=sb1516/> Zaha played the whole 120 minutes in the final, but could not help Palace to a victory, as Manchester United won 2–1.<ref name=FAC2016>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36292265 |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Manchester United |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2016 |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref> Zaha won the [[Crystal Palace F.C. Player of the Year|Crystal Palace Player of the Year]] award for the first time.<ref name=POTY2016>{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2016/may/zaha-wins-cpfc-player-of-the-year/ |title=Zaha wins CPFC Player of the Year |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |date=12 May 2016 |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== On 26 December 2016, Zaha was declined a penalty in the closing minutes against Watford. Some speculated that Zaha had overplayed the foul or taken a dive. After the match Watford's mascot attempted to rile Zaha up by mimicking a dive in front of him.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/watford-mascot-harry-the-hornet-wilfried-zaha-video-diving-a7497211.html |title=Watford mascot Harry the Hornet captured on video diving behind Crystal Palace winger Wilfried Zaha |first=Jack|last=De Menezes |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=27 December 2016 |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/12/26/harry-hornet-order-mocking-wilfried-zaha-says-sam-allardyce/ |title=Harry the Hornet 'out of order' for mocking Wilfried Zaha after Watford vs Crystal Palace, says Sam Allardyce |first=Sean |last=Gibson |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=27 December 2016 |accessdate=12 June 2016}}</ref> On 14 May 2017, Zaha scored the opening goal in the third minute of the Crystal Palace Hull city game<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39833968 |title=Crystal Palace 4–0 Hull City |first=Neil |last=Johnston |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2017 |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref> that simultaneously mathematically secured Crystal Palace's top flight status and relegated Hull City to the Championship.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20170921155912/https://www.londonnewsonline.co.uk/24046/crystal-palace-safe-resounding-victory-relegated-hull-city/ "Crystal Palace mathematically safe"]. LondonNewsOnline. 14 May 2017. Retrieved 15 May 2017. Archived on 21 September 2017</ref> After another outstanding season with The Eagles, Zaha won Crystal Palace's Player of the Year award for the second year running.<ref name=POTY2017>{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2017/may/wilf-wins-player-of-the-year/ |title=Wilf wins Player of the Year |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |date=14 May 2017 |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref> On 26 May 2017, Zaha signed a new five-year contract with Crystal Palace.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40054740 |title=Wilfried Zaha: Crystal Palace winger extends deal by five years |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2017 |accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== [[File:2017-12-02 WestBrom23 (38774549002).jpg|thumb|right|Zaha ''(right)'' playing for Palace, 2017]] On 14 October 2017, Zaha returned to Palace's starting line-up for the first time in two months and scored to open a 2–1 win over Chelsea to give the Eagles their first points of the season.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Fifield |first1=Dominic |title=Crystal Palace shock champions Chelsea as Wilfried Zaha secures vital win |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/oct/14/crystal-palace-chelsea-premier-league-match-report |accessdate=12 August 2018 |work=The Observer |date=14 October 2017}}</ref> He was [[Premier League Player of the Month]] for April 2018 for his four goals and assist while playing up front;<ref name=potm>{{cite news|title=Zaha claims first EA SPORTS Player of the Month award|publisher=Premier League |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/682756 |language=en|date=9 May 2018|accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref> on 14 April he scored twice in the first half of a 3–2 win over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.–Crystal Palace F.C. rivalry|rivals]] [[Brighton & Hove Albion]].<ref name=brighton>{{cite news |last1=Winrow |first1=Ian |title=Wilfried Zaha scores twice as Crystal Palace close on rivals Brighton |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/04/14/wilfried-zaha-scores-twice-crystal-palace-close-rivals-brighton/ |accessdate=12 August 2018 |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=13 April 2018}}</ref>
Despite their poor start, Palace stayed up with a game in hand under new manager [[Roy Hodgson]], with the combination between Zaha and fellow winger [[Andros Townsend]] a key factor.<ref name = "move up front">{{cite news |last1=Clarke |first1=Adrian |title=Move up front makes Zaha a striking force |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/668140 |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=Premier League |date=20 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=McNulty |first1=Phil |title=Premier League: Crystal Palace and Stoke – how one stayed up and one went down |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44017358 |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Palace survival depends on Zaha staying fit, says Townsend |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-england-cry-townsend/palace-survival-depends-on-zaha-staying-fit-says-townsend-idUKKBN1GV0NJ |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=Reuters |date=19 March 2018}}</ref> He was named their Player of the Year for the third time in a row, a feat only done before by goalkeeper [[Julián Speroni]].<ref name=poty18>{{cite news |title=Zaha Named Palace’s 2017/18 Player of the Year |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2018/may/zaha-named-palaces-201718-player-of-the-year/ |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |date=9 May 2018}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== In Palace's first game of the new season on 11 August, Zaha scored the second goal of a 2–0 win at Fulham. It was his 23rd Premier League goal for the club, drawing level with [[Chris Armstrong (footballer, born 1971)|Chris Armstrong]] as their top scorer in the competition's history.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Marsh |first1=Charlotte |title=Fulham 0–2 Crystal Palace: Wilfried Zaha on target in Palace win |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/fulham-vs-c-palace/390759 |accessdate=11 August 2018 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=11 August 2018}}</ref> Fifteen days later, with a consolation goal in a 2–1 loss at Watford, he overtook Armstrong.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Fayiga |first1=Kunle |title=Wilfried Zaha can truly be fulfilled at Crystal Palace |url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/wilfried-zaha-can-truly-be-fulfilled-at-crystal-palace/w0120dqxwdkr1an8d8qjcjghy |accessdate=30 August 2018 |publisher=Goal.com |date=28 August 2018}}</ref>
After scoring a winning goal against [[Huddersfield Town]] in September 2018, Zaha publicly complained about what he considered to be a lack of appropriate protection by referees against fouls, saying that he would need a broken leg before any action would be taken. Data proved that in the last five years, he was the second most fouled player in the league after [[Eden Hazard]].<ref name=bysouth>{{cite news |last1=Bysouth |first1=Alex |title=Wilfried Zaha: Is the Crystal Palace winger a target? Does he get enough protection? |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45537498 |accessdate=19 September 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 September 2018}}</ref>
Zaha received a [[Penalty card#Red card|red card]] for dissent against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 30 January 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/01/30/wilfried-zaha-scores-sees-red-southampton-crystal-palace-share/|title=Wilfried Zaha scores and sees red as Southampton and Crystal Palace share spoils in scrappy draw|first=Jim|last=White|date=30 January 2019|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref>
==International career== Zaha was eligible to represent both the [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] and [[England national football team|England]], the former because he has Ivorian parents and it was where he was born, and the latter because it is where he grew up.<ref>{{cite news |title=Exclusive: Stick with England, Pearce pleads with Palace wonderkid Zaha |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2109427/Stuart-Pearce-tells-Wilfried-Zaha-stick-England.html |location=London |newspaper=Daily Mail |first=Sami |last=Mokbel |date=2 March 2012}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref>
===England (2011–2013)=== His success over the course of his first full season resulted in a call-up to the [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19]] team for their match against [[Germany national youth football team|Germany]] in February 2011.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He was called up to the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] team on 23 February 2012.<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2012/England-v-Belgium/Match-Previews/england-under-21s-squad-middlesbrough.aspx "Zaha earns first U21s call"]. The Football Association. 23 February 2012. Retrieved 21 April 2012.</ref> He made his debut in a 4–0 win against [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium]] on 29 February, assisting [[Henri Lansbury]] for the third goal.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17211368 "England 4–0 Belgium"]. BBC Sport. 29 February 2012. Retrieved 21 April 2012.</ref> On 11 November 2012, Zaha was called up to the senior team by manager [[Roy Hodgson]] for a friendly match against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] on 14 November. He came on as a substitute for fellow debutant [[Raheem Sterling]] in the 83rd minute.<ref>[http://www.thefa.com/England/News/2012/squad-update-111112 "England squad update"]. The Football Association. 11 November 2012. Retrieved 11 November 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Sweden 4–2 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20306158 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 November 2012 |accessdate=15 November 2012}}</ref>
When Zaha was in good form for Crystal Palace under Hodgson ahead of the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], the manager said that he regretted not fielding the winger in a competitive game to tie him to England.<ref name=brighton/>
===Ivory Coast (2016–present)=== On 27 November 2016, the [[Ivorian Football Federation]] confirmed that Zaha had sent correspondence to [[FIFA]] to switch his international football allegiance from England to the [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]].<ref>[http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/10675387/wilfried-zaha-swaps-england-for-the-ivory-coast "Wilfried Zaha swaps England for the Ivory Coast"]. Sky Sports. 27 November 2016. Retrieved 28 November 2016.</ref> In response to this development, England manager [[Gareth Southgate]] indicated he would try to dissuade Zaha from changing allegiance due to his consistent club form.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/10682854/gareth-southgate-to-speak-to-wilfried-zaha-over-switch-to-ivory-coast|title=Gareth Southgate to speak to Wilfried Zaha over switch to Ivory Coast|publisher=Sky Sports|date=3 December 2016|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref>
In January, Zaha was named in the Ivory Coast squad for the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38451141|title=Afcon 2017: Wilfried Zaha in Ivory Coast's final squad|publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 January 2017|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> He made his debut against Sweden in a friendly in [[Abu Dhabi]] on 8 January, coming on as a half-time substitute and assisting [[Giovanni Sio]]'s goal in a 2–1 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/sweden-vs-ivory-coast/teams/368294|title=Internationals (Sky Sports)|publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> Three days later, against [[Uganda national football team|Uganda]] at the same venue, he made his first international start and scored his first goal in a 3–0 win.<ref name=uganda/> At the tournament in Gabon, the reigning champion Elephants were eliminated at the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations Group B|group stage]], with Zaha starting each game.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ivory Coast 0–0 Togo |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38605798 |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Ivory Coast 2–2 DR Congo |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38605798 |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Morocco 1–0 Ivory Coast |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38646336 |accessdate=12 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 January 2017}}</ref>
==Style of play== Zaha can play as a [[forward (association football)|forward]] or as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]].<ref name="move up front" /> In 2018, Adrian Clarke of the Premier League's website opined that he "offers more threat" as a frontman, going on to add that "his ultra-mobile combination with [Andros] Townsend generates more goals and points", citing "the speed, athleticism and unpredictable movement of the Zaha-Townsend axis is more difficult for opponents to contain".<ref name="move up front" />
Zaha has been accused of [[diving (association football)|diving]], however Roy Hodgson, who managed him at club level for Crystal Palace and internationally [[England national football team manager|for England]], has stated: "Wilf Zaha does not dive for penalties. He gets knocked over sometimes – sometimes he gets knocked over or unbalanced without it being a penalty or a foul – because he runs at such speed and has such agility with the ball. But he certainly doesn’t dive".<ref>{{cite news|title=Roy Hodgson warns ‘disgraceful’ Harry the Hornet over diving antics|agency=Press Association|date=24 August 2018|accessdate=24 August 2018|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Media Group|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/aug/24/roy-hodgson-warns-disgraceful-harry-the-hornet-over-diving-antics}}</ref> Hodgson also said that Zaha's characterisation as a diver is because of a "campaign" and it causes fouls against him to be dismissed by referees.<ref name=bysouth/>
==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 9 March 2019}}
