'''Mamadou Sakho''' (born 13 February 1990) is a French professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[centre back]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and the [[France national football team|France national team]]. He is known for his tackling ability and his passing accuracy.
Sakho began his career at [[Paris FC]] before moving to [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]]'s youth system in 2002. In October 2007, on his league debut, he became the youngest player ever to captain a [[Ligue 1]] club. Sakho made over 200 appearances for the club, winning all four [[Football in France|domestic trophies]]. In 2013, he transferred to Liverpool for £18 million. He had a loan spell with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in 2017, and was subsequently bought by the team for £26 million on 1 September 2017.
Sakho is a full international, who has previously earned caps and [[Captain (association football)|captained]] the nation at all youth levels. Since making his senior debut in 2010 against [[England national football team|England]], Sakho has over 25 caps and represented France at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].
==Early life== Sakho was born in [[Paris]] to [[Senegal]]ese parents and was the fourth child of a family of seven children.<ref name="biographie_sakho">{{cite news|url=http://www.mamadousakho.fr/fr/biographie-mamadou-sakho/ |title=Biographie 1/2 |accessdate=10 April 2010 |publisher=Mamadou Sakho Official Website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100312221958/http://www.mamadousakho.fr/fr/biographie-mamadou-sakho/ |archivedate=12 March 2010 }}</ref> He was raised in the northern neighborhood of [[Goutte d'Or]].<ref name="Dyer">Dyer, Ervin. "[http://www.post-gazette.com/travel/20021027paris1027trp2.asp Little Africa in Paris is a continent within a city]." ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''. Sunday 27 October 2002. Retrieved 22 February 2010.</ref>
==Club career== ===Early career=== Sakho started his football career at the age of six playing for the juniors of hometown club [[Paris FC]].{{citation needed|date=January 2019}} In 2002, he was lured away to professional club [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]]. Sakho was originally a striker, but due to Paris Saint-Germain's youth team having fewer defenders than strikers, he was moved into a more defensive role.
Sakho struggled to adapt during his first year at the [[Camp des Loges]], the headquarters of the club's [[Youth system|youth academy]], often refusing to accept orders handed out by the trainers, such as when to go to bed. At one point, he was threatened with expulsion from the club due to his constant bad behavior. Following guidance from his parents and, particularly, under-13 Paris Saint-Germain coach Christian Mas, Sakho curbed his bad behavior and began to focus on his studies and football. When Sakho was 14, his father suddenly died. The resulting pain led to Sakho considering leaving football, but he later described that idea as "useless" and returned to the club after [[Grief|bereavement]]. Sakho quickly became one of the club's most sought after prospects winning numerous [[Most Valuable Player|MVP]] awards during his time in the youth academy. In April 2005, he was a part of the [[Île-de-France (region)|Île-de-France]] [[Regions of France|region]] team that won the 2004–05 Coupe Nationale. That same year, he was a part of the Paris Saint-Germain under-18 team that won the ''Championnat National des 18 ans'' league title, despite being three years younger than many of his teammates.<ref name ="biographie_sakho" />
In total, Sakho spent nearly six years at the [[Camp des Loges]]. A day after his 17th birthday, manager [[Paul Le Guen]] called the youngster up for the club's [[UEFA Cup]] Round of 32 first leg match against [[AEK Athens F.C.|AEK Athens]] on 14 February 2007. Sakho started the match picking up a yellow card in the 20th minute. He played 85 minutes before being substituted out as Paris Saint-Germain won the match 2–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/uefacup/history/season=2006/round=2366/match=85542/report=lu.html | title = AEK v. PSG Match Report |date= 14 February 2007 | accessdate =10 April 2010 |publisher=UEFA}}</ref> Sakho played his second and final match of the season in the [[UEFA Cup]] Round of 16 first leg match against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]], he played the full match in a 2–1 victory.
===Paris Saint-Germain===
====2007–10==== On 14 June 2007, Sakho signed his first professional contract agreeing to a three-year deal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://psgenforceleblog.football.fr/post/2007/06/14/740-mamadou-sakho-signe-pro?post_id=87615&vote=yes&mode=url |title= Mamadou Sakho signe pro |date= 14 June 2007 | accessdate =10 April 2010 | publisher=PSG En Force | language = French }}</ref> He was officially promoted to the senior side for the [[Ligue 1 2007–08|2007–08 season]], despite being only 17 years old, and was assigned the first team number 3 shirt. Sakho made his first start that season for Paris Saint-Germain in the club's 3–0 win over [[FC Lorient|Lorient]] in the [[Coupe de la Ligue]] on 26 September 2007, starting in the centre back role alongside the experienced Colombian [[Mario Yepes]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lfp.fr/coupeLigue/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007/2008&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=T95&num_ordre=2 | title = Lorient v. PSG Match Report | date = 26 September 2007 | accessdate = 10 April 2010 | publisher = Ligue du Professionnel Football | language = French }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Sakho made his league debut on 20 October against [[Valenciennes FC|Valeciennes]] in a 0–0 draw.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lfp.fr/joueur/detail_tempsJeu.asp?no_joueur=108943&saison=2007/2008&code_evt=D1 | title = Mamadou SAKHO | accessdate = 10 April 2010 | publisher = Ligue du Professionnel Football | language = French | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090202154819/http://www.lfp.fr/joueur/detail_tempsJeu.asp?no_joueur=108943&saison=2007%2F2008&code_evt=D1 | archivedate = 2 February 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> In an effort to galvanize the questionable leadership of several senior team players, such as first-team captain [[Pauleta]] and vice-captain [[Sylvain Armand]], Le Guen named Sakho captain for the match. Sakho's role as captain made him the youngest-ever captain of Paris Saint-Germain at the age of 17 years and 8 months and also the youngest player to ever captain a side in [[Ligue 1]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007/2008&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=J11&num_ordre=10 | title = FEUILLE DE MATCH 11ème Journée | date = 20 October 2007 | accessdate = 10 April 2010 | publisher = Ligue du Professionnel Football | language = French | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090524204528/http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007%2F2008&code_evt=D1&num_ordre=10&code_jr_tr=J11 | archivedate = 24 May 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> In the following match against [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]], he was named captain again and tasked with the role of containing fellow French starlet [[Hatem Ben Arfa]]. Despite Sakho and the club putting up a strong fight, Ben Arfa scored two goals in a span of three minutes as ''Les Parisiens'' suffered a 3–2 defeat.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007/2008&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=J12&num_ordre=8 | title = FEUILLE DE MATCH 12ème Journée | date = 27 October 2007 | accessdate = 10 April 2010 | publisher = Ligue du Professionnel Football | language = French | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090202154918/http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007%2F2008&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=J12&num_ordre=8 | archivedate = 2 February 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> In the club's following match against [[AS Nancy|Nancy]], Sakho picked up an extensive injury, which ruled him out for two months.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet-assets.espn.go.com/gamecast?id=252289&cc=5901 |title=PSG v. Nancy Match Report |date=3 November 2007 |accessdate=10 April 2010 |publisher=[[ESPN]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005143957/http://soccernet-assets.espn.go.com/gamecast?id=252289&cc=5901 |archivedate=5 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He returned to action on 23 February 2008, playing the entire match in a 1–1 draw against [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007/2008&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=J26&num_ordre=6 | title = PSG v. Monaco Match Report | date = 23 February 2008 | accessdate = 10 April 2010 | publisher = Ligue du Professionnel Football | language = French | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090603001909/http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2007%2F2008&code_evt=D1&num_ordre=6&code_jr_tr=J26 | archivedate = 3 June 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> On 29 March, Sakho started and play the full 90 minutes in the Paris Saint-Germain's 2–1 victory over [[RC Lens|Lens]] in the [[Coupe de la Ligue Final 2008|2008 Coupe de la Ligue Final]]. The victory awarded Sakho the first major trophy of his career. In total that season, Sakho made 16 appearances.
In the [[Ligue 1 2008–09|following season]], Sakho made 34 total appearances contributing to the Paris Saint-Germain's successful play where the club reached as high as 2nd in the league, reached the semi-finals of the [[Coupe de France]], and made it to the [[2008-09 UEFA Cup#Quarter-finals|UEFA Cup quarterfinals]]. On 30 January 2009, due to his positive play and clubs from abroad constantly inquiring for his services, Paris Saint-Germain awarded Sakho a contract extension until the June 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.leparisien.fr/psg-foot-paris-saint-germain/psg-mamadou-sakho-prolonge-mulumbu-revient-30-01-2009-392726.php | title = Mamadou Sakho prolonge, Mulumbu revient |date= 30 January 2009 | accessdate =10 April 2010 |work=Le Parisien | language = French }}</ref> Two weeks later, he scored his first career goal for the club in a league match against [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]] on 14 February 2009, a day after his 19th birthday. The goal gave Paris Saint-Germain a 1–0 lead and the club went on to win the match 2–1.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2008/2009&code_evt=D1&code_jr_tr=J24&num_ordre=7 | title = PSG v. Saint Etienne Match Report | date = 14 February 2009 | accessdate = 10 April 2010 | publisher = Ligue du Professionnel Football | language = French | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090426084327/http://lfp.fr/ligue1/feuilleMatch.asp?saison=2008%2F2009&code_evt=D1&num_ordre=7&code_jr_tr=J24 | archivedate = 26 April 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
Sakho opened the [[2009–10 Ligue 1|2009–10 season]] as the incumbent starter partnering either veterans [[Sammy Traoré]] or [[Zoumana Camara]] in defense. Midway through the season, Sakho was embroiled in controversy when he allegedly slapped a ''[[Le Parisien]]'' newspaper journalist at the [[Camp des Loges]], the club's training center. Before the incident, Sakho had allegedly confronted the journalist to question the accuracy of an article he had written referring to the controversy surrounding why Sakho went to a [[nightclub]] following Paris Saint-Germain's embarrassing loss to [[FC Lorient|Lorient]] hours earlier.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lepost.fr/article/2010/02/11/1936958_un-joueur-du-psg-frappe-un-journaliste_2.html | title = Un journaliste frappé par le joueur Mamadou Sakho: "Il m'a insulté et m'a mis une claque" |date= 11 February 2010 | accessdate =10 April 2010 | publisher=Le Post | language = French }}</ref> Sakho reportedly insulted the journalist and then slapped him before walking away. The journalist, who preferred to remain [[Anonymity|anonymous]], filed a complaint the following day with both he and the newspaper describing Sakho's attitude as "unprofessional". Paris Saint-Germain president Robin Leproux and manager [[Antoine Kombouaré]] issued an apology on the club's behalf and Sakho later apologized to the journalist by telephone.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://fr.novopress.info/49011/psg-mamadou-sakho-frappe-un-journaliste/ | title = Mamadou Sakho frappe un journaliste | date = 12 February 2010 | accessdate = 10 April 2010 | publisher = NovoPress | language = French | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100330132226/http://fr.novopress.info/49011/psg-mamadou-sakho-frappe-un-journaliste/ | archivedate = 30 March 2010 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espoirsdufootball.com/10364-psg-mamadou-sakho-frappe-un-journaliste.html | title = PSG – Mamadou Sakho frappe un journaliste |date= 12 February 2010 | accessdate =10 April 2010 | publisher=Espoirs du Football | language = French }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foot01.com/equipe/paris/sakho-frappe-au-porte-monnaie,46921 | title = Sakho frappé au porte-monnaie |date= 12 February 2010 | accessdate =10 April 2010 | publisher=Foot 01 | language = French }}</ref>
====2010–13==== [[File:Mamadou Sakho, PSG.JPG|thumb|Sakho signing autographs at [[Paris Saint Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]].]] Sakho started the [[2010–11 in French football|2010–11 campaign]] partnering with Camara in defense. He was also installed as the team's captain in the [[UEFA Europa League]] by manager Kombouaré due to the unavailability of [[Claude Makelele]]. Midway through August, Sakho began appearing in the centre back position alongside veteran [[Sylvain Armand]]. He scored his first goal of the season on 11 September 2010 in a 4–0 victory over [[AC Arles-Avignon|Arles-Avignon]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53680 | title = Paris SG v. Arles-Avignon Match Report |date= 11 September 2010 | accessdate =11 October 2010 | publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | language = French }}</ref> In Europe, Sakho captained the team in their 5–4 aggregate victory over Israeli club [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] in the Europa League playoff round.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000127/match=2003059/index.html | title = Paris SG v. Maccabi Tel Aviv Match Report |date= 19 August 2010 | accessdate =11 October 2010 | publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000127/match=2003096/index.html | title = Maccabi Tel Aviv v. Paris SG Match Report |date= 26 August 2010 | accessdate =11 October 2010 | publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] }}</ref> He accomplished this feat again in the group stage leading the team to a 2–0 victory over Ukrainian club [[FC Karpaty Lviv|Karpaty Lviv]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000128/match=2002955/postmatch/index.html | title = PSG profit from perfect start |date= 30 September 2010 | accessdate =11 October 2010 | publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] }}</ref> On 16 October, Sakho scored the game-winning goal in a 2–0 victory over [[Toulouse FC|Toulouse]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53717 | title = Toulouse v. Paris SG Match Report |date= 16 October 2010 | accessdate =20 April 2011 | publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | language = French }}</ref> In the team's first match following the winter break, he scored his third goal of the campaign in Paris Saint-Germain's victory over [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53856 | title = Paris SG v. Sochaux Match Report |date= 15 January 2011 | accessdate =20 April 2011 | publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | language = French }}</ref> After a prolonged period of negotiations, on 8 March 2011, Sakho signed a two-year contract extension with the club until June 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12875_6802354,00.html | title = PSG seal Sakho extension |date= 8 March 2011 | accessdate =9 March 2011 | publisher=[[Sky Sports]] }}</ref> On 20 April, he captained the team to a 3–1 victory over [[Angers SCO|Angers]] in the semi-finals of the Coupe de France. The victory inserted the club into the [[2011 Coupe de France Final]]; the club's second consecutive appearance in the competition's final match.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://le75020.fr/paris-XXe-75020-20e-arrondissement/vie-locale/sports/27931-angers-psg-sakho-stade-de-france.paris-75020-info?etmonth=201104&etpostid=27567 | title = Angers – PSG: Sakho au Stade de France |date= 21 April 2011 | accessdate =21 April 2011 | publisher=Le 75020 | language = French }}</ref> Paris Saint-Germain lost the match 1–0 to [[Lille OSC|Lille]]. On 10 May, Sakho was nominated for the [[National Union of Professional Footballers]] (UNFP) [[Trophées UNFP du football#Young Player of the Year|Young Player of the Year]] award. Two weeks later, he won the honour. Sakho was also named to the organization's Team of the Year alongside club teammate [[Nenê (footballer)|Nenê]].<ref>{{cite news |title=UNFP: Trophées UNFP du football Un petit coin de paradis...|url=http://www.unfp.org/a-la-une/actualite-detaillee/cat/19/article/un-petit-coin-de-paradis.html |work=[[National Union of Professional Footballers]] |date= 22 May 2011 |accessdate=22 May 2011 | language = French}}</ref>
Sakho began the [[2011–12 in French football|2011–12 season]] as the club's first-choice captain under Kombouaré. On 13 August 2011, in the club's second league match of the season, he suffered a [[hamstring]] injury.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mamadou Sakho blessé pour trois semaines|url=http://www.chronofoot.com/psg/psg-mamadou-sakho-blesse-pour-trois-semaines_art17181.html |work=Chronofoot |date= 15 August 2011 |accessdate=14 May 2012 | language = French}}</ref> Despite initially being ruled out for three weeks, Sakho missed two months and returned to the team in its 3–1 away win over [[AC Ajaccio|Ajaccio]]. He remained a fixture in the team for the rest of the autumn campaign as PSG finished the first half of the league in first-place position.<ref>{{cite news |title=Le PSG champion d'automne, Montpellier prend l'eau|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/sport/article/2011/12/21/le-psg-champion-d-automne-apres-avoir-battu-saint-etienne-1-0_1621302_3242.html |work=[[Le Monde]] |date= 21 December 2011 |accessdate=14 May 2012 | language = French}}</ref> In January 2012, Kombouaré resigned from his position. He was replaced by Italian manager [[Carlo Ancelotti]]. Under the helm of Ancelotti, Sakho retained the captaincy and appeared as a starter through March. However, after unconvincing performances in draws with Lyon, [[Stade Malherbe Caen|Caen]], and Bordeaux, which resulted in the club losing its grip on first place, the captain was benched by Ancelotti and stripped of the captaincy. Ancelotti based Sakho's benching on the increased competition in the squad as the Italian preferred the central duo of [[Milan Biševac]] and [[Alex (footballer, born 1982)|Alex]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Carlo Ancelotti cherche encore son capitaine|url=http://www.chronofoot.com/psg/psg-carlo-ancelotti-cherche-encore-son-capitaine_art31086.html |work=Chronofoot |date= 9 May 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012 | language = French}}</ref><ref name="leparisien.fr">{{cite news |title=Bisevac-Alex, les deux font la paire|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/psg-foot-paris-saint-germain/bisevac-alex-les-deux-font-la-paire-14-04-2012-1954337.php |work=[[Le Parisien]] |date= 14 April 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012 | language = French}}</ref><ref name="leparisien.fr"/> Sakho was also questioned by club director [[Leonardo Araújo|Leonardo]] for being "slightly overweight".<ref>{{cite news |title=Le titre, le cas Mamadou Sakho, le mercato: Carlo Ancelotti dit tout!|url=http://www.footmercato.net/ligue1/le-titre-le-cas-mamadou-sakho-le-mercato-carlo-ancelotti-dit-tout_84219 |work=FootMercato |date= 30 April 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012 | language = French}}</ref>
After making a cameo appearance in the ''[[Le Classique]]'',<ref>{{cite news |title=Sakho ne voit rien venir |url=http://www.leparisien.fr/psg-foot-paris-saint-germain/sakho-ne-voit-rien-venir-20-04-2012-1963388.php |work=[[Le Parisien]] |date= 20 April 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012 | language = French}}</ref> Sakho made his second appearance since his benching on 29 April 2012 appearing as a first-half substitute for the injured Biševac against fellow title contenders [[Lille OSC|Lille]]. In the second half, with ''Les Parisiens'' leading 1–0, Sakho conceded a penalty after fouling striker [[Nolan Roux]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Sakho aura du mal à s'en remettre|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/psg-foot-paris-saint-germain/sakho-aura-du-mal-a-s-en-remettre-30-04-2012-1978456.php |work=[[Le Parisien]] |date= 30 April 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012 | language = French}}</ref> The foul also resulted in a [[Penalty card|red card]]. Lille converted the penalty and later went on to win the match 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Lille v. Paris SG Report|url=http://www.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/74701 |work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date= 30 April 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012 | language = French}}</ref>
On 26 May, in PSG's final game of the season having already won the league, Sakho came on as an emergency goalkeeper for the final seven minutes against [[FC Lorient|Lorient]] after substitute goalkeeper [[Ronan Le Crom]] had been sent off for fouling [[Julien Quercia]] to give away a penalty. [[Arnaud Le Lan]] converted the penalty, but PSG won 3–1.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lorient 1–3 Paris Saint-Germain: Gameiro at the double but Sakho in goal as champions' season finishes in farce|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/lorient-vs-psg/1286387/report|accessdate=30 November 2014|work=Goal.com|date=23 May 2013}}</ref>
===Liverpool=== [[File:A Cissokho, K Jones, M Sakho 2014.jpg|thumb|Sakho (right) playing for Liverpool against [[Cardiff City FC|Cardiff City]] in 2014.]]
On 2 September 2013, [[Premier League]] club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] announced the signing of Sakho for a fee of £18 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/144053-reds-announce-sakho-signing|title=Reds announce Sakho signing|date=2 September 2013|accessdate=2 September 2013|publisher=Liverpool F.C.}}</ref>
====2013–14==== Sakho made his debut on 16 September 2013 against [[Swansea City F.C.|Swansea City]] in a 2–2 draw at the [[Liberty Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2422852/Swansea-2-Liverpool-2-match-report--Jonjo-Shelvey-match-match--Martin-Samuel.html|title= Swansea 2 Liverpool 2|date=16 September 2013|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref> Liverpool manager [[Brendan Rodgers]] had described the Frenchman as "a beast in training" prior to his debut.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brendan Rodgers Says Mamadou Sakho, Tiago Ilori Can Give Liverpool Defensive Security for 'Next 10 Years'|url=http://nesn.com/2013/09/brendan-rodgers-says-mamadou-sakho-tiago-ilori-can-give-liverpool-defensive-security-next-10-years/|accessdate=22 November 2013|publisher=NESN|date=16 September 2013}}</ref> On 7 December 2013, Sakho scored his first goal for Liverpool in a 4–1 win at [[Anfield]] against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Late Suarez double sinks West Ham|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/150731-late-suarez-double-sinks-west-ham|accessdate=7 December 2013|newspaper=liverpoolfc.com|date=7 December 2013}}</ref> Intermittent injuries limited Sakho to just 19 appearances, however he played a key role in Liverpool's surprise [[2013–14 Liverpool F.C. season|title challenge]] where they eventually finished as runners-up in the Premier League.
====2014–15==== On 27 September 2014, Sakho was left out of the squad for the Merseyside Derby clash against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. Upon hearing the manager's decision, he left the stadium. The Frenchman later apologised for his action.<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool's Mamadou Sakho apologises for leaving Anfield before derby|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/sep/28/liverpool-sakho-apologises-leaving-merseyside-derby-everton|accessdate=28 December 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=28 September 2014}}</ref> After a poor beginning to the [[2014–15 Liverpool F.C. season|season]], manager [[Brendan Rodgers]] switched to a 3-man defensive line in October – with Sakho playing a crucial part. His pace, athleticism, and ball playing abilities were key in this formation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Munton|first1=Max|title=What Is Brendan Rodgers' Best Defensive Line-Up at Liverpool?|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2390145-what-is-brendan-rodgers-best-defensive-line-up-at-liverpool|publisher=[[Bleacher Report]]|accessdate=4 November 2015|date=9 March 2015}}</ref> Sakho returned to the Liverpool team for a 2–2 draw with [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 22 December 2014<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.football365.com/f365-says/9616503/16-Conclusions-Liverpool-2-2-Arsenal|title=16 Conclusions: Liverpool 2–2 Arsenal|date=22 December 2014|work=Football365}}</ref> and went on to help the Reds to five clean sheets in eight [[2014–15 Premier League|Premier League]] matches.<ref>{{Cite new|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/profile.statistics.html/mamadou-sakho|title=Mamadou Sakho|accessdate=8 February 2015|work=Premier League}}</ref>
====2015–16==== Sakho began the season as backup to [[Dejan Lovren]]. On 17 September 2015, Sakho made his first start of the season; a man-of-the-match performance in a [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League group stage#Group B|Europa League]] away match against [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]], captaining the side in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers buoyed by young team|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34286275|accessdate=18 September 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> A day later, it was announced that he had signed a new long-term contract with the club.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sakho signs new long-term LFC contract|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/194067-sakho-signs-new-long-term-lfc-contract|publisher=Liverpool FC|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Sakho was restored to the starting lineup and under new manager [[Jürgen Klopp]] was praised for his excellent form.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ullal|first1=Naveen|title=Mamadou Sakho and Lucas have rediscovered their form under Jurgen Klopp says John Aldridge|url=https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/liverpool-mamadou-sakho-lucas-rediscovered-061037313.html|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|accessdate=4 November 2015|date=4 November 2015}}</ref> On 8 November, however, he sustained a knee injury in a 2–1 defeat to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at Anfield that ruled him out for two months.<ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool's Mamadou Sakho out six to eight weeks with knee injury|url=http://www.espnfc.com/liverpool/story/2709248/mamadou-sakho-out-six-eight-weeks-for-liverpool-knee-injury|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=13 November 2015}}</ref>
Sakho was praised in Liverpool's victory over [[Borussia Dortmund]] in the Europa League quarter-finals. He coped against in-form striker [[Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang]] in the 1–1 away draw in the first leg,<ref name=innes>{{cite news|last1=Innes|first1=Richard|title=Twitter baffled by mystery of Mamadou Sakho's brilliance for Liverpool against Borussia Dortmund|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/row-zed/twitter-baffled-mystery-mamadou-sakhos-7712052|accessdate=3 May 2016|work=Daily Mirror|date=8 April 2016}}</ref> and then scored a header as they mounted a late comeback to win the second 4–3.
On 23 April 2016, it was announced that Sakho was being investigated by [[UEFA]] for violating an anti-doping rule, after he was tested on 17 March following a Europa League game against Manchester United.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mamadou Sakho: Liverpool defender investigated over 'anti-doping violation'|url=https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/liverpool-france-defender-mamadou-sakho-fails-dope-test-121415361--sow.html}}</ref> The club, along with Sakho, agreed that while UEFA were investigating, he would not be available for team selection.<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool FC club statement'|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/218080-liverpool-fc-club-statement}}</ref> Five days later, after testing positive for a fat-burner, UEFA punished him with a 30-day ban from all European football, which FIFA extended to cover all world football.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mamadou Sakho: Liverpool defender's 30-day ban extended worldwide|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36188347|accessdate=3 May 2016|publisher=UEFA|date=2 May 2016}}</ref> On 28 May 2016, the ban expired after the substance was found to not be in the banned substance list.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/28/mamadou-sakho-no-further-doping-ban|title=Mamadou Sakho handed Euro 2016 lifeline after Uefa doping ban expires|first=Guardian|last=sport|date=28 May 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> On 8 July 2016, the case was dismissed by UEFA.<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool: Mamadou Sakho has doping case dismissed by Uefa|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36752127|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 July 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17==== On 18 July 2016, it was announced that Sakho would wear the number 3 jersey for the [[2016–17 Liverpool F.C. season|2016–17 season]], switching from the number 17 he had worn since he joined Liverpool.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/228132-mamadou-sakho-to-wear-no-3-shirt-for-2016-17|title=Mamadou Sakho to wear No.3 shirt for 2016-17|date=18 July 2016|publisher=[[Liverpool F.C.]]|accessdate=18 July 2016}}</ref> During Liverpool's pre-season tour of the United States, Sakho was sent home by manager Jürgen Klopp for not respecting the rules that had been put in place for the squad. Klopp revealed that Sakho had been late for the team's flight as well as for a subsequent medical treatment session and a team meal time.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jul/28/jurgen-klopp-respect-mamadou-sakho-liverpool-us-tour|title=Jürgen Klopp sent Mamadou Sakho home for a 'lack of respect'|last=Dobson|first=Mark|date=28 July 2016|website=The Guardian|accessdate=28 July 2016}}</ref> As a result, Sakho was demoted from the senior squad and thus only played competitive football with the [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|reserves]] in the [[Professional Development League]] that season.
====Loan to Crystal Palace==== On 31 January 2017, Sakho signed with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on loan until the end of the season. Sakho made his debut appearance in a 1–0 victory over [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on 25 February, and was praised by manager [[Sam Allardyce]] for his role in Crystal Palace's victory.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com.au/news/allardyce-hails-van-aanholt-and-sakho-452654|title=ALLARDYCE HAILS VAN AANHOLT AND SAKHO|date=26 February 2017|work=FourFourTwo}}</ref> After Palace kept clean sheets in victories against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] and [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], Sakho was named a nominee for the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] award for March<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/354749|title=EA SPORTS Player of the Month: Vote now!|access-date=2017-04-09|language=en}}</ref> and was also awarded Crystal Palace's Player of the Month on March 31.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2017/march/sakho-scoops-mansion-player-of-the-month/|title=Crystal Palace's Mamadou Sakho has been named the Mansion Player of the Month for March|access-date=2017-04-09|language=en}}</ref> Sakho followed this up with well-received performances in Palace's 1–2 victory at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] over league leaders [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and a 3–0 home win over [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/how-crystal-palace-falling-love-12876734|title=How Crystal Palace are falling in love with Mamadou Sakho|date=11 April 2017|work=Liverpool Echo}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== On 31 August 2017, Sakho signed for Crystal Palace on a four-year contract, with a transfer fee of £24 million plus £2 million in add-ons being agreed with Liverpool.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2017/september/sakho-makes-permanent-crystal-palace-move/|title=Sakho Makes Permanent Crystal Palace Move|website=cpfc.co.uk|date=1 September 2017|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11706/11014400/crystal-palace-sign-mamadou-sakho-from-liverpool|title=Crystal Palace sign Mamadou Sakho from Liverpool|website=skysports.com|date=1 September 2017|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== Sakho has been active with [[France national youth football team|France at youth level]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rlfoot.fr/Joueurs/SAKHO_Mamadou.htm | title = La fiche de Mamadou SAKHO | accessdate =10 April 2010 | publisher=RL Foot | language = French }}</ref> As early as the age of 13, he began featuring with regional youth sides playing for [[Île-de-France (region)|Île-de-France]] alongside fellow youth internationals [[Yacine Brahimi]], [[Tripy Makonda]], [[Maxime Partouche]], and [[Sébastien Corchia]]. Sakho made his debut for the [[France national under-16 football team|under-16 team]] on 21 March 2006 in a [[Exhibition match|friendly match]] against [[Germany national youth football team|Germany]] in a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/292421.shtml | title = La France bat l'Allemagne (3–1) |date= 21 March 2006 | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=French Football Federation | language = French }}</ref> He scored his only goal for the team in their 1–0 victory over [[England national under-16 football team|England]] in the [[Montaigu Tournament]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/297994.shtml | title = La France bat l'Angleterre (1–0) |date= 13 April 2006 | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=French Football Federation | language = French }}</ref> France later won the competition defeating [[Italy national under-16 football team|Italy]] 2–1 in the final.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/298516.shtml | title = La France remporte la finale (2–1) |date= 17 April 2006 | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=French Football Federation | language = French }}</ref> With the [[France national under-17 football team|under-17 team]], Sakho made his debut in the team's opening match against Cyprus in an international youth tournament.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m17ans/318468.shtml | title = La France bat la Grèce (2–1) |date= 26 August 2006 | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=French Football Federation | language = French }}</ref> Midway through the season, Sakho was named [[Captain (association football)|captain]] by coach François Blaquart who noticed the player's leadership skills. Under Sakho's captaincy, the team reached the [[2007 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]] and, later, the [[2007 FIFA U-17 World Cup]] by virtue of their semi-final appearance in the UEFA-sanctioned tournament. At the U-17 World Cup, which was held in South Korea, Sakho captained the team to a quarter-final appearance where they lost to [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]] in a [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u17worldcup/korea2007/teams/team=1888290/profile.html | title = France squad preview | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=FIFA.com }}</ref>
Due his increased playing time with his parent club, Sakho only made four appearances with the [[France national under-18 football team|under-18 team]]. He made his debut for the team on 18 December 2007 in a friendly match against [[Portugal national under-18 football team|Portugal]] and later featured in two friendly matches against [[Germany national under-18 football team|Germany]], one of which was played at the [[GAZi-Stadion auf der Waldau]] in [[Stuttgart]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m18ans/actualite/414180.shtml | title = Courte défaite tricolore (1–0) |date=18 December 2007 | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=French Football Federation }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m18ans/actualite/428650.shtml | title = Succès allemand à Stuttgart (1–0) |date=11 March 2008 | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=French Football Federation }}</ref> Similarly with the [[France national under-19 football team|under-19 team]], Sakho's play with the team was limited not only due to his playing time with Paris Saint-Germain, but also due to his commitments with the [[France national under-21 football team|under-21 team]]. Despite making only four appearances with the team, he was selected to play in the [[2009 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship]]. Paris Saint-Germain, however, refused his participation in order to preserve the player's fitness with the player having already played in the [[2009 Toulon Tournament]], which was held the same month.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m19ans/selection/332273.shtml | title = Les joueurs retenus | accessdate =10 April 2010 | publisher=French Football Federation }}</ref>
Sakho made his France U21 debut on 19 August 2008 in a friendly match against [[Slovakia national under-21 football team|Slovakia]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/servfff/fiche_joueur/match.php?id_match=45 | title = France v. Slovakia Match Report |date=19 August 2008 | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=French Football Federation }}</ref> He played in the 2009 Toulon Tournament and captained the team on two occasions serving in place of the lead captain for the tournament, [[Étienne Capoue]], who came off the bench. On 8 September 2009, Sakho scored his first under-21 goal in a [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification]] match against [[Ukraine national under-21 football team|Ukraine]]. The match ended in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/matches/season=2011/round=2000006/match=2000191/index.html | title = Chesnakov pegs back France |date=8 September 2009 | accessdate =22 June 2010 | publisher=UEFA }}</ref> A month later, he was installed as the first-choice captain of the team following the selection of former captain [[Moussa Sissoko]] to the [[France national football team|senior team]].
===Senior=== [[File:Sakho.JPG|thumb|Sakho playing for France in 2013.]] On 5 August 2010, Sakho was called up to the [[France national football team|France senior team]] for the first time by new manager [[Laurent Blanc]] for the team's [[Exhibition match|friendly match]] against [[Norway national football team|Norway]] on 11 August 2010. He didn't make his international debut in the match, but was subsequently called up by Blanc for national team matches in September and October 2010. On 17 November 2010, Sakho made his senior international debut against [[England national football team|England]] in a 2–1 win at [[Wembley Stadium]], appearing as a substitute at the start of the second half for [[Philippe Mexès]].
On 19 November 2013, in the second leg of their [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Second Round|2014 World Cup qualifying play-off]] against [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]], Sakho scored his first and second international goals, giving ''Les Bleus'' a 3–2 aggregate win to qualify for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/worldcup2014/article-2510109/France-3-Ukraine-0-agg-3-2-match-report-Mamadou-Sakho-Karim-Benzema-Oleg-Gusev-goal-Les-Bleus-World-Cup.html|title= Sakho and Benzema ensure rampant Les Bleus complete mission impossible|date=19 November 2013|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref>
On 13 May 2014, Sakho was named in [[Didier Deschamps]]' squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=World Cup 2014: Samir Nasri and Gael Clichy not in France squad|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27401306|accessdate=14 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=13 May 2014}}</ref> He made his [[FIFA World Cup]] debut in the team's opening match, keeping a clean sheet in partnership with [[Raphaël Varane]] in a 3–0 defeat of [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285092|title=France 3–0 Honduras|date=15 June 2014|accessdate=16 June 2014|work=BBC}}</ref> In the second match, ''Les Bleus'' were again on course for a shutout with Sakho in defence, leading 3–0 against [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] when he was substituted with an injury in the 66th minute. The team eventually ran out 5–2 winners to qualify for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|knockout stage]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285207|title=Switzerland 2–5 France|date=20 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014|work=BBC}}</ref> Sakho returned to the side for the next match, helping France to another clean sheet in a 0–0 draw with [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285420|date=25 June 2014|title=Ecuador 0–0 France|accessdate=26 June 2014|website=bbc.com}}</ref>
On May 17, 2018, he was named on the preliminary list for the [[French national football team|French squad]] for the [[2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>https://www.skysports.com/amp/football/news/12025/11376691/alexandre-lacazette-and-anthony-martial-on-standby-for-france-world-cup-squad-and-dimitri-payet-out</ref> He ultimately did not make the final list.
==Style of play== Sakho is renowned for his energy on the pitch, and had [[cult status]] at Liverpool for his interaction with the supporters. In April 2016, Richard Innes of the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' described him as "a defensive maverick; a man who plays by his own rules", who practises an "often highly ''alternative'' approach" to defending.<ref name=innes/>
==Personal life== Sakho is married to Majda, with whom he has two daughters, Aida and Sienna, born in 2013 and 2015,<ref>{{cite news|title=Mamadou Sakho : Sa fille Aïda s'incruste en direct à la télévision|trans-title=Mamadou Sakho: His daughter Aïda is shown on live television|url=http://www.purepeople.com/article/mamadou-sakho-sa-fille-aida-s-incruste-en-direct-a-la-television_a171219/1|accessdate=3 May 2016|publisher=Pure People|date=21 January 2016|language=French}}</ref> and a son, Tidiane, born in 2018.<ref>{{cite news|title=Madja Sakho's Instangram|trans-title=Madja Sakho's Instagram|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Bfk8PQDjVQ0/|accessdate=24 Feb 2018|publisher=Instagram|date=24 February 2018|language=English}}</ref>
As part of Liverpool Football Club's work in the community, Sakho helped teach the [[French language]] to local children when he played for them.<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool's Mamadou Sakho teaches French to pupils|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32173950|accessdate=5 April 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=5 April 2015}}</ref>
Sakho is a [[Muslim]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/28/world-cup-muslim-fasting_n_5538226.html|title=Will These Men Fast While Competing In The World Cup?|last=Service|first=Janet Tappin Coelho Religion News|date=2014-06-28|website=HuffPost|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref>
==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|23 February 2019}}<ref>{{cite web|title=M. Sakho|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/mamadou-sakho/13118/|website=Soccerway|accessdate=1 February 2017}}</ref>

nationalteam3 = [[Wales national under-21 football team|Wales U21]] | nationalteam4 = [[Wales national football team|Wales]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalcaps2 = 7 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalcaps3 = 6 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalcaps4 = 81 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalteam-update = 06:24, 17 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Wayne Robert Hennessey''' (born 24 January 1987) is a Welsh professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and the [[Wales national football team|Wales national team]].
Hennessey's first professional games saw him set a new League Two record for consecutive clean sheets while on loan at [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]]. He played 166 times for [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] over eight seasons, including three years at Premier League level. After several injury setbacks, he moved to join Crystal Palace in 2014.
A full international since 2007, Hennessey has earned more than 80 caps for [[Wales national football team|Wales]].
==Early life and career== Hennessey is a cousin of [[Terry Hennessey]], who earned 39 caps for Wales from 1962 to 1972.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nardiello follows in father's footsteps |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-452221/Nardiello-follows-fathers-footsteps.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=2 May 2007 |accessdate=5 June 2011}}</ref> Born in [[Bangor, Gwynedd]] and raised in [[Beaumaris]], [[Anglesey]], Hennessey speaks [[Welsh language|Welsh]]<ref>{{citenews|title=Wales players told to learn words of national anthem|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/mar/22/gary-speed-wales-anthem|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=22 March 2011}}</ref> and was educated at [[Ysgol David Hughes]] but switched to [[Connah's Quay High School]] as it was easier to travel to [[Manchester]].<ref>{{citenews|title=Where it all began for Wales' Euro 2016 goalkeeper Wayne Hennessey|url=http://www.dailypost.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/began-wales-euro-2016-goalkeeper-11425292|work=[[North Wales Daily Post]]|date=5 June 2016|first=Blake|last=Welton}}</ref> Hennessey began as a trainee at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] but was released in 2003, whereupon he joined the youth academy at [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. After progressing through the ranks, he signed professional forms in April 2005.
After remaining in Wolves' reserve and youth teams during the 2005–06 season, Hennessey was sent on trial with [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in July 2006<ref>{{cite news |url=http://home.skysports.com/list.aspx?hlid=406314&plid=50647&clid=113&cpid=11 |title=Stockport Robins admit McAllister interest |accessdate=4 March 2007 |date=28 July 2006 |author=Alex Dunn |publisher=Sky Sports }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> with a view to a [[loan (sports)|loan]] move to gain [[first team]] experience but was recalled to Wolves after an injury to their first-choice goalkeeper [[Matt Murray (English footballer)|Matt Murray]]. He did go back to Bristol City in August 2006, however, on a one-month loan deal,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://home.skysports.com/list.aspx?hlid=409245&plid=50647&clid=113&cpid=11 |title=Robins to sign young keeper |accessdate=4 March 2007 |date=11 August 2006 |author=Mark Buckingham |publisher=Sky Sports }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> but he did not make an appearance and returned to his parent club early due to an arm injury.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/b/bristol_city/5271818.stm Johnson eager to bring in keeper]</ref>
==Club career== ===Stockport County=== To gain first-team football, Hennessey joined [[Football League Two|League Two]] side [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] in January 2007 on a one-month loan.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/stockport/6252807.stm |title=Hatters sign goalkeeper Hennessey |accessdate=4 March 2007 |date=11 January 2007 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On his senior debut against [[Boston United F.C.|Boston United]], he kept a [[clean sheet]] and after keeping another five clean sheets in successive matches, his loan spell was extended by an extra month.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/stockport/6357051.stm |title=Stockport extend Hennessey loan |accessdate=4 March 2007 |date=13 February 2007 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
He went on to set a [[The Football League|Football League]] record of nine successive clean sheets and wins.<ref name="FL record">{{cite news |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/sport/story/0,,2026082,00.html |title=Leeds deeper in gloom as Nicholls says he wants away |accessdate=4 March 2007 |date=4 March 2007 |author=Jason Tomas |newspaper=The Observer}}</ref> Stockport broke the 119-year-old record,<ref name="FL record"/> when they beat [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] 3–0 on 3 March 2007.<ref name="FL record"/> After this accomplishment, he was named the League Two Player of the Month for February 2007.<ref name="Hennessey's heroics secure award">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/stockport/6417015.stm |title=Hennessey's heroics secure award |accessdate=4 March 2007 |date=4 March 2007 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> His feat also means he now holds County's record for the longest period without conceding a goal, beating [[Harry Hardy]]'s 85-year-old record. His record now stands at 857 minutes, from the start of his competitive club debut, against Boston United on 13 January 2007, until [[Oliver Allen (footballer)|Oliver Allen]] of [[Barnet F.C|Barnet]] scored on 10 March 2007. He therefore did not concede in his first nine-and-a-half matches of competitive club football.
===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== Hennessey was recalled by Wolves in April 2007 after another injury to first-choice [[Matt Murray (English footballer)|Matt Murray]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sportbox.tv/football/news/story.php?id=244508 |title=County lose Hennessey |accessdate=16 April 2007 |date=10 April 2007 |publisher=Sportbox.tv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929061750/http://www.sportbox.tv/football/news/story.php?id=244508 |archivedate=29 September 2007 }}</ref> and found himself on the substitutes bench for several games. When Murray broke his shoulder on the eve of Wolves' [[Football League Championship|Championship]] play-off semi-final first leg against local rivals [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], Hennessey stepped in to make his Wolves debut.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wolverhampton_wanderers/6651217.stm |title=Murray out with broken shoulder |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 May 2007 |accessdate=16 December 2008}}</ref>
With Murray sidelined for the whole of the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08 season]] with yet another injury, Hennessey became firmly established at the club's number one, being an ever-present in the league and signing a new extended contract.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wolves.co.uk/page/News/0,,10307~1218608,00.html |title=New Deals For Young Duo |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C |date=18 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716192732/http://www.wolves.co.uk/page/News/0,,10307~1218608,00.html |archivedate=16 July 2011 }}</ref> At the end of the season he was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year#Championship|2007–08 PFA Championship Team of the Year]] as well as being named Wolves' Player of the Season.<ref name="Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C">{{cite news |url=http://www.wolves.co.uk/page/News/0,,10307~1303707,00.html |title=Hennessey Scoops Player of the Season Titles |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. |date=2 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716192816/http://www.wolves.co.uk/page/News/0,,10307~1303707,00.html |archivedate=16 July 2011 }}</ref> ''[[FourFourTwo]]'' magazine ranked him 22nd in their Top 50 Football League Players list.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fourfourtwo.com/blogs/footballleagueawards/archive/2008/03/02/fourfourtwo-50-best-football-league-players.aspx |title=FourFourTwo 50 Best Football League Players |work=[[FourFourTwo]] |date=2 March 2008 |accessdate=16 December 2008}}</ref>
The 2008–09 season saw a strong start for Hennessey and Wolves with eight victories out of the first nine league games. This fine run ended against promotion rivals [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] with a 0–3 loss begun by an own goal from Hennessey.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7639348.stm |title=Wolves 0–3 Reading |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 September 2008}}</ref> Soon after manager [[Mick McCarthy]] dropped him to the bench, citing mental fatigue as the reason.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wolverhampton_wanderers/7654568.stm |title=Hennessey needs a rest – McCarthy |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 October 2009 }}</ref> Reserve keeper [[Carl Ikeme]] deputised and impressed enough to leave Hennessey on the sidelines until an injury ruled him out for the majority of the season. Hennessey then regained and kept his place in goal for the remainder of the season which culminated with promotion to the [[Premier League]] as champions after a five-year absence.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8015237.stm |title=Wolves 1–0 Doncaster |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 May 2009 }}</ref>
Hennessey began the club's 2009–10 Premier League campaign as first choice goalkeeper, making his 100th senior appearance for the club in a 2–2 draw at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in October 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wayne Hennessey is one appearance away from Wolverhampton Wanderers landmark|url=http://www.birminghammail.net/birmingham-sport/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/wolves-fc-news/2009/10/30/wayne-hennessey-is-one-appearance-away-from-wolverhampton-wanderers-landmark-97319-25051332/|newspaper=Birmingham Mail|date=30 October 2009}}</ref> However, after conceding four goals in two successive games, he was replaced by the more experienced [[Marcus Hahnemann]] and remained on the bench for the rest of the season as the club finished 15th.
In July 2010, Hennessey extended his contract with Wolves to run until the summer of 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wolverhampton_wanderers/8788850.stm |title=Goalkeeper Wayne Hennessey signs new deal at Wolves |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 July 2010}}</ref> The following season began with Hahnemann retaining the number one spot until his own loss of form saw Hennessey return to the starting line-up in November 2010. He then held on to the spot for the remainder of the campaign as the club narrowly avoided relegation on the final day.
During the 2011–12 season, Hennessey was part of the Wolves defence that went a club record of 30 consecutive league games without a clean sheet. They finally ended this with a goalless draw at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in April 2012, but by then the team was rooted to the bottom of the table.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17643422 |title=Sunderland 0–0 Wolves|publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 April 2012 }}</ref> Despite the game halting this run, it brought bad news for Hennessey as he suffered a torn cruciate knee ligament during it that was due to keep him sidelined until Autumn 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17754937 |title=Wolves goalkeeper Wayne Hennessey out for six months |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 April 2012}}</ref> After completing several reserve games during his comeback he re-injured the knee during training in November 2012 which kept him out of action for the remainder of the 2012–13 season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/wayne-hennessey-141112-486254.aspx |title=Crushing blow for keeper |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C |date=14 November 2012 |access-date=14 November 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117002150/http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/wayne-hennessey-141112-486254.aspx |archive-date=17 November 2012 |dead-url=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20325266 |title=Wolves keeper Wayne Hennessey ruled out for the season|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 November 2012}}</ref>
He made his return to the Wolves goal during pre-season ahead of their 2013–14 campaign – with the club now in [[Football League One|League One]] having suffered two relegations since Hennessey's initial injury – but he was not selected to start the club's opening fixtures.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23340086|title=Wolves and Wales keeper Wayne Hennessey makes comeback|publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 July 2013}}</ref> On 12 August 2013 it was agreed for the goalkeeper to spend a month on loan at [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] as he recovers from his long-term injury problems.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/gloveman-to-glovers-120813-988291.aspx|title=Gloveman to Glovers?|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C|date=12 August 2013|access-date=12 August 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814142511/http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/gloveman-to-glovers-120813-988291.aspx|archive-date=14 August 2013|dead-url=yes}}</ref> However, before this deal was officially concluded Hennessey suffered a hamstring problem while on international duty with the Welsh national team and so the proposed loan was scrapped.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23715305|title=Wayne Hennessey: Wolves keeper's injury halts Yeovil loan|publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2013}}</ref> Although, on 21 August 2013, after an injury to Yeovil's replacement goalkeeper [[Sam Johnstone]] Hennessey officially joined Yeovil Town on an initial one-month loan which was eventually extended until 17 November 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23779668 |title=Wayne Hennessey: Wolves keeper cleared for Yeovil Town loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2013 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24674195 |title=Wayne Hennessey: Yeovil Town keep Wolves goalkeeper on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 October 2013 |accessdate=12 November 2013 }}</ref> He made his Yeovil debut in a 0–3 loss to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 24 August 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23744657 |title=Yeovil 0–3 Derby |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2013 |accessdate=12 November 2013 }}</ref> In his penultimate home match Hennessey received the man of the match award after the Glovers achieved their first ever home win at [[Football League Championship|Championship]] by defeating [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24590303 |title=Yeovil 3–1 Nottingham Forest |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 October 2013 |accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref>
After his loan spell at Yeovil ended, Hennessey returned to Wolves but did not displace [[Carl Ikeme]] in goal. When Ikeme suffered an injury in January 2014, Hennessey declined to play in the following fixture against [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]], launching speculation that he wanted a move away from the club.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12040/9100583/league-one-wolves-goalkeeper-wayne-hennessey-declines-to-play-against-gillingham |title=League One: Wolves goalkeeper Wayne Hennessey declines to play against Gillingham |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=4 January 2014}}</ref> Although he subsequently apologised for his refusal to play,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25645844|title=Wolves goalkeeper Wayne Hennessey apologises for no-show|publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 January 2014}}</ref> he did not play again for Wolves and negotiations were later entered into with [[Premier League]] team [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref name="news">{{cite news |first=John |last=Drayton |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2533160/Crystal-Palace-set-sign-goalkeeper-Wayne-Hennessey-Wolves.html |title=Palace set to capture Wolves outcast Hennessey as Pulis targets first signing |work=[[The Daily Mail]] |date=3 January 2014}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== On 31 January 2014, Hennessey joined [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on a three-and-a-half year deal for an undisclosed fee, with media speculation suggesting it to be an initial £1.6 million, with add-on clauses.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Hennessey Signs For Palace |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2014/january/hennessey-signs-for-palace/ |work=Crystal Palace FC |date=31 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25980091|title=Wolves' Wayne Hennessey joins Palace|publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2014}}</ref> Hennessey made his debut for the Eagles in the team's final match of the [[2013–14 Premier League|Premier League season]], a 2–2 draw with [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on 11 May 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/news/11205470.Eagles_held_at_Fulham_despite_Gayle_brace/|title=Fulham 2–2 Crystal Palace|date=12 May 2015|work=The Bolton News}}</ref>
Hennessey's first appearance of the [[2014–15 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2014–15 season]] came a 3–0 win at [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] in the [[2014–15 Football League Cup|Football League Cup]] second round.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28847260|title=Walsall 0–3 Crystal Palace|work=BBC|date=26 August 2014}}</ref> On 25 October, he made his first [[2014–15 Premier League|Premier League]] appearance of the season as a substitute for injured first choice goalkeeper [[Julián Speroni]] in a 2–2 draw at [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29671751|title=West Brom 2–2 Crystal Palace|date=25 October 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> He ended the season starting in Palace's final two league fixtures, wins against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], keeping his first Premier League clean sheet for the club in the latter match.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32670817|title=Liverpool 1–3 Crystal Palace|date=16 May 2015|work=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32770846 |title=Crystal Palace 1–0 Swansea|date=24 May 2015|work=BBC |accessdate=22 July 2016}}</ref>
After starting in Crystal Palace's [[2015–16 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2015–16]] [[2015–16 Football League Cup|Football League Cup]] second and third round matches, Hennessey was selected to start the [[2015–16 Premier League|Premier League]] fixture against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] in place of [[Alex McCarthy]]. He kept a clean sheet as Palace won 1–0 at [[Vicarage Road]] and has retained his place as the team's first choice goalkeeper, making five consecutive league appearances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/profile.career-history.html/wayne-hennessey|title=13 Wayne Hennessey|accessdate=3 November 2015|work=Premier League}}</ref>
==International career== Hennessey was capped for Wales at under-17, under-19 and under-21 level. He once scored for the under-19 side with a 40-yard free kick against [[Turkey national under-19 football team|Turkey]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/stockport_county/s/233/233326_hennessey_puts_county_strikers_in_shade.html |title=Hennessey puts County strikers in shade |accessdate=4 March 2007 |date=16 January 2007 |author=Stuart Brennan |newspaper=Manchester Evening News}}</ref>
He made his full international debut for [[Wales national football team|Wales]] in a 2–2 [[exhibition game|friendly]] draw against [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand]] on 26 May 2007 and has since established himself as his country's first-choice goalkeeper.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wayne Hennessey out to establish himself as Wales’ No 1 goalkeeper|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/footballnation/football-news/2009/10/09/wayne-hennessey-out-to-establish-himself-as-wales-no-1-goalkeeper-91466-24886688/|newspaper=South Wales Echo|date=9 October 2009}}</ref> Hennessey made his 50th appearance for Wales on 3 September 2015, keeping a clean sheet in a 1–0 away win over [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]] in [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gwilym|first1=Andrew|title=Cyprus vs Wales match report: Gareth Bale's bullet header has Welsh on brink of Euro 2016|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/cyprus-vs-wales-match-report-gareth-bales-bullet-header-has-welsh-on-brink-of-euro-2016-10485586.html|accessdate=4 September 2015|work=The Independent|date=3 September 2015}}</ref>
Hennessey played in all ten of Wales' qualifying matches for [[UEFA Euro 2016]], conceding just four times, as they reached their first major international tournament since the [[1958 FIFA World Cup]]. He was named in Wales' 23-man squad for the tournament as first choice goalkeeper but was forced to miss the opening game of the tournament, a 2–1 victory over [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]], after suffering a [[back spasm]] prior to the match, being replaced by [[Danny Ward (Welsh footballer)|Danny Ward]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36507888 |title=Euro 2016: Hennessey ruled out of Wales opener with back spasm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 June 2016 |accessdate=12 June 2016}}</ref>

==Honours== '''Wolverhampton Wanderers''' *[[Football League Championship]]: [[2008–09 Football League Championship|2008–09]]<ref>{{cite book |editor1-first=Glenda |editor1-last=Rollin |editor2-first=Jack |editor2-last=Rollin |title=Sky Sports Football Yearbook 2009–2010 |year=2009 |publisher=Headline Publishing Group |location=London |isbn=978-0-7553-1948-0 |pages=44, 416–417}}</ref>
'''Individual''' *[[PFA Team of the Year]]: [[PFA Team of the Year (2000s)#Championship 4|2007–08 Championship]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7370319.stm |title=Ronaldo named player of the year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 April 2008 |accessdate=14 December 2018}}</ref> *[[Football League Two Player of the Month]]: February 2007<ref name="Hennessey's heroics secure award"/> *[[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] Player of the Year: 2007–08<ref name="Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C"/>
==Personal life== In January 2019, an investigation was launched by the [[The Football Association|FA]] after Hennessey was pictured making what appeared to be a [[Nazi salute]] in a group photo posted on [[Instagram]] by teammate [[Max Meyer (footballer)|Max Meyer]]. Hennessey denied making the salute, claiming that "any kind of resemblance to that kind of gesture is absolutely coincidental".<ref>{{cite news |title=Wayne Hennessey: Football Association looking into alleged Nazi salute |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46796546 |accessdate=11 January 2019 |work=BBC Sport |date=8 January 2019}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jordan Ayew | image = 20150331 Mali vs Ghana 023.jpg | image_size = | caption = Jordan Ayew playing for Ghana in 2015 | fullname = Jordan Pierre Ayew{{cite web |title=List of Players |url=http://www.cafonline.com/userfiles/file/CAN2012/Group%20D%20teams.pdf |publisher=Confederation of African Football |format=PDF |page=4 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109004153/http://www.cafonline.com/userfiles/file/CAN2012/Group%20D%20teams.pdf |archivedate=9 November 2013 |deadurl=yes}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1991|9|11|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Marseille]], France | height = 1.82 m{{cite web |url=https://www.om.net/equipes/effectifs/joueurs/15172/ayew-jordan |title=Fiche joueur Jordan Ayew |publisher=Olympique de Marseille |accessdate=23 October 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150815024530/https://www.om.net/equipes/effectifs/joueurs/15172/ayew-jordan |archivedate=15 August 2015 |deadurl=no}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]]
(on loan from [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]]) | clubnumber = 14 | youthyears1 = 2000–2006 | youthclubs1 = [[AS Lyon Duchère|Lyon Duchère]] | youthyears2 = 2006–2009 | youthclubs2 = [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] | years1 = 2009–2014 | clubs1 = [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] | caps1 = 111 | goals1 = 14 | years2 = 2014 | clubs2 = → [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]] (loan) | caps2 = 17 | goals2 = 5 | years3 = 2014–2015 | clubs3 = [[FC Lorient|Lorient]] | caps3 = 31 | goals3 = 12 | years4 = 2015–2017 | clubs4 = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] | caps4 = 51 | goals4 = 9 | years5 = 2017– | clubs5 = [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] | caps5 = 50 | goals5 = 8 | years6 = 2018– | clubs6 = → [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (loan) | caps6 = 18 | goals6 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2010 | nationalteam1 = [[Ghana national under-20 football team|Ghana U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalyears2 = 2010– | nationalteam2 = [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] | nationalcaps2 = 51 | nationalgoals2 = 14 | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport|[[Association football|Football]]}} {{medalTeam|[[Olympique de Marseille]]}} {{medalW|[[Coupe de la Ligue]]|[[2010 Coupe de la Ligue Final|2010]]}} {{medalW|[[Ligue 1]]|[[2009–10 Ligue 1|2010]]}} {{medalW|[[Trophée des Champions]]|[[2010 Trophée des Champions|2010]]}} {{medalW|[[Coupe de la Ligue]]|[[2011 Coupe de la Ligue Final|2011]]}} {{medalW|[[Trophée des Champions]]|[[2011 Trophée des Champions|2011]]}} {{medalW|[[Coupe de la Ligue]]|[[2012 Coupe de la Ligue Final|2012]]}} | club-update = 20:19, 23 February 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 18 November 2018 }} '''Jordan Pierre Ayew''' (born 11 September 1991) is a Ghanaian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on loan from [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] and the [[Ghana national football team|Ghana national team]]. He is the son of former Ghana captain [[Abedi Pele]] and brother of [[André Ayew]], who plays for [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]]. ==Club career== ===Marseille=== [[File:Valais Cup 2013 - OM-FC Porto 13-07-2013 - Maicon et Jordan Ayew.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Ayew playing for [[Olympique de Marseille]] in 2013]] Ayew joined [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] as a trainee in 2006. He signed a three-year professional [[Association football contracts|contract]] with Marseille in 2009. Jordan Ayew made his debut for the senior team on 16 December 2009 in a [[Ligue 1|league]] match, scoring the equaliser against [[FC Lorient|Lorient]]. [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] went on to win the match 2–1.{{LFP|id=ayew-jordan}} Ayew scored his second goal against [[OGC Nice|Nice]] at the [[Stade Vélodrome]] on 27 April 2011 in a match which saw his elder brother [[André Ayew]] score a [[Hat-trick#Football .28Association football.29|hat-trick]]. On 1 November 2011, Jordan and André both started a [[UEFA Champions League]] match for the first time against Premier League outfit [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. On 6 January 2014, he joined Ligue 1 rivals [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]] on a loan deal until the end of the [[2013-14 Ligue 1|2013–14 season]].{{cite web|title=Jordan Ayew Officiellement Sochalien|url=http://www.fcsochaux.fr/fr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5939 |publisher=FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|accessdate=6 January 2014|date=6 January 2014}} ===Lorient=== On 28 July 2014, Ayew signed a four-year contract with [[FC Lorient|Lorient]].{{cite web|title=Jordan Ayew FC Lorient decision|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28530377 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 July 2014|date=29 July 2014}} Ayew explained the style and quality of play that Lorient proposed was the reason behind the decision. ===Aston Villa=== On 27 July 2015, Ayew joined [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on a five-year deal for an undisclosed fee, reported to be in the region of £8 million.{{cite web|title=Breaking news: Villa sign Ayew |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~4891745,00.html |publisher=Aston Villa |accessdate=27 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118025652/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10265~4891745%2C00.html |archivedate=18 November 2015 }}{{cite web|title=Aston Villa bid for Lorient's Jordan Ayew accepted, according to Sky sources|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9922994/aston-villa-bid-for-lorients-jordan-ayew-accepted-according-to-sky-sources|publisher=SkySports|accessdate=27 July 2015|date=24 July 2015}} He scored his first goal for the club on 24 October 2015 against his elder brother's club, Swansea City, in the 62nd minute.{{cite web|title=Aston Villa 1–2 Swansea City|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34558441|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=10 November 2015}} Aston Villa were relegated at the end of the 2015–16 season, winning only 17 points, but Ayew did end the season as their top scorer, albeit with just seven goals. ===Swansea City=== On 31 January 2017, Jordan Ayew joined Swansea City in exchange for Welsh International defender [[Neil Taylor (footballer)|Neil Taylor]], plus a fee from Swansea that can rise to £5 million if undisclosed future conditions are met.{{cite news| title=Jordan Ayew: Swansea sign Aston Villa forward in Neil Taylor swap deal| url= https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38800257|work=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2017|accessdate=4 February 2017}} Jordan's elder brother was a Swansea City player during the 2015–16 season and later joined him in the winter transfer window of 2018.{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42767978 | title = Andre Ayew: Swansea City re-sign Ghana forward from West Ham | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 31 January 2018 | accessdate = 2 February 2018 }} ===Crystal Palace (loan)=== On transfer deadline day, Ayew joined Crystal Palace on loan for the [[2018–19 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2018–19 season]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2018/august/jordan-ayew-joins-crystal-palace/|title=Jordan Ayew Joins Crystal Palace|publisher = Crystal Palace F.C.|date=9 August 2018|accessdate=9 August 2018}} ==International career== Ayew made his first senior [[Cap (sport)|appearance]] for [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] on 5 September 2010, in a 3–0 [[2012 & 2013 Africa Cup of Nations qualification|2012 AFCON Qualification]] match win against Swaziland, at the [[Somhlolo National Stadium]] in [[Lobamba]], Swaziland.{{cite web|title=Ghana beats Swaziland 3–0 in 2012 qualifier|url=http://www.ghanafa.org/blackstars/201009/5034.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908090524/http://www.ghanafa.org/blackstars/201009/5034.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 September 2010|publisher=[[Ghana Football Association]]|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|title=Olympique de Marseille's Jordan Ayew Yearns For More With Ghana|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/89/africa/2010/09/07/2105589/olympique-de-marseilles-jordan-ayew-yearns-for-more-with |author=K.N.S Mensah|publisher=Goal.com|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=7 September 2010}} On 1 June 2012, Ayew scored his first and second international [[Goal (sport)|goals]] in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)#Group D|2014 World Cup qualification]] match win against Lesotho, at the [[Kumasi Sports Stadium]] in [[Kumasi]], Ghana.{{cite web|title=Ghana 7–0 Lesotho (2014 FIFA World Cup Qualifiers)|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/africa/matches/round=258334/match=300176007/index.html|publisher=[[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] (FIFA)|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=1 June 2012}} In December 2011, Ayew was named to the Ghana national team provisional 25-man squad for the [[2012 Africa Cup of Nations]],{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1658/ghana/2011/12/15/2804053/ghana-announce-25-man-squad-for-2012-africa-cup-of-nations|title=Ghana announce 25-man squad for 2012 Africa Cup of Nations|last=Mensah|first=Kent|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=15 December 2011|publisher=Goal.com}} and in January 2012 he was selected for the tournament's 23-man squad.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtnfootball.com/africa/african-tournaments/african-cup-of-nations/2012-player-profiles/ghana/jordan-ayew.html|title=Jordan Ayew – 2012 Africa Cup of Nations profile|accessdate=7 June 2012|work=mtnfootball.com|publisher=[[MTN Group]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007123731/http://www.mtnfootball.com/africa/african-tournaments/african-cup-of-nations/2012-player-profiles/ghana/jordan-ayew.html|archivedate=7 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} In June 2014, he was included in the Ghanaian squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]]. In Ghana's last warm-up match before the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] in Brazil on 9 June 2014, Ayew came on as a first-half substitute for the injured [[Majeed Waris]] and ended up scoring a hat-trick in a 4–0 victory over [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/fifa-world-cup/story/1863563/ghana-4-0-south-korea-ayew-hat-trick |title=Ghana wins final World Cup warmup |publisher=ESPNFC |date=9 June 2014 |accessdate=9 June 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gh/news/4389/ghana/2014/06/10/4871892/ghana-4-0-south-korea-j-ayews-hat-trick-inspires-confidence?ICID=HP_BN_1|title=Ghana 4–0 South Korea: J. Ayew's hat-trick inspires confidence ahead of World Cup|last=Mensah|first=Kent|accessdate=9 June 2014|date=10 June 2014|publisher=Goal.com}} Jordan Ayew was part of the 2015 Africa Cup of Nations team in [[Equatorial Guinea]] that took a silver medal as result of losing out to Ivory Coast on a penalty shoot out whom they clinch the [[African Cup]], which occurred on 8 February 2015. ==Personal life== Ayew is the son of Maha Ayew and [[Abedi Pele]]. His father, uncles [[Kwame Ayew|Kwame]] and Sola, and brothers [[André Ayew|André]], [[Ibrahim Ayew|Ibrahim]] and Imani are all current or former professional footballers. Ayew is a practising [[Muslim]].{{cite news|title=Picture: Jordan & Andre Ayew pictured in Muslim prayers|url=http://ghanasoccernet.com/picture-jordan-andre-ayew-pictured-in-muslim-prayers/|publisher=ghanasoccernet.com|date=21 December 2013|accessdate=4 April 2014}} ==Career statistics==
