{{EngvarB|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jeffrey Schlupp | image = 20150331 Mali vs Ghana 247.jpg | image_size = | caption = Schlupp playing for [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] in 2015 | fullname = Jeffrey Schlupp<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|12|23|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Hamburg]], Germany | height = 1.78 m<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/8980/Jeffrey-Schlupp/overview |title=Jeffrey Schlupp: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Full back (association football)|Full back]] / [[Winger (association football)|Winger]] | currentclub = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | clubnumber = 15 | youthclubs1 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | youthyears1 = 2005–2010 | clubs1 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | clubs2 = → [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] (loan) | clubs3 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | years1 = 2010–2017 | years2 = 2011 | years3 = 2017– | caps1 = 122 | caps2 = 9 | caps3 = 65 | goals1 = 10 | goals2 = 6 | goals3 = 4 | nationalteam1 = [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] | nationalyears1 = 2011– | nationalcaps1 = 15 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | club-update = 18:52, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 17:33, 3 April 2017 (UTC) }} '''Jeffrey Schlupp''' ({{IPA-de|ˈdʒɛ.fʀiː ˈʃlʊp}}; born 23 December 1992) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Premier League]] club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and the [[Ghana national football team|Ghana national team]] as a [[Full back (association football)|left back]] or winger. He started his career as a [[Forward (association football)|striker]].
Schlupp is known for his extreme pace and athleticism, which allows him to be a versatile option and able to play anywhere on the left wing. Former teammate [[Andrej Kramarić]] once said of Schlupp, "I've never played with a more powerful player than Jeffrey Schlupp, such power and speed like I've never seen before."<ref name=Pulse>{{cite web|title=Leicester teammate lauds 'powerful' Ghanaian player|url=http://pulse.com.gh/sports/jeffrey-schlupp-leicester-teammate-lauds-powerful-ghanaian-player-id4998343.html|work=Pulse|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref>
Schlupp was part of the Leicester team that shocked the footballing world, by winning the [[2015–16 Premier League]] as rank outsiders with the odds of 5000–1.
== Early life == Jeff Schlupp was born to Ghanaian parents in [[Hamburg]], Germany, on 23 December 1992, and raised mostly in England after his family moved there when he was young.<ref name="LCFC – Jeff Schlupp"/> He attended [[Oakgrove School]] in [[Milton Keynes]] along with [[Salford City F.C]] goalkeeper [[Max Crocombe]].<ref name=oakgrove>{{cite web|title=Oakgrove Alumni Football Success|url=https://www.oakgrove.school/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/issue06.pdf|work=Oakgrove School|accessdate=29 March 2013}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name=oakgrove2>{{cite web|title=Oakgrove School March 2008 Newsletter|url=http://www.oakgrove.milton-keynes.sch.uk/documents/newsletters/2008/March/March2008.pdf|work=Oakgrove School|accessdate=29 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115065624/http://www.oakgrove.milton-keynes.sch.uk/documents/newsletters/2008/March/March2008.pdf|archivedate=15 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Club career ==
=== Leicester City === A product of the [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] [[Youth system|youth academy]], Schlupp was given a [[squad number]], 31, for the first time for the [[2010–11 Leicester City F.C. season|2010–11]] season along with fellow academy players [[Tom Parkes]] and Jorrin John by then manager [[Paulo Sousa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~2104744,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100731085703/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~2104744%2C00.html |archivedate=31 July 2010 |title=City Finalise Squad Numbers |work=Leicester City F.C |date=28 July 2010 |accessdate=11 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Schlupp signed a new contract keeping him at the club until 2013 on 14 March 2011.<ref name="bring-in">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/brentford/9424865.stm|title=Brentford bring in Leicester City's Jeffrey Schlupp|work=BBC Sport|date=14 March 2011|accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> Schlupp was named amongst the Leicester City substitutes for the first time by, then manager, [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] in the 3–2 home defeat to Norwich City on 8 March 2011.
==== Loan to Brentford ==== Schlupp joined [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] on a one-month [[loan (sports)|loan]] on 14 March 2011, declining a call up to the [[Germany national youth football team|Germany Under-19]] squad in order to complete the move.<ref name="bring-in"/> He made his senior debut in a 1–0 defeat to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] coming on as a substitute on 77 minutes on 15 March 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9422282.stm|title=Brentford 0 – 1 Huddersfield|work=BBC Sport|date=15 March 2011|accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref> On his first full senior appearance in his career he scored two goals winning the match against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] 2–1 on 25 March 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9429110.stm|title=Brentford 2 – 1 Carlisle|work=BBC Sport|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref> Schlupp earned a start in Brentford's next match and proved himself once more by scoring a header from a [[Lewis Grabban]] cross against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] in a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9436379.stm|title=Sheff Wed 1 – 3 Brentford|work=BBC Sport|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref>
On 3 April Schlupp started in the [[2011 Football League Trophy Final]], playing the full 90 minutes. Schlupp hit the post with an effort on goal. Carlisle United won the match 1–0.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9443308.stm|title=Brentford 0 – 1 Carlisle|work=BBC Sport|date=3 April 2011|accessdate=3 April 2011|first=Stephan|last=Shemilt}}</ref>
On 14 April the loan deal was extended to the end of the 2010–11 season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13087409.stm|title=Brentford to keep Leicester City's Jeffrey Schlupp|work=BBC Sport|date=14 April 2011|accessdate=14 April 2011}}</ref>
=== Return to Leicester City ===
==== 2011–12 season ==== [[File:Schlupp 2.jpg|thumb|200px|Schlupp playing for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in 2011]] On returning to Leicester, Schlupp travelled with the squad on their tour to Sweden often playing in friendlies as a left-back. He was given the squad number 27 for the [[2011–12 Leicester City F.C. season|2011–12 season]].<ref name="LCFC – Jeff Schlupp">{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~2407882,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422033851/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~2407882%2C00.html |archivedate=22 April 2012 |title=2011/12 Squad Numbers Confirmed |work=Leicester City F.C |date=5 August 2011 |accessdate=10 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In his first competitive senior appearance for the club he scored a hat-trick against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] first round on 9 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10274~59922,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313103430/http://www.lcfc.com/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10274~59922%2C00.html |archivedate=13 March 2012 |title=Rotherham vs Leicester City |work=Leicester City F.C |date=9 August 2011 |accessdate=10 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/14475843.stm|title=Eriksson praises Leicester City's Jeffrey Schlupp|work=BBC Sport|date=10 August 2011|accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref> He made his league debut in a 2–0 defeat to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 13 August,<ref>{{cite news|title=Leicester 0 – 2 Reading|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/14429624.stm|work=BBC Sport|date=13 August 2011|accessdate=14 August 2011}}</ref> and scored his first league goal in a 4–0 win over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 1 October.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leicester 4 – 0 Derby|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/15045690.stm|work=BBC Sport|date=1 October 2011|accessdate=2 October 2011}}</ref> Schlupp scored his second league goal, and Leicester City's 4,000th home league goal, against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in the 80th minute of 13 March 2012 [[Football League Championship|Championship]] clash. Schlupp ended his first season in the Leicester first team, scoring six times in 26 games in all competitions.
==== 2012–13 season ==== Schlupp spent a week in January 2013 training with [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11712/8406224/Manchester-United-have-taken-Leicester-City-s-Jefferey-Schlupp-on-trial | title=Manchester United have taken Leicester City's Jefferey Schlupp on trial | work=Sky Sports}}</ref> This trial was extended into a second and third week into the beginning of February.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/21368222|title=Jeffrey Schlupp: Nigel Pearson coy about Man Utd 'move'|work=BBC Sport|date=7 February 2013|accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref> During his time at Manchester United he played two under-21 games, a game against Liverpool and then a game against West Ham at Upton Park.
Upon Schlupp's return to Leicester he found his way into the Leicester team both at left back and in attack, scoring three goals towards the latter part of the [[2012–13 Football League Championship|2012–13]] season. Schlupp scored key goals in back to back home games against Birmingham City and [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].
==== 2013–14 season ==== Schlupp opened his goalscoring account for the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|2013–14]] season, rounding off a 3–1 away win to against Millwall on New Year's Day 2014 with smart finish through the goalkeeper's legs on his weaker foot. Following regular left-back [[Paul Konchesky]] receiving a three-match suspension for a red card against East Midlands rivals [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]], Schlupp found greater opportunities at the back of the Leicester side, putting in highly rated performances against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] and [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]].
==== 2014–15 season ==== On 16 August 2014, Schlupp made his [[Premier League]] debut as a second-half substitute against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on the opening weekend of the season. On 4 October, Schlupp scored his first Premier League goal, in the 2–2 draw with [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]. Schlupp scored his second goal of the season on 29 November, in the 2–3 defeat against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] before adding his third in the 2–2 draw against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 1 January 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/11/29/england/premier-league/queens-park-rangers-fc/leicester-city-fc/1703741/|title=QUEENS PARK RANGERS VS. LEICESTER CITY 3 – 2 |work=Soccerway|date=29 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/01/01/england/premier-league/liverpool-fc/leicester-city-fc/1703879/|title=LIVERPOOL VS. LEICESTER CITY 2 – 2 |work=Soccerway|date=1 January 2015}}</ref> On 18 May 2015, Schlupp's fine first season in the Premier League was met with reward as he was named Leicester City's Young Player of the Year, as voted by the fans, as well as winning the Players' Player of the Year award.<ref>{{cite news|title=Esteban Cambiasso Named Leicester City Player of the Year|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/esteban-cambiasso-named-leicester-city-player-of-the-year-2461984.aspx|accessdate=18 May 2015|work=Leicester City|date=18 May 2015}}</ref>
==== 2015–16 season ====
Schlupp started as the left back during Leicester's flying start to the season, although he later moved into a midfield role as the season progressed. Schlupp scored his first goal of the season in the 2–1 away victory against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34366647|title=Norwich City 1 – Leicester City 2|work=BBC Sport|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> He was ruled out for six weeks in December with a hamstring injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11712/10102756/leicester-have-been-hit-by-jeff-schlupps-hamstring-injury|title=Leicester hit by Jeff Schlupp's hamstring injury|work=Sky Sports|date=17 December 2015|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> After returning from the injury Schlupp had a strong impact on Leicester City's season, and contributed hugely to Leicester's unlikely title triumph. As a result of his successful season Schlupp was named Leicester's Young Player of the Year for the second year running beating [[Demarai Gray]] and [[Ben Chilwell]] to the award.<ref name=Leicester>{{cite web|title=Riyad Mahrez Named Leicester City Player of the Season|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/riyad-mahrez-named-leicester-city-player-of-the-season-3107732.aspx|work=Leicester City|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref>
=== Crystal Palace ===
On 13 January 2017, after only four league appearances for Leicester City in 2016–17, he joined Premier League club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] for a reported £12 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/jeffrey-schlupp-leaves-leicester-for-crystal-palace-35366186.html|title=Jeffrey Schlupp leaves Leicester for Crystal Palace|website=The Irish Independent|date=13 January 2017|accessdate=17 January 2017}}</ref> His first appearance for the club ended in defeat by three goals to nil to London rivals [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38539427|title=West Ham United 3–0 Crystal Palace|date=14 January 2017|publisher=BBC|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref>
== International career == [[File:20150331 Mali vs Ghana 155.jpg|thumb|200px|Schlupp playing for [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] in 2015]]
=== Germany === Schlupp was called up to a [[Germany national youth football team#Germany national under-19 squad|Germany under-19]] training camp in early 2011, but did not earn a cap in [[Ralf Minge]]'s side.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fussballtalente.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=395:dfb-laedt-qenglaenderq-jeffrey-schlupp-ein&catid=35:nationalmannschaft&Itemid=18|title=DFB lädt "Engländer" Jeffrey Schlupp ein|work=fussballtalente.net|date=28 February 2011|language=German}}{{Dead link|date=March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ghanafa.org/gfa/201111/6189.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204231334/http://www.ghanafa.org/gfa/201111/6189.php|archivedate=2014-12-04|title=DFB confirm Schlupp's status|publisher=Ghana Football Association|date=9 November 2011|accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref>
=== Ghana === On 7 November 2011, Schlupp was called up to the [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] squad to face [[Sierra Leone national football team|Sierra Leone]] and [[Gabon national football team|Gabon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ghanafa.org/blackstars/201111/6177.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113162910/http://ghanafa.org/blackstars/201111/6177.php|archivedate=2014-11-13|title=Black Stars squad announced|work=Ghana Football Association|date=7 November 2011|accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref> Schlupp made his Ghana debut against Gabon on 15 November, coming on as a late substitute for [[Prince Tagoe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201111160569.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140406184717/http://allafrica.com/stories/201111160569.html|archivedate=2014-04-06|title=Ghana: Asamoah Scores Black Star's Winner|work=allAfrica|date=15 November 2011|accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref> In April 2014, it was reported that The Black Star's coaching team are believed to have watched Schlupp play with a view to taking him to the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] in Brazil following a string of impressive performances for Leicester. Schlupp played in a friendly against Netherlands on 31 May but wasn't named in [[2014 FIFA World Cup squads#Ghana|Ghana's final 23]]. Schlupp was recalled to the Ghana squad for the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations qualification|2015 Africa Cup of Nations]] qualifiers against [[Uganda national football team|Uganda]] and [[Togo national football team|Togo]] in September 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28874478?ocid|title=Ghana drop Kwarasey and Essien for Nations Cup qualifiers|work=BBC Sport|date=21 August 2014|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> Schlupp earned his fourth cap as a late substitute in Ghana's 3–1 win against [[Togo national football team|Togo]] in the Blackstars last African Cup of Nations qualifier on 19 November 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/match/ghana-vs-togo/1870181/live-commentary?ICID=MP_MS_3|title=Ghana 3–1 Togo LIVE|work=Goal.com|date=19 November 2014|accessdate=30 November 2014}}</ref> Schlupp returned to the Black Stars squad in March 2015, coming on as a second-half substitute in the 2–1 defeat to [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] on 28 March and playing the full 90 minutes in a 1–1 draw with [[Mali national football team|Mali]] on 31 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/03/31/world/friendlies/ghana/mali/2022102/|title=GHANA VS. MALI 1 – 1 |work=Soccerway|date=31 March 2015|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/03/28/world/friendlies/ghana/senegal/2022097/|title=GHANA VS. SENEGAL 1 – 2 |work=Soccerway|date=28 March 2015|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref>
Schlupp scored his first goal for Ghana in a 7–1 win over [[Mauritius national football team|Mauritius]] in an [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualification#Group H|African Cup of Nations qualifier]] on 14 June 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/ghana-vs-mauritius/2038193/report|title=Ghana 7–1 Mauritius: Gyan and Jordan Ayew score twice in Black Stars romp |work=Goal|date=14 June 2015|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
== Personal life ==
Schlupp became a father in January 2014 to a son, Arlo.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leicester City pair Gary Taylor-Fletcher and Jeff Schlupp were disappointed to be left out – Pearson|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Pair-disappointed-left-ndash-Pearson/story-20470835-detail/story.html|accessdate=18 January 2014|work=Leicester Mercury|date=21 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140124000135/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Pair-disappointed-left-ndash-Pearson/story-20470835-detail/story.html|archivedate=24 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

No live updates when a match is still ongoing.-->| nationalyears1 = 2007 | nationalteam1 = [[Belgium national under-17 football team|Belgium U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 18 | nationalgoals1 = 6 | nationalyears2 = 2007–2008 | nationalteam2 = [[Belgium national under-18 football team|Belgium U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 7 | nationalgoals2 = 3 | nationalyears3 = 2008–2009 | nationalteam3 = [[Belgium national under-19 football team|Belgium U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 10 | nationalgoals3 = 10 | nationalyears4 = 2009–2012 | nationalteam4 = [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 9 | nationalgoals4 = 4 | nationalyears5 = 2010– | nationalteam5 = [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] | nationalcaps5 = 34 | nationalgoals5 = 12 | pcupdate = 19:38, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 3 June 2018 }}
'''Christian Benteke Liolo''' (born 3 December 1990) is a Belgian professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for English club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]].
He began his career at [[Standard Liège]], playing a part in their [[2008–09 Belgian First Division]] triumph. Following a season at [[K.R.C. Genk|Genk]] he was signed for £7 million by Aston Villa. He scored 49 goals in 100 matches for Villa across all competitions, including 19 Premier League goals in his debut season and helping them to the [[2015 FA Cup Final]], before transferring to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in 2015 for £32.5 million. He spent a single season at Liverpool, scoring a total of ten goals, before being transferred to Crystal Palace at the start of the 2016–17 season.
Benteke has earned over 30 caps for Belgium since making his debut in 2010. He missed the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] through injury, but was part of their team that reached the quarter-finals of [[UEFA Euro 2016]].
==Early life== Benteke was born in [[Kinshasa]] in 1990. He and his family fled during the [[Mobutu Sese Seko|Mobutu]] regime and in 1993 emigrated to [[Liège]], Belgium.<ref>{{cite news|author=Sam Wallace|work=The Independent|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/christian-benteke-street-football-took-brilliant-belgians-to-top-8298505.html|title=Christian Benteke: Street football took brilliant Belgians to top|location=London|date=9 November 2012}}</ref>
==Club career==
===Standard Liège and Genk=== Benteke played youth football for JS Pierreuse and later [[Standard Liège]] before moving to [[K.R.C. Genk|Genk]]. He rejoined Standard in January 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://article.wn.com/view/WNATb23a8af74ba369c45b1b97f597636c02/ |title=Christian Benteke volgt Bolat |publisher=Article.wn.com }}</ref> and scored three goals in 12 matches as the Walloon club won the [[2008–09 Belgian First Division|2008–09]] [[List of Belgian football champions|Belgian championship]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dhnet.be/sports/football/division1/standard/standard-champion-51b7afd3e4b0de6db987c419|title=Standard champion !|date=24 May 2009|language=French|work=DH.be}}</ref> On 7 August 2009, he joined [[KV Kortrijk]] on loan for a season,<ref>{{cite web |author=Footgoal.Net |url=http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=42996 |title=Officiel : Benteke à Courtrai, Van Hout au Standard |publisher=Footgoal.net |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810074449/http://www.footgoal.net/suite.php?selection=42996 |archivedate=10 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> where he scored 14 goals in the [[2009–10 Belgian Pro League|Belgian Pro League]], including five goals in the [[2009–10 Belgian Pro League#Championship Playoff|championship play-offs]], as the club achieved its best ever finish.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/analysis-liverpool-fc-match-winner-9885143|title=Analysis: Liverpool FC match winner Benteke reaches 50 Premier League goals|date=19 August 2015|work=Liverpool Echo}}</ref>
He spent the following season on loan at [[KV Mechelen]] as part of the transfer of [[Aloys Nong]], who moved from Mechelen to Standard Liège. Benteke's spell at Mechelen was less successful, with seven goals from 25 appearances. He returned to Genk from Standard in August 2011 for an undisclosed fee,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sporza.be/cm/sporza/voetbal/Jupiler_Pro_League/1.1098745|title=Benteke verhuist van Standard naar Genk |date=29 August 2011|language=Dutch|work=Sporza}}</ref> and went on to score 16 goals and register nine assists in 20 starts during the [[2011–12 Belgian Pro League|2011–12 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whoscored.com/Players/68312/ |title=Christian Benteke | Age 21 |publisher=WhoScored.com }}</ref>
After beginning the [[2012–13 Belgian Pro League|2012–13]] season with three goals from five league matches, Benteke was subject of an offer of €6m from [[Premier League]] club [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in August 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/aug/29/aston-villa-genk-christian-benteke|title=Aston Villa ready to abandon bid for Genk's Christian Benteke|date=30 August 2012|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
===Aston Villa===
====2012–13 season==== On 31 August 2012, Benteke joined [[Premier League]] club [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on a four-year deal for a fee believed to be around £7 million.<ref>{{cite news|author=Stuart James |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/sep/01/aston-villa-sign-christian-benteke |title=Aston Villa sign £7m Christian Benteke but are forced to defend transfers |newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 September 2012 |location=London}}</ref> Benteke stated it was a dream come true in getting a move to the Premier League and thanked the players and manager at [[K.R.C. Genk]] for his move.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2196578/Christian-Benteke-signs-Aston-Villa.html |title=Christian Benteke signs for Aston Villa |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=31 August 2012 |location=London}}</ref>
On 15 September 2012, Benteke scored on his debut for Aston Villa in a 2–0 win against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], after coming on as a substitute for Austrian forward [[Andreas Weimann]]. The goal came when Swansea defender [[Ashley Williams (footballer)|Ashley Williams]] headed the ball into Benteke's path, which he then lifted over the keeper and tapped in on the volley. Villa manager [[Paul Lambert]] praised Benteke's performance on his debut calling him "unplayable".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19528067 |title=Aston Villa 2–0 Swansea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 September 2012}}</ref> He then scored Villa's only goal in a 1–1 home draw with [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20014232 |title=Aston Villa 1–1 Norwich |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 October 2012}}</ref> He added a further two goals to his tally during a 3–2 victory over [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] in the [[2012–13 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20053684 |title=Swindon 2–3 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 October 2012}}</ref> He scored the winner in a 1–0 Premier League victory for Villa against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] at [[Villa Park]] on 27 November to continue his impressive start in [[Football in England|English football]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20405324 |title=Aston Villa 1–0 Reading |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 November 2012 |accessdate= 16 December 2012}}</ref>
Benteke then scored Villa's fourth goal in a 4–1 League Cup win over Norwich City at [[Carrow Road]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20590506 |title=Norwich 1–4 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 December 2012|accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref> Benteke further added to his impressive start in Premier League football by scoring two goals in Villa's 3–1 win against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] on 15 December. In addition to the two goals, he also assisted Villa's second goal with a back-heel to Andreas Weimann. [[Paul Lambert]] said afterwards that 'Benteke has been unbelievable', after already stating midweek (post–[[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich]]) that 'you run out of things to say about the guy, how well he's performing and how young he is'.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20650106 |title=Liverpool 1–3 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 December 2012}}</ref> Around Christmas time, [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] manager [[André Villas-Boas]] was reportedly interested in signing Benteke, referring to him as the season's "surprise package".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/dec/25/tottenham-andre-villas-boas-christian-benteke|title=Tottenham's André Villas-Boas eyes summer move for Christian Benteke|last=Hytner|first=David|date=2012-12-25|work=The Guardian|access-date=2019-02-19|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
After not scoring for three games, Benteke scored Villa's first [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]] in almost a year in a 2–2 draw away to Swansea City in Villa's first game of 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20840916 |title=Swansea 2–2 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2013 |accessdate=3 January 2013}}</ref> He recorded his 10th goal of the season with a 28-yard strike against [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]] rivals [[West Bromwich Albion F.C|West Bromwich Albion]] in a 2–2 draw at [[The Hawthorns]]. The goal was nominated for January's goal of the month competition on [[Match of the Day]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20996732 |title=West Brom 2–2 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013}}</ref> He then netted Villa's first goal in their 2–1 [[2012-13 Football League Cup#Semi-finals|League Cup semi-final]] victory over [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]]. However, the victory was not enough as Bradford won 4–3 on aggregate to progress to the final.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21022502 |title=Aston Villa 2–1 Bradford (3–4) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 January 2013 }}</ref> Former [[England national football team|England]] striker [[Michael Owen]] called him one of the signings of the season and posted a [[Tweet (Twitter)|tweet]] the day after the semi-final saying: 'I'm seriously impressed with Benteke. What a player.'<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.twitter.com/themichaelowen/statuses/293820156210188288 |title=Tweet |publisher=Twitter |date=23 January 2013 }}</ref> Benteke continued his rich scoring form with a goal against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and a brace against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], in a game that Villa had led 3–1 at one point but eventually finished 3–3.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21137565 |title=Aston Villa 1–2 Newcastle |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 January 2013 |accessdate=11 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21209061 |title=Everton 3–3 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 February 2013}}</ref> He racked up his 15th goal in all competitions, as well as tallying six goals in five games, when he scored a penalty in a 2–1 victory against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 10 February 2013. This was Villa's first league victory in eight games, since Benteke inspired the win against Liverpool back in December.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21311649 |title=Aston Villa 2–1 West Ham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 February 2013}}</ref> Benteke scored a deflected goal in a 2–1 victory at [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], scoring the club's 1,000th goal in the [[Premier League]] in the process. The following week he went on to score a goal that sealed a 3–2 win over [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21639183 |title=Reading 1–2 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 March 2013 |accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21724358 |title=Aston Villa 3–2 QPR |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 March 2013 |accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref> He then scored the third goal to seal a 3–1 win against relegation rivals [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] at the [[Britannia Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21979453 |title=Stoke 1–3 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 April 2013 |accessdate=1 May 2013}}</ref> Benteke was nominated for the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] after his excellent debut season, eventually finishing as runner-up to eventual double award winner [[Gareth Bale]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22216746 |title=Carrick, Bale, Suarez, Van Persie, Hazard & Mata on PFA shortlist |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 April 2013 |accessdate=1 May 2013}}</ref> On 29 April, Benteke scored his first [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|hat-trick]] for Aston Villa in a 6–1 thrashing of [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]. These goals also saw him exceed [[Dwight Yorke]]'s record for most Premier League goals in a season (18) by an Aston Villa player and pass the 20 goal mark in all competitions, becoming the first player to do so for Villa since [[Juan Pablo Ángel]] in the [[2003-04 Aston Villa F.C. season|2003–04 season]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22244165 |title=Aston Villa 6–1 Sunderland |date=29 April 2013 |accessdate=1 May 2013}}</ref>
On 11 May, Benteke scored Villa's only goal in a 1–2 loss to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] but in the second half he was sent off after receiving his second yellow card for a high boot on [[John Terry]], meaning he would miss the last game of the season.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22409606|title=Aston Villa 1–2 Chelsea|date=11 May 2013|accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref>
====2013–14 season==== [[File:Christian Benteke, Aston Villa 2013 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Benteke playing for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in 2013]] Benteke's 23 goals in 2012–13 led to speculation about his future, and in early July he submitted a transfer request. Villa said he could leave only if their valuation were met, but a fortnight later he withdrew his transfer request, after talks with manager Paul Lambert, and signed a new four-year contract with the club.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23236667 |title=Christian Benteke: Aston Villa striker submits transfer request |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 July 2013 |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23383683 |title=Christian Benteke: Aston Villa striker signs new deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 July 2013 |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> On his second pre-season appearance, he scored a hat-trick against [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] in a 5–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~3328995,00.html |title=Crewe 1–5 Villa report: Benteke the hat-trick hero |publisher=Aston Villa F.C |date=26 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730050107/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~3328995,00.html |archivedate=30 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He finished pre-season with seven goals in five appearances, including two goals against [[Málaga CF|Málaga]] at [[Villa Park]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~3344140,00.html |title=Villa 3–2 Malaga report: Benteke double in final friendly win |publisher=Aston Villa Football Club |date=10 August 2013 |accessdate=18 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814021508/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~3344140,00.html |archivedate=14 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/332352/Christian-Benteke-on-song-to-repeat-goals-feat |title=Christian Benteke on song to repeat goals feat |work=Daily Star |date=14 August 2013 }}</ref>
On 17 August 2013, Benteke scored twice, once from a penalty and one headed goal via a rebound from a missed penalty, in Aston Villa's 3–1 away-win against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on the opening day of the [[2013–14 Premier League]] season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23644714 |title=Arsenal 1–3 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2013 }}</ref> Four days later, Benteke scored against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] in a 2–1 defeat.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/236915514 |title=Chelsea 2–1 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2013 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He scored his fourth goal in as many games, as Villa comfortably beat [[Football League One|League One]] side [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] 3–0 in the [[2013-14 Football League Cup#Second round|League Cup second round]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23776656 |title=Aston Villa 3–0 Rotherham |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=29 August 2013 }}</ref> He continued scoring, as he racked up his fifth goal in all competitions, against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in a 1–2 defeat at [[Villa Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23999651 |title=Aston Villa 1–2 Newcastle |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 September 2013 |accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref> However his brilliant early season form was abruptly ended, as he was injured in the next match against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]]. It was later confirmed that he would be out for up to six weeks with a hip flexor injury.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11677/8940234/premier-league-aston-villa-striker-christian-benteke-faces-six-weeks-out-with-hip-injury |title=Premier League: Aston Villa striker Christian Benteke faces six weeks out with hip injury |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref> However, he made his comeback earlier than expected, after coming on as a substitute against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] a month later in a 2–0 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24510366 |title=Aston Villa 0–2 Tottenham |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref>
After loss of form and niggling injuries prevented Benteke scoring for 12 games (his last goal being against Newcastle on 14 September), he eventually ended his drought against Arsenal in a 1–2 defeat on 13 January 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www1.skysports.com/news/12040/9096538/ |title=Premier League: Aston Villa's Christian Benteke backed to rediscover top form |publisher=Sky Sports |date=1 January 2014 |accessdate=14 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="Villa 1-2 Arsenal">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25617902 |title=Aston Villa 1–2 Arsenal |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=14 January 2014 }}</ref> He followed this up with goals in back-to-back games against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], in a 2–2 draw and 4–3 victory respectively.<ref name="Liverpool 2-2 Villa BBC">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25693308 |title=Liverpool 2–2 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 January 2014 }}</ref><ref name="Villa 4-3 West Brom">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25838290 |title=Aston Villa 4–3 West Bromwich Albion |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 January 2014 |accessdate=2 February 2014 }}</ref> Having not scored throughout February, the Belgian then scored a superb overhead volley as well as a header, in an eventual 4–1 home victory against Norwich City on 2 March.<ref name="Villa 4-1 Norwich">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26311656 |title=Aston Villa 4–1 Norwich City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 March 2014 |accessdate=1 April 2014 }}</ref>
On 3 April 2014, Benteke suffered a rupture of his [[achilles tendon]] while training and was ruled out for at least six months, missing the remainder of the season and the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/apr/03/christian-benteke-suffers-achilles-injury-aston-villa-belgium-world-cup|title=Christian Benteke ruled out of World Cup after rupturing achilles|date=3 April 2014|accessdate=4 April 2014|publisher=ESPN Soccernet}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== On 2 November 2014, Benteke was given a straight red card by referee [[Neil Swarbrick]] for pushing the face of [[Tottenham Hotspur]]'s [[Ryan Mason]] after Mason had stuck his face in Benteke's chest. Villa had been winning at the time, but went on to lose 2–1.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Whalley|first1=Mike|title=Aston Villa 1–2 Tottenham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29775975|accessdate=2 November 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 November 2014}}</ref> The incident led to both clubs being fined £20,000 by [[The FA]] for failing to keep their players under control.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aston Villa and Tottenham fined £20,000 each by FA|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29921851|accessdate=12 November 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 November 2014}}</ref>
He scored his second goal of the season against Manchester United in a 1–1 draw at Villa Park.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30459793 |title=Aston Villa 1–1 Manchester United |date=20 December 2014 |accessdate=8 April 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> It took him until early March to score his next goal, a 94th-minute penalty in a local derby against rivals [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31598202 |title=Aston Villa 2–1 West Bromwich Albion |date=3 March 2015 |accessdate=8 April 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 7 April, he scored his second [[List of Premier League hat-tricks|Premier League hat-trick]] in a 3–3 draw with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32126419 |title=Aston Villa 3–3 QPR |date=7 April 2015 |accessdate=7 April 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Twelve days later, he equalised as Villa came from behind to defeat Liverpool and reach the [[2015 FA Cup Final]], their first for fifteen years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aston Villa 2–1 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32273487|accessdate=19 April 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 April 2015}}</ref> On 2 May, he scored twice in a 3–2 win at home to Everton, taking him to a total of eleven goals in nine matches since the arrival of [[Tim Sherwood]] as manager.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32460322|title=Aston Villa 3–2 Everton|date=2 May 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Six days later, Benteke was announced as the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] for April.<ref>{{cite news |title=Barclays player of the month: Christian Benteke wins April award |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~4699825,00.html |publisher=Aston Villa F.C. |date=8 May 2015 |accessdate=8 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512000717/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~4699825,00.html |archivedate=12 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Benteke and Pearson win Barclays monthly awards |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2014-15/may/080515-benteke-and-pearson-claim-barclays-monthly-awards-for-april.html |publisher=Premier League |date=8 May 2015 |accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref> He played the full 90 minutes in the FA Cup Final as Villa lost 0–4 to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], being beaten to a header by [[Per Mertesacker]] for the third goal of the rout.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Arsenal 4–0 Aston Villa|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32856754|accessdate=30 May 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 May 2015}}</ref>
===Liverpool=== On 22 July 2015, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] completed the signing of Benteke on a "long-term contract"<!--This is Liverpool's own description of it, so it needs quotation marks, just as it is reported in the BBC article used as a source--> after meeting his release clause of £32.5 million, at the time making him their second [[List of Liverpool F.C. records and statistics#Record transfer fees paid|most expensive transfer]] ever.<ref>{{cite news|title=Christian Benteke: Liverpool sign £32.5m Aston Villa striker|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33627800|accessdate=22 July 2015|date=22 July 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He made his debut on 2 August in a pre-season friendly at [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]], putting Liverpool into the lead with a volley as they went on to win 2–1.<ref>{{cite news|title=Christian Benteke: Liverpool striker scores in Swindon friendly|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33754238|accessdate=3 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 August 2015}}</ref>
On 9 August, Benteke made his competitive debut by starting in a 0–1 win at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 0–1 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33750574|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=10 August 2015|date=9 August 2015}}</ref> Eight days later he scored his first league goal for Liverpool in a 1–0 home win over newly promoted [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Liverpool 1–0 Bournemouth|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33843979|accessdate=17 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 August 2015}}</ref> On 12 September, he scored an [[overhead kick]] in a 1–3 defeat to [[Liverpool F.C.–Manchester United F.C. rivalry|rivals]] [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Man Utd 1–3 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34160795 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 September 2015 |accessdate=13 September 2015}}</ref>
After missing several games through injury, Benteke returned to score in consecutive games as a substitute on 25 and 31 October: a 1–1 draw against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Match Report|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34564965|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 October 2015|date=25 October 2015}}</ref> and a 1–3 away win against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34623902|last=McNulty|first=Phil|title=Chelsea 1–3 Liverpool|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 October 2015|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref> On 26 December, he replaced compatriot [[Divock Origi]] in the first half of a home fixture against league leaders [[Leicester City]], and scored the only goal in a victory that curtailed the visitors' nine-game unbeaten run.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jurejko|first1=Jonathan|title=Liverpool 1–0 Leicester|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35140035|accessdate=26 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 December 2015}}</ref>
On 8 January 2016, Benteke was named as [[Captain (association football)|captain]] for Liverpool's [[2015–16 FA Cup|FA Cup]] third round tie with [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] at [[St James Park (Exeter)|St James Park]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/fa-league-cups/exeter-vs-liverpool-team-news-christian-benteke-captains-jurgen-klopps-youthful-liverpool-line-up-a6803166.html|title=Exeter vs Liverpool team news: Christian Benteke the captain as Jurgen Klopp makes 11 changes|date=9 January 2016|work=The Independent}}</ref>
On 11 May 2016, Benteke scored his tenth goal of his only season at Liverpool with a 92nd-minute equaliser in the team's final home game of 2015–16, a 1–1 draw with Chelsea.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/football/premier-league/live-coverage-of-liverpool-v-chelsea-sunderland-v-everton-norwich-v-watford/news-story/ead855105fd49409ddea00b7dd52a3f9|title=Liverpool v Chelsea: Christian Benteke cancels out Eden Hazard goal at Anfield in Premier League|date=12 May 2016|publisher=Fox Sports}}</ref> Benteke was often found on the bench because he wasn't fitting into [[Jürgen Klopp]]'s style of play. Because of this, he ended his stint at Liverpool after making 42 appearances and scoring 10 goals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/232467-christian-benteke-completes-move-to-palace|title=Christian Benteke completes move to Palace|access-date=2016-08-20}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== On 20 August 2016, [[Premier League]] side [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] completed the signing of Benteke on a four-year deal for a fee of £27m which could rise by a further £5m, bringing the total fee to £32m.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2016/august/benteke-signs-for-palace/|title=Crystal Palace have signed Belgium international striker Christian Benteke from Liverpool for an undisclosed fee on a four year contract|access-date=2016-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37028477|title=Christian Benteke: Crystal Palace sign striker from Liverpool for £27m|access-date=2016-08-20}}</ref> On 10 September 2016, Benteke scored his first goal for Palace in a 1–2 victory against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], in just his second league game.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/09/10/middlesbrough-1-crystal-palace-2-christian-benteke-and-wilfried/|title=Middlesbrough 1 Crystal Palace 2: Christian Benteke and Wilfried Zaha net to end Boro's unbeaten run|access-date=2016-09-10}}</ref> On 24 September 2016, Benteke headed home a goal against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in the 94th minute to cap Palace's comeback from 2–0 down to win 3–2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37394578|title=Sunderland 2-3 Crystal Palace|date=24 September 2016|publisher=BBC}}</ref> On 3 December 2016 (Benteke's birthday), he scored twice in a 3–0 win over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] that ended Palace's run of six consecutive defeats.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/crystal-palace-3-southampton-0-relief-for-alan-pardew-as-birthday-boy-christian-benteke-ends-losing-a3411641.html|title=Palace 3 Southampton 0: Birthday boy Benteke eases pressure on Pardew|publisher=}}</ref> Benteke marked his return to Anfield, the ground of his former club Liverpool, with two goals in a 2–1 win on 23 April 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39612237|title=Liverpool 1-2 Crystal Palace|date=2017-04-23|publisher=BBC Sport|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en-GB}}</ref> He finished his first season with Palace as their top-scorer, with 15 league goals and 17 in total. The next season was less successful, with Benteke not scoring until December,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/12/16/leicester-0-crystal-palace-3-christian-benteke-ends-league-goal/|title=Leicester 0 Crystal Palace 3: Christian Benteke ends league goal drought to lift Palace out of drop zone|last=Percy|first=John|date=2017-12-16|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2019-01-29|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> and finishing the season with just three league goals in 30 appearances.
==International career== [[File:Christian_Benteke.JPG|thumb|upright|Benteke with [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] in 2013]]
Benteke was a member of the [[Belgium national under-17 football team|Belgium U17]] team at the [[2007 FIFA U-17 World Cup squads|2007 FIFA U-17 World Cup]] in South Korea where he played three games and scored once.<ref>{{FIFA player|274008}}</ref>
On 19 May 2010, he made his senior debut for the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]] in a friendly match against [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]] in Brussels after his former coach at [[KV Kortrijk|Kortrijk]], [[Georges Leekens]], became national coach. On 15 August 2012, he scored his first goal in a 4–2 win against the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]]. Since then, he has become a regular starter for Belgium under [[Marc Wilmots]]. On 29 May 2013, he scored twice in a 4–2 friendly victory against the [[USMNT|United States]] in [[Cleveland, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Slane|first1=Mike|title=United States 2–4 Belgium: Sloppy defensive play leads to friendly defeat|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/match/united-states-vs-belgium/1460935/report|accessdate=8 April 2015|publisher=Goal.com|date=29 May 2013}}</ref>
He scored two goals in seven appearances during [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|qualifying]] for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/worldcup/season=2014/teams/player=1902165/index.html|title=Christian Benteke|accessdate=11 April 2014|publisher=UEFA}}</ref> but was ruled out of the tournament finals with a ruptured Achilles tendon.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/worldcup/news/newsid=2083755.html|title=Belgium's Benteke ruled out of World Cup|date=3 April 2014|accessdate=11 April 2014|publisher=UEFA}}</ref>
Benteke returned to Belgium's squad for the [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] campaign, scoring his first international goal for two years in a 5–0 defeat of [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]] on 28 March 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/qualifiers/season=2016/matches/live/day=5/session=2/match=2013931/index.html|title=Belgium 5–0 Cyprus|accessdate=3 April 2015|publisher=UEFA}}</ref> He was selected for [[UEFA Euro 2016|the final tournament]] in France, and made his tournament debut in the second group game on 18 June, replacing [[Romelu Lukaku]] for the last seven minutes of a 3–0 win over the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] in [[Bordeaux]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Saffer|first1=Paul|title=Belgium find best form to beat Ireland|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2016/matches/round=2000448/match=2017955/postmatch/report/|accessdate=4 July 2016|publisher=UEFA|date=18 June 2016}}</ref> He played three more minutes in place of the same player four days later in a victory over [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ladyman|first1=Ian|title=Sweden 0–1 Belgium: Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Co bow out of Euro 2016 as Radja Nainggolan scores screamer in Nice|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3655065/Sweden-0-1-Belgium-Zlatan-Ibrahimovic-bow-Euro-2016-Radja-Nainggolan-scores-screamer-Nice.html|accessdate=4 July 2016|work=Daily Mail|date=22 June 2016}}</ref> but took no further part as the Belgians reached the quarter-finals and lost to [[Wales national football team|Wales]]. On 10 October 2016, Benteke set a record for the fastest goal in a [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] match—either qualifying or the finals—when he scored after 8.1 seconds against [[Gibraltar national football team|Gibraltar]] in a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group H|2018 FIFA World Cup qualifying match]], breaking the 23-year-old record previously held by [[Davide Gualtieri]]. He scored twice more to complete his first hat-trick for Belgium.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/european-qualifiers/news/newsid=2412481.html|title=Record-breaking Benteke scores after 8.1 seconds|publisher=UEFA|access-date=10 October 2016}}</ref>
He was left out of the final Belgium 23-man squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] despite initially being named in the preliminary squad.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/amp/football/44353673</ref>
==International goals== :''As of match played 28 March 2017. ==Personal life== Benteke is a Christian. He points up to the sky after scoring goals to thank [[God in Christianity|God]], and also prays frequently.<ref>{{cite web|title=Christian Benteke: I thank God for my goalscoring gift|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/christian-benteke-thank-god-goalscoring-5700465}}</ref> He has a younger brother, [[Jonathan Benteke|Jonathan]], who is also a footballer.
==Media== Benteke's [[goal celebration]] features him beating his chest. The celebration appears in EA Sports’ video game ''[[FIFA 18]]''.<ref>{{cite news |title=How to do the 12 new FIFA 18 celebrations – plus more of our favourites |url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/how-do-12-new-fifa-18-celebrations-plus-more-our-favourites?page=0%2C2 |accessdate=17 October 2018 |work=FourFourTwo}}</ref>

'''James McFarlane McArthur''' (born 7 October 1987) is a Scottish [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|central midfielder]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].
McArthur started his career at [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] and was part of the team that won the [[2007–08 Scottish First Division]] title. He made over 190 appearances for Hamilton before joining [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in July 2010. McArthur helped Wigan win the [[FA Cup]] in [[2013 FA Cup Final|2013]]. He was transferred to Crystal Palace in the summer of 2014.
McArthur made 32 international appearances for the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]] between 2010 and 2017.
==Club career== ===Hamilton Academical=== Born in [[Glasgow]] and raised in the city's [[Barrowfield]] district, McArthur attended [[Whitehill Secondary School]] and supported [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] in his youth;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12380478.Family_feeling_is_the_secret_of_success_so_far_for_Hamilton/ |title=Family feeling is the secret of success so far for Hamilton |publisher=The Herald |date=26 February 2009 |accessdate=25 September 2017}}</ref> he played for Rangers South BC (alongside future international colleagues [[Robert Snodgrass]] and [[Graham Dorrans]]),<ref name=roots>{{cite web |url=https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/robert-snodgrass-grassroots-football-glasgow-7592004 |title=Robert Snodgrass: Grassroots football in Glasgow was tough... but it is brilliant |work=Daily Record|date=20 March 2016|accessdate=11 July 2018}}</ref> [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone pro youth]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/teams/scotland/james-mcarthur-i-ll-always-remember-don-hutchison-s-goal-1-4469383 |title=James McArthur: 'I'll always remember Don Hutchison's goal'|publisher=The Scotsman |date=8 June 2017|accessdate=25 September 2017}}</ref> Rangers SABC and [[Clyde F.C. Under-20s and Academy|Clyde]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youthfootballscotland.co.uk/news-a-media/my-youth-career/969-james-mcarthur|title=James McArthur|accessdate=2011-02-22|publisher=Youth Football Scotland}}</ref> before moving to [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] as a youth in 2003. He made his professional debut in January 2005 against [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]]. He established himself in the Hamilton team the following season and scored his first goal in April 2006 against St Johnstone.
Such was his progress that he was given the captaincy for Hamilton against [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] in February 2008 for a [[Scottish Cup]] tie<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.acciesfc.co.uk/home/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=477&Itemid=38|title=Aberdeen 1 Accies 0|publisher=Hamilton Academical F.C|date=2 February 2008|access-date=7 April 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207100148/http://www.acciesfc.co.uk/home/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=477&Itemid=38|archive-date=7 February 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and nominated for the First Division Player of the Year for the [[2007–08 Scottish First Division|2007–08]] season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/scot_div_1/7335161.stm|title= Dorrans and McDonald on shortlist|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 April 2008}}</ref> In May 2008 after helping his side to the [[Scottish First Division]], McArthur was awarded with a new three-year contract. By the time he departed from [[New Douglas Park]] aged 22, he had played in nearly 200 matches for ''Accies''.
===Wigan Athletic=== In the 2009–10 season, several English [[Football League Championship|Championship]] and [[Premier League]] clubs, including [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] and [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], showed an interest in McArthur. On 5 April 2010, McArthur went on a three-day visit to [[Premier League]] club [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] with a view to a permanent move in the summer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/h/hamilton_academical/8598986.stm|title= Hamilton Accies' James McArthur to visit Wigan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 April 2010}}</ref> He signed a four-year contract at the [[DW Stadium]] on 23 July for a fee of around £500,000.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hamilton_academical/8839771.stm|title= James McArthur completes move from Hamilton to Wigan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10429~2100292,00.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=23 July 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725010259/http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10429~2100292,00.html |archive-date=25 July 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The move reunited him with former Hamilton teammate [[James McCarthy (footballer)|James McCarthy]], who had made the same move at the beginning of the [[2009–10 Premier League|2009–10]] season. On 31 January 2012, McArthur scored his first goal for Wigan in a 3–1 loss to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], and followed it up two games later with a winning goal over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] at the [[Reebok Stadium]] in a game which finished 2–1 to Wigan. McArthur extended his contract with Wigan in May 2012, with the new deal due to run until 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18118717 |title=Wigan extend contract of Scotland midfielder James McArthur |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 May 2012 |accessdate=27 August 2014}}</ref> On 11 May 2013 McArthur won the [[FA Cup]], playing the whole game in a 1–0 upset win against [[Manchester City]].<ref name=facup13>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22409634 |title=Man City 0 - 1 Wigan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 May 2013 |accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> However, only three days later, Wigan were relegated from the Premier League following a 4–1 defeat against Arsenal.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22430454|title=Arsenal 4 - 1 Wigan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2013 |accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref>
Wigan rejected a first offer of £5 million from [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for McArthur in August 2014, but then accepted a proposed valuation of nearly £7 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28957513 |title=James McArthur: Leicester set to sign Wigan Athletic midfielder |work= |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 August 2014 |accessdate=27 August 2014}}</ref> A payment schedule was not agreed and the proposed transfer collapsed, with Leicester signing [[Esteban Cambiasso]] instead.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28983784 |title=James McArthur: Leicester move for Wigan midfielder collapses |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 August 2014 |accessdate=29 August 2014}}</ref> On the last day of the summer 2014 transfer window, Wigan accepted a £7 million offer from [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] for McArthur.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29013298 |title=Transfer deadline day: Crystal Palace to sign Wigan's McArthur |work= |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 September 2014 |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== On 1 September 2014, McArthur signed a three-year contract with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] after joining from Wigan Athletic for an undisclosed fee;<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2014/september/eagles-make-deadline-day-swoop-for-mcarthur/ |title=James McArthur: Eagles Make Deadline Day Swoop For McArthur |work=Crystal Palace Football Club |publisher=Crystal Palace Football Club |date=1 September 2014 |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> due to a clause in his Wigan contract, his former club Hamilton received a sell-on fee from the Crystal Palace transfer, which they used to invest in the youth system through which the player had emerged.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/hamilton/11147234/James-McArthur-Scottish-sides-can-follow-Hamiltons-youth-policy.html |title=James McArthur: Scottish sides can follow Hamilton's youth policy |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=7 October 2014 |accessdate=25 September 2017|last1=Grahame |first1=Ewing }}</ref> McArthur scored his first goal for Palace on 13 December, in a 1–1 draw against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30357667 |title=Crystal Palace 1–1 Stoke |first=Tim |last=Oscroft |newspaper=BBC Sport |date=13 December 2014 |accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref>
In February 2016, McArthur tore ankle ligaments in a 2–1 loss to [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Crystal Palace's James McArthur and Jason Puncheon injured|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35498766|accessdate=4 February 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 February 2016}}</ref> He returned in time to take part in the [[2016 FA Cup Final]], which Crystal Palace lost 2–1 to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] after extra time.<ref name=facup16>{{cite web |author =Phil McNulty |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Manchester United (aet)|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36292265 |work=BBC Sport |date=21 May 2016|accessdate=28 January 2019 }}</ref>
In May 2018, having helped his club to maintain top division status for the fifth consecutive season of his spell at [[Selhurst Park]], McArthur was recognised by the Premier League for reaching 200 appearances in the competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/gallery/517617|title=Premier League Milestones|publisher=Premier League|date=23 May 2018|accessdate=21 September 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:James McArthur and Neymar.jpg|thumb|James McArthur being defended by [[Neymar Jr.]] in a friendly match between [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in March 2011]] He was first called up to the [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland under-21]] squad in February 2008,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/7228335.stm |title=Reid delight at McArthur call-up |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 February 2008 |accessdate=}}</ref> and he made his debut at that level against [[Ukraine national under-21 football team|Ukraine]] later that month.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.acciesfc.co.uk/home/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=483&Itemid=2|title=McArthur Earns First Cap|date=7 February 2008|publisher=Hamilton Academical FC|access-date=7 February 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618054736/http://www.acciesfc.co.uk/home/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=483&Itemid=2|archive-date=18 June 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 16 November 2010, McArthur made his senior international debut as a second-half substitute for [[Charlie Adam]] against the [[Faroe Islands national football team|Faroe Islands]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/9187834.stm | work= |publisher=BBC Sport | first=David | last=McDaid | title=Scotland 3–0 Faroe Islands | date=16 November 2010}}</ref> He scored his first international goal on 9 February 2011, in a [[Nations Cup (football)|Nations Cup]] match against [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Comfortable Carling Nations Cup win for Scotland|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_fa_news.cfm?page=1848&newsID=7210|publisher=Scottish Football Association|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=29 March 2014}}</ref>
As of August 2018, McArthur had made 32 international appearances and scored four goals.<ref name = "back problems">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45314080 |title=Scotland: Crystal Palace's James McArthur out, Hearts' John Souttar in |first=Richard |last=Winton |newspaper=BBC Sport |date=26 August 2018 |accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> At this time he advised Scotland manager [[Alex McLeish]] that he wished to be excused from international games while he managed ongoing back problems.<ref name = "back problems"/> Later that year, he announced his retirement from international football.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46016117 |title=James McArthur: Crystal Palace midfielder retires from Scotland duty |newspaper=BBC Sport |date=29 October 2018 |accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref>
