| caption = Wickham playing for [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in 2014 | fullname = Connor Neil Ralph Wickham<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|3|31|df=y}}<ref name="Hugman2010-11 436">{{Cite book | editor-first = Barry J. | editor-last = Hugman | title = The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 | year = 2010 | publisher = Mainstream Publishing | isbn = 978-1-84596-601-0 | page = 436 }}</ref> | birth_place = [[Hereford]], England | height = {{convert|1.91|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.safc.com/players-and-staff/first-team/connor-wickham |title=Connor Wickham |publisher=Sunderland A.F.C. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150327060751/http://www.safc.com/players-and-staff/first-team/connor-wickham |archivedate=27 March 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Striker]] / [[Winger (association football)#Winger|Winger]] | currentclub = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | clubnumber = 21 | youthyears1 = 2002–2006 | youthclubs1 = [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] | youthyears2 = 2006–2009 | youthclubs2 = [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] | years1 = 2009–2011 | clubs1 = [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] | caps1 = 65 | goals1 = 13 | years2 = 2011–2015 | clubs2 = [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] | caps2 = 74 | goals2 = 11 | years3 = 2013 | clubs3 = → [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] (loan) | caps3 = 6 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2013–2014 | clubs4 = → [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] (loan) | caps4 = 11 | goals4 = 8 | years5 = 2014 | clubs5 = → [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] (loan) | caps5 = 5 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2015– | clubs6 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | caps6 = 34 | goals6 = 7 | nationalyears1 = 2008 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalyears2 = 2009–2010 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 13 | nationalgoals2 = 9 | nationalyears3 = 2010–2013 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 4 | nationalgoals3 = 1 | nationalyears4 = 2010–2015 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 17 | nationalgoals4 = 6 | club-update = 21:18, 19 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 30 August 2013 | medaltemplates = {{MedalCompetition|[[UEFA European Under-17 Championship]]}} {{Medal|W|[[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship|2010]]|}} }} '''Connor Neil Ralph Wickham''' (born 31 March 1993) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] as a [[Forward (association football)#Forward|forward]].
He played youth football at [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] before moving to [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in 2006 where he continued in the youth structure. He made his full professional debut for the club in April 2009. He has also played at various levels of international football, scoring the winning goal in the [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]] Final.
==Early life== Wickham was born in [[Hereford]], [[Herefordshire]],<ref>{{cite news |last = Morgan |first = Ian |title = Bright future ahead for Ipswich Town's Connor Wickham |work = [[Hereford Times]] |date = 14 May 2010 |url=http://www.herefordtimes.com/sport/other/8166595.Bright_future_ahead_for_Ipswich_Town_s_Connor_Wickham |accessdate = 16 May 2010}}</ref> the son of an Army [[Warrant Officer]],<ref name="Striker Connor Wickham soon to cast aside his L plates">{{Cite news | last = Lansley | first = Peter | title = Striker Connor Wickham soon to cast aside his L plates | newspaper = [[The Times]] | date = 17 May 2010 | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/football_league/article7128066.ece | accessdate = 18 May 2010 | location=London}}</ref> He attended [[Philip Morant School and College|Philip Morant School]] in [[Colchester]], where he achieved eight A-C grade GCSEs – as well as being a prominent member of the school football team, where he was a prolific goalscorer from a young age.<ref name="Striker Connor Wickham soon to cast aside his L plates"/> He played youth football with [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] for four years.<ref name="Striker Connor Wickham soon to cast aside his L plates"/> Wickham's father is Northern Irish.<ref name="Speck">{{Cite news |url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1303333/The-Irish-coming-poaching-Connor-Wickham-approached-Nigel-Worthington.html |work = Daily Mail |accessdate = 5 February 2011 |date=16 August 2010 |title=All the buzz from the Football League: The Irish are coming poaching! Connor Wickham approached by Nigel Worthington |first=Ivan |last=Speck |location=London}}</ref>
==Club career==
===Ipswich Town===
====2008–09==== Wickham made his debut for the [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] [[first team]] on 11 April 2009, aged 16 years and 11 days. He came on as a 66th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Veliče Šumulikoski]] in a 3–1 home defeat against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]]<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7978909.stm | title = Ipswich 1–3 Doncaster | publisher= [[BBC Sport]] | accessdate = 11 April 2009| date = 11 April 2009}}</ref> and in doing so he became Ipswich's youngest ever player, beating the previous record being held by [[Jason Dozzell]] by 46 days.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eveningstar.co.uk/content/eveningstar/news/story.aspx?brand=ESTOnline&category=News&tBrand=ESTOnline&tCategory=News&itemid=IPED25%20Oct%202007%2007%3A06%3A10%3A037|title=Teenage star set to shine|date=24 October 2007|work=[[Evening Star (Ipswich)|Evening Star]]|accessdate=9 August 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070317011632/http://www.eveningstar.co.uk/content/eveningstar/news/story.aspx?brand=ESTOnline|archivedate=17 March 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====2009–10==== [[File:Connor Wickham - It 6.jpg|thumb|Wickham with Ipswich Town in 2009]] Wickham scored his first two senior goals in only his fourth appearance, when he scored in Ipswich's [[2009–10 Football League Cup#First round|2009–10 League Cup]] tie against [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]]. He also scored in the [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]], which saw Ipswich prevail 4–2.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Shrewsbury 3–3 Ipswich |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8188438.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 August 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2009}}</ref> He scored his first league goal in a 1–0 home victory over [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] in March 2010, his winning effort coming deep into injury time.<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8558495.stm | title = Ipswich 1–0 Scunthorpe|publisher = BBC Sport|date=13 March 2010|accessdate=13 March 2010 }}</ref> In April 2010, Wickham scored his second league goal, which came in the 90th minute in a 3–1 victory over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]]. This came two days after he signed his first professional contract at Ipswich, a two-year deal following his 17th birthday.<ref name="Connor Signs Two Year Deal">{{Cite web | url = http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10272~2014145,00.html | title = Connor Signs Two Year Deal | publisher = Ipswich Town F.C. | accessdate = 4 June 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100602214223/http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10272~2014145%2C00.html | archivedate = 2 June 2010 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
In April 2010, Wickham was named the Football League [[Football League Young Player of the Month|young player of the month]]. He won the award after scoring three goals in four matches during that time.<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.twtd.co.uk/news.php?storyid=16469 | title = Wickham Young Player of the Month |publisher = TWTD |date= 17 May 2010|accessdate=27 May 2010}}</ref> The following month [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] made offers to buy Wickham, but these were rejected by Ipswich Town.<ref name="Henderson">{{Cite news | last = Henderson | first = Mel | title = Ipswich wonderkid Connor Wickham passes Euro test on his way to the top | newspaper = [[Daily Mail]] | date = 1 June 2010 | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1282957/Ipswich-wonderkid-Connor-Wickham-passes-Euro-test-way-top.html?ito=feeds-newsxml | accessdate = 1 June 2010 | location=London}}</ref>
====2010–11==== Wickham extended his contract with Ipswich to 2013 in January 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Connor Wickham signs fresh Ipswich Town deal|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/i/ipswich_town/9370218.stm |publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 January 2011|accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref> It has an offer clause in it which states that if any bid equals or beats the one written in the contract, Ipswich would have to allow him to speak to the bidding club. It was reported that the figure was around the £15 million mark.<ref>{{Cite web|title=New Wickham Contract Has Offer Clause|url=http://www.twtd.co.uk/news.php?storyid=17929&title=new_wickham_contract_has_offer_clause |publisher=TWTD|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref>
On 22 January 2011, Wickham scored Ipswich's his first goal of the season in a 3–2 win over Doncaster Rovers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9365340.stm|title=Ipswich 3-2 Doncaster|date=29 January 2018|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> Two games later, Wickham scored in a 3–0 win over [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] at [[Portman Road]]. A clearance of a set piece saw Wickham pass two opponents before wrong-footing [[Rob Kozluk]] and goalkeeper [[Steve Simonsen]] to tap the ball into the net.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9389147.stm|title=Ipswich 3-0 Sheff Utd|date=14 February 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> Former Ipswich player, [[Kevin Beattie]] witnessed the goal, and described it as one of the greatest goals ever scored at Portman Road.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twtd.co.uk/news.php?storyid=17866&title=town_topic:_the_greatest_town_goals|title=Town Topic: The Greatest Town Goals - Ipswich Town News|publisher=|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> Two weeks later Wickham recorded his first professional [[hat-trick]] in a 6–0 win at Doncaster Rovers.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11707_6771920,00.html | title = Jewell hopes to keep Wickham| publisher = Sky Sports | date = 22 February 2011 | accessdate = 22 February 2011 }}</ref> Wickham's superb scoring form continued when he scored late in the match against Reading on 8 March. With Ipswich already 3–0 down, his goal counted for little, although it was once again a superb finish, as he volleyed a ball that was coming over his shoulder into the top corner of the goal from a tight angle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9415246.stm|title=Ipswich 1-3 Reading|date=8 March 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref>
On 4 March 2011, Wickham was named Championship player of the month for February after scoring four goals in the month, including his first professional hat-trick at Doncaster.<ref name="twtd.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.twtd.co.uk/news.php?storyid=18009&title=wickham_named_championship_player_of_the_month|title=Wickham Named Championship Player of the Month - Ipswich Town News|publisher=|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> Two weeks later he was named the Football League Young Player of the Year as well as the Championship Apprentice of the Year at the [[Football League Awards|2011 Football League Awards]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.football-league.co.uk/flawards/news/20110320/connor-wickham-wins-young-player-of-the-year_2293338_2319366 | title = Connor Wickham wins Young Player of the Year| publisher = Football League | date = 20 March 2011 | accessdate = 20 March 2011 }}</ref>
On 2 April 2011, [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] manager, [[Harry Redknapp]] admitted that his side had not made a bid for Wickham. This was despite several reports to the contrary suggesting a bid in the region of £10m had been made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11890_6847653,00.html|title=Harry denies bids|publisher=|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> The same day, Wickham scored the second of Ipswich's two goals against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in the Championship, as they won 2–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9439038.stm|title=Burnley 1-2 Ipswich|date=2 April 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref>
He signed a one-year extension to his contract on 8 April 2011, contracting him to the club until the summer of 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/13012409|title=Connor Wickham extends Ipswich Town contract|date=8 April 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> Wickham admitted he was delighted to have signed the contract, and said he just wanted to concentrate on achieving his goals with Ipswich, rather than focusing on speculation about his future. He said:
{{Cquote|I'm obviously delighted to have signed a new contract and feel that I'm at the right club to progress as a player. After having a look over the last two years I approached this season wanting to make a real impact. It didn't start well with me getting injured but I feel I have moved forward as a player since I got back in the side. I'm playing games every week, I'm enjoying my football and the club is moving in the right direction and that's all I want.|||Connor Wickham|<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twtd.co.uk/news.php?storyid=18220&title=wickham_delighted_to_extend_contract|title=Wickham Delighted to Extend Contract - Ipswich Town News|publisher=|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref>}}
He scored his next league goal on 7 May away to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], making the score 3–2 in Leicester's favour.
===Sunderland=== On 29 June 2011, Wickham signed a four-year deal with [[Premier League]] club [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] for a fee of £8 million. The fee has the potential to rise to £12 million over the course of the contract.<ref name="Black Cats snap up Wickham">{{Cite web | url = http://www.safc.com/news/20110629/black-cats-snap-up-wickham_2256213_2383586 | title = Black Cats snap up Wickham | date=29 June 2011 | publisher = Sunderland A.F.C. | accessdate = 29 June 2011}}</ref> Despite having recently signed a new contract with Ipswich, Wickham had been widely tipped to move to a Premier League club following a highly successful 2010–11 season. Although Ipswich manager [[Paul Jewell]] had said there was no pressure to sell the youngster, Sunderland's eventual offer proved too lucrative.<ref name="Sunderland sign Ipswich striker Connor Wickham">{{Cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/13873800.stm| title = Sunderland sign Ipswich striker Connor Wickham| publisher = BBC Sport| accessdate = 29 June 2011| date=29 June 2011}}</ref> The fee broke Ipswich's record for transfer fees recouped, and broke the transfer record for a Football League player moving to a Premier League club. Ipswich's chief executive Simon Clegg summed it up: {{Cquote|As much as we would have liked to have kept Connor at Portman Road we have to be realistic and recognise that the offer from Sunderland was simply too good to turn down.|||Simon Clegg|<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10272~2383584,00.html|title=Wickham leaves Town in record move|date=29 June 2011|publisher=Ipswich Town F.C.|accessdate=22 October 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903144841/http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10272~2383584%2C00.html|archivedate=3 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>}}
He scored his first goal for Sunderland in a pre-season friendly against [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]]. Wickham made his first competitive appearance for Sunderland when he came on as a substitute in the 1–0 defeat to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] in the [[Tyne–Wear derby]] on 20 August 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14514549.stm|title=Sunderland 0–1 Newcastle|author=Alistair Magowan|date=21 August 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 October 2011}}</ref> He made his first Premier League start for Sunderland on 22 October 2011 where he helped Sunderland secure their second win of the season against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15319551.stm|title=Bolton 0–2 Sunderland|first=Becky|last= Ashton|date=22 October 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=22 October 2011}}</ref>
Wickham scored his first Premier League goal for the ''Black Cats'' a week later in the 2–2 draw with [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. The following week against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[Old Trafford]], Wickham suffered a knee injury and had to be substituted just five minutes into the game.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11695/7294582/Injury-woe-for-Wickham |title=Injury woe for Wickham| work=Sky Sports}}</ref> The arrival of new manager [[Martin O'Neill]] saw Wickham fall out of favour as he spent the majority of the remainder of the season on the bench and playing for the reserves.<ref>{{cite news |last=Spellman |first=Damian |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/martin-oneill-challenges-sunderland-striker-connor-wickham-to-take-his-chance-8428851.html |title=Martin O'Neill challenges Sunderland striker Connor Wickham to take his chance |date=21 December 2012 |accessdate=6 July 2014 |publisher=The Independent}}</ref> Wickham came off the bench at [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in the third round of the [[2012–13 FA Cup|FA Cup]] to score his first goal of the season as Sunderland came from 2–0 down to earn a replay.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cartwright |first=Phil |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20863471 |title=Bolton 2–2 Sunderland |date=5 January 2013 |accessdate=6 July 2014 |publisher=BBC}}</ref>
====Loan spells==== On 8 February 2013, Wickham joined [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on loan, initially on a one-month deal.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21383420 | title = Connor Wickham: Sheffield Wednesday secure loan deal | date = 8 February 2013 | accessdate = 8 February 2013 | publisher = BBC Sport}}</ref> He made his debut on 9 February, in a 2–2 draw against Derby County.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21311544 "Sheffield Wed 2–2 Derby"] BBC Sport. 9 February 2013. Retrieved 9 March 2013.</ref> He scored his first goal for the club on 9 March, in a 1–0 win away against Leicester City in what was the last game of his loan spell, firing a first time volley into the roof of the net.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21639176 "Leicester 0–1 Sheff Wed"] BBC Sport. 9 March 2013. Retrieved 9 March 2013.</ref> On 14 March 2013 it was confirmed that Wickham would not be re-joining Sheffield Wednesday on loan.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.swfc.co.uk/news/article/wickham-returns-to-sunderland-714851.aspx |title=Wickham returns to Sunderland |work=www.swfc.co.uk |date=14 March 2013}}</ref>
On 27 August 2013, Wickham inspired Sunderland to a late comeback against [[MK Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] in the [[2013–14 Football League Cup|Football League Cup]], scoring twice and assisting [[Jozy Altidore]]'s goal as the Premier League side scored four times in the last 20 minutes to win 4–2.
On 1 November 2013, Wickham re-joined Sheffield Wednesday in another loan move until 1 January 2014.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Wickham signs |url=http://www.swfc.co.uk/news/article/wickham-signs-1148390.aspx |work=www.swfc.co.uk |date=1 November 2013}}</ref> Wickham scored on his return in the 5–2 win over Reading at [[Hillsborough Stadium|Hillsborough]] on 2 November. Wickham again appeared on the score sheet scoring a brace of goals in the 2–1 win over Leicester City on 3 December. Four goals in four games in December 2013 earned Wickham a nomination for the December Championship Player of the Month award<ref>http://www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/20140109/player-of-the-month-nominations_2293322_3610119</ref> but he ultimately lost out to Leicester City's Danny Drinkwater.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eatsleepsport.com/leicester-city/drinkwater-gets-monthly-award-1692866.html#.Us_FpPZAKHk|title=EatSleepSport|website=www.eatsleepsport.com|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> On 31 December 2013, his loan spell at Wednesday was extended by a further month,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25561786|title=Connor Wickham extends Sheffield Wednesday loan|date=31 December 2013|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> although his parent club prevented him from representing the ''Owls'' in the [[2013–14 FA Cup|FA Cup]].<ref>http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/sheffield-wednesday/sheffield-wednesday-owls-connor-blow-1-6346262</ref> On 11 January 2014, he scored in Wednesday's 6–0 win over Yorkshire rivals [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/football/leeds-utd/sheffield-wednesday-6-leeds-united-0-wednesday-wipe-out-22-years-of-hurt-with-destruction-of-leeds-1-6368579|title=Sheffield Wednesday 6 Leeds United 0: Wednesday wipe out 22 years of hurt with destruction of Leeds|website=www.yorkshirepost.co.uk|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> After the game, he described the win as a "fantastic team performance" while saying that he was "unhappy with my own personal performance."<ref>{{cite tweet|user=ConnorWickham10|author=Connor Wickham|number=422033957568651264|date=11 January 2014|title=Unhappy with my personal performance today but buzzing for @clavery13 deserved his goals! Fantastic team, performance onwards & upwards now}}</ref> He was recalled to his parent club on 27 January 2014.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25913122 | title = Connor Wickham: Sunderland recall Sheffield Wednesday striker | accessdate=27 January 2014 | date = 27 January 2014 | publisher = BBC Sport}}</ref>
On 26 February 2014, Wickham joined Football League Championship side Leeds United on loan until the end of the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|2013–14]] season.<ref>{{Cite web |title=UNITED WIN STRIKER RACE |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/news/article/1we28v1r0zbldzj4yk6qnebld/title/united-win-striker-race |work=Leeds United AFC |date=26 February 2014}}</ref> Wickham was handed the number 9 shirt for Leeds.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Striker Connor Wickham signs on loan for Leeds|url=http://www.itv.com/news/calendar/story/2014-02-26/striker-connor-wickham-signs-on-loan-for-leeds/|work=ITV |date=26 February 2014|accessdate=26 February 2014}}</ref> He made his debut on 1 March 2014 in a 1–1 draw away to [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] at [[Loftus Road]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=QPR 1 1 Leeds|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26300044|work=BBC |date=1 March 2014|accessdate=4 March 2014}}</ref>
====Return to Sunderland==== On 24 March, Wickham was recalled from his loan after playing four games for Leeds to bolster Sunderland's goal scoring options, with Steven Fletcher injured and [[Jozy Altidore]] badly out of form.
On 16 April, he scored two goals in a 2–2 draw with Manchester City at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26716896 "Manchester City 2–2 Sunderland"] BBC Sport. 16 April 2014. Retrieved 27 April 2014.</ref> Three days later, he scored the club's first goal in Sunderland's 2–1 win against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Sheringham|first=Sam|title=Chelsea 1 – 2 Sunderland|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26999147|accessdate=19 April 2014|newspaper=BBC Sport|date=19 April 2014}}</ref> On 27 April, he scored a brace to help Sunderland overcome [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] 4–0, playing a pivotal role in Sunderland's late surge to try and avoid relegation.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27092972 "Sunderland 4–0 Cardiff City"] BBC Sport. 27 April 2014. Retrieved 27 April 2014.</ref> He was named [[Premier League Player of the Month]] for April.<ref name="Tony Pulis & Connor Wickham">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27252682 "Tony Pulis & Connor Wickham"] BBC Sport. 2 May 2014. Retrieved 2 May 2014.</ref> On 3 May, his [[Cross (football)|cross]] assisted [[Sebastian Larsson]]'s goal in a 1–0 win at [[Old Trafford]], making it Sunderland's first win away to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] since 1968.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stone|first=Simon|title=Manchester United 0–1 Sunderland|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27168533|accessdate=5 May 2014|newspaper=BBC Sport|date=3 May 2014}}</ref>
On 4 October 2014, he scored his first goal of the season and assisted a [[Steven Fletcher (footballer)|Steven Fletcher]] goal in a 3–1 win over [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/sunderland-3-1-stoke-wickham-fletcher-4376481|title=Sunderland 3-1 Stoke: Gus Poyet's side grab first win|first=Colin|last=Young|date=4 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> In December 2014, Connor Wickham agreed a new four-and-a-half year deal with Sunderland.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://safc.com/news/team-news/2014/december/wickham-signs-new-deal |title=Wickham pens new deal |publisher=Sunderland Association Football Club |date=9 December 2014 |accessdate=24 December 2014 |first=Stuart |last=Vose}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== On 3 August 2015, Wickham joined [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on a five-year deal for an undisclosed fee,<ref>{{Cite news |title=Wickham Moves South |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/august/wickham-moves-south/ |publisher=Crystal Palace FC |date=3 August 2015}}</ref> although some sources reported it as an initial £7 million, rising to a potential £9 million depending upon his performance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Crystal Palace sign striker Connor Wickham from Sunderland|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33756128|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=3 August 2015|date=3 August 2015}}</ref> Wickham made his debut on 8 August 2015 as a second-half substitute in the 3–1 win at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Report: Norwich City 1–3 Crystal Palace|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/august/report-norwich-city-1-3-crystal-palace/|date=8 August 2015|website=cpfc.co.uk|accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref>
In November 2016, Wickham sustained a serious knee injury which kept him out of first-team action until October 2018. He did not not make an appearance in the starting line-up until January 2019, scoring the opening goal in a 2–0 fourth-round [[FA Cup]] win against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2019/january/team-news-wickham-makes-first-start-in-26-months/|title=Team News: Wickham Makes First Start in 26 Months|website=cpfc.co.uk|date=27 January 2019|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/jan/27/crystal-palace-tottenham-fa-cup-match-report|last=Fifield|first=Dominic|date=27 January 2019|title=Connor Wickham ends long wait as Crystal Palace knock out Tottenham|work=theguardian.com|accessdate=28 January 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Wickham is eligible for Northern Ireland, as his father is Northern Irish meaning that until he receives a full cap from [[England national football team|England]] in a competitive game he is still eligible for the national team. His progress in the English Premier League was also being monitored by former Republic of Ireland management duo of [[Martin O'Neill]] and [[Roy Keane]].<ref>Irish Independent Weekender Magazine 26 April 2024</ref> His links to Northern Ireland mean that he also qualifies to play for the Republic of Ireland though there are no reports of Wickham having been approached by current manager Mick McCarthy.<ref name="Speck"/>
===England U16=== Wickham has represented the [[England national under-16 football team|England under-16]] team and was also on stand-by for the [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]] squad during the 2008–09 season.<ref name="Profiles - Connor Wickham">{{Cite web | url = http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/ProfilesDetail/0,,10272~46161,00.html | title = Profiles – Connor Wickham | publisher = Ipswich Town F.C. | accessdate = 11 April 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090427135335/http://www.itfc.co.uk/page/ProfilesDetail/0%2C%2C10272~46161%2C00.html | archivedate = 27 April 2009 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> He won the 2008 [[Victory Shield]] with England, scoring in the 2–0 final win over Scotland.
===England U17=== On 11 August 2009, Wickham received a call-up to the [[England national under-17 football team|under-17 squad]], for their three-game FA International Tournament, which would take place later that month.<ref>[http://simply-blue.co.uk/viewtopic.php?id=826 Wickham Gets England Call]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Simply-Blue. Retrieved 13 August 2009.</ref>
In May 2010, Wickham was included in the [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] squad for the [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|UEFA European U17 Championship]] in [[Liechtenstein]]. He was involved in two of the goals in England's 3–1 win against the [[Czech Republic national under-17 football team|Czech Republic]] in the group stage, with a convincing performance.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.uefa.com/under17/matches/season=2010/round=15342/match=2002332/report/ | title = England flex muscles against Czechs | publisher = UEFA | accessdate = 22 May 2010 }}</ref> He then played the full game in the second group match against [[Greece national under-17 football team|Greece]], once again playing well.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2010/Greece%20v%20England/210510# | title = Barkley banks semi spot | publisher = The Football Association | accessdate = 22 May 2010 }}</ref> Wickham was rested for the final group game of the tournament, but returned to face [[France national youth football team|France]] in the semi-final. He scored both goals for England in a 2–1 victory, both left-footed, and both in the first half.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u17s/News/match-centre/2010/EnglandvFrance/Report | title = Wickham brace sends England into Final | publisher = The Football Association | accessdate = 27 May 2010 }}</ref> Wickham scored the winner in a 2–1 victory over [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]] in the final. He received the ball on the edge of the box before proceeding to beat two defenders and drill the ball low into the net.<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1282660/England-youngsters-seniors-claiming-UEFA-Under-17-title.html?ito=feeds-newsxml | title = England youngsters show the seniors how it's done by claiming UEFA Under 17 title | publisher = The Daily Mail | accessdate = 30 May 2010 | location=London | first=Neil | last=Moxley | date=31 May 2010}}</ref> He was given the Golden Player award by UEFA for the best player in the tournament.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/under17/history/season=2010/goldenplayer/index.html|title=2010: Connor Wickham|accessdate=18 May 2014|work=UEFA}}</ref>
Following the success of Wickham in the England youth set-up, speculation began to mount about him winning a senior cap, and possibly even being included in [[Fabio Capello]]'s [[2010 FIFA World Cup|World Cup squad]] – although seemingly a longshot. Former England defender [[Russell Osman]] said:
{{Cquote|Of course people will question why Capello would take Wickham to the World Cup but my reply would be, "Why not?" [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] picked [[Theo Walcott]] four years ago and he was 17 with even less experience than Wickham.|||Russell Osman|"<ref name="Henderson"/>''}}
===England U21=== [[File:Connor Wickham England U21.jpg|upright|thumbnail|left|Wickham playing for England Under 21s in 2012]] On 7 September 2010, England under-21 boss, [[Stuart Pearce]] admitted that he had been monitoring Wickham's progress, and that he would consider calling him up to the under-21 squad once he had recovered from injury.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Pearce well aware of Wickham | newspaper = [[Yahoo! Sports]] | date = 7 September 2010 | url = http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/07092010/63/pearce-well-aware-wickham.html | accessdate = 8 September 2010}}</ref> On 15 November 2010 Pearce did name Wickham in the [[England under-21 national football team|under-21s]] friendly match against Germany on 16 November 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twtd.co.uk/news.php?storyid=17388|title=Wickham Called Up to England U21s - Ipswich Town News|publisher=|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> In that game he came on as a 66th-minute substitute in a 2–0 defeat for England. Following that game, and the important experience Wickham gained, he returned to the England under-19 side. However, it would not be long before he was back in the fold for the under-21s.
On 14 March 2011, it was announced that Wickham had been included in the squad for England's games against Denmark and Iceland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twtd.co.uk/news.php?storyid=18065|title=Wickham in England U21 Squad - Ipswich Town News|publisher=|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> He came on as a substitute in the game against Denmark, which England went on to win 4–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/sturridge-stands-out-as-england-romp-to-40-victory-2252547.html|title=Sturridge stands out as England romp to 4-0 victory|date=25 March 2011|publisher=|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref> The following Monday, Wickham started the game in a friendly against Iceland at [[Deepdale Stadium|Deepdale]] in [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]]. It was his first start for the under-21s, and he played the full 90 minutes as England lost the game 2–1 to a very strong Iceland side that consisted of a number of first team regulars. Wickham played as a lone striker in the game.
Prior to the Iceland game, Wickham admitted that he was hopeful of being included in the squad that would play in the summer's Euro 2011 under-21s [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|tournament]] due to take place in June. Having been an instrumental figure in the success of the under-17's the previous summer, he felt he could repeat the feat at a higher level. He said:
{{Cquote|It would be another summer tournament, and I want to win another tournament. It'll be different, but if we play to the potential that is in our team we are capable of beating anyone on our day. All the boys have taken me as part of the team and have treated me no differently to anyone else. They are a great bunch of lads and I'd be happy to spend the summer with them. Even just to be selected would be brilliant but to win it would be better. I don't see why we can't go on and really push this summer to win the tournament.|||Connor Wickham|<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2011/EnglandIceland/Match-Previews/connor-wickham|title=The website for the English football association, the Emirates FA Cup and the England football team|first=The Football|last=Association|website=www.thefa.com|accessdate=29 January 2018}}</ref>"''}}
He scored his first goal for the under-21s on 10 September 2012, scoring the only goal of the game in a win against [[Norway national under-21 football team|Norway]] in [[Chesterfield]], ensuring England won their European Under-21 Championship qualifying group.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19547219 "England U-21 1–0 Norway U-21"] BBC Sport. 10 September 2012. Retrieved 16 October 2012.</ref> He scored his second goal on 16 October, helping England to a 2–0 aggregate win in the play-off against [[Serbia national under-21 football team|Serbia]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19944974 "Serbia U21 0–1 England U21"] BBC Sport. 16 October 2012. Retrieved 16 October 2012.</ref>

==Sponsorship== In 2010, Wickham signed a sponsorship deal with British sportswear and equipment supplier, [[Umbro]].<ref name="Striker Connor Wickham soon to cast aside his L plates"/> He appeared in an advert for the new England kit in September 2010<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.football-shirts.co.uk/fans/a-closer-look-at-the-201011-england-home-shirt_8881 | title = Closer Look At England 10/11 Home Shirt | publisher = Football Shirts News | accessdate = 22 August 2011 }}</ref> and is one of the flagship wearers of Umbro's GT range of football boots.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.footballboots.co.uk/umbro-gt.html | title = Umbro GT Football Boots| publisher = FootballBoots.co.uk | accessdate = 22 August 2011 }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Michy Batshuayi | image = ENG-BEL (26).jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Batshuayi playing for [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] in 2018 | fullname = Michy Batshuayi-Atunga<ref>{{cite web |title=Squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/465277 |publisher=Premier League |date=1 September 2017 |accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|10|2|df=y}}<ref name="FIFA">{{cite web |url=https://tournament.fifadata.com/documents/FWC/2018/pdf/FWC_2018_SQUADLISTS.PDF |title=2018 FIFA World Cup Russia: List of players: Belgium |publisher=FIFA |format=PDF |page=3 |date=10 June 2018 |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Brussels]], Belgium | height = 1.85 m<ref name="FIFA"/> | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Crystal Palace F. C.|Crystal Palace]] (on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]) | clubnumber = 23 | youthyears1 = 2003–2005 | youthclubs1 = RFC Evere | youthyears2 = 2005–2006 | youthclubs2 = RUSA Schaarbeek | youthyears3 = 2006–2007 | youthclubs3 = [[RWDM Brussels FC|Brussels]] | youthyears4 = 2007–2008 | youthclubs4 = [[RSC Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] | youthyears5 = 2008–2009 | youthclubs5 = [[RWDM Brussels FC|Brussels]] | youthyears6 = 2008–2011 | youthclubs6 = [[Standard Liège]] | years1 = 2011–2014 | clubs1 = [[Standard Liège]] | caps1 = 97 | goals1 = 39 | years2 = 2014–2016 | clubs2 = [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] | caps2 = 62 | goals2 = 26 | years3 = 2016– | clubs3 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | caps3 = 32 | goals3 = 7 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4 = → [[Borussia Dortmund]] (loan) | caps4 = 10 | goals4 = 7 | years5 = 2018–2019 | clubs5 = → [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] (loan) | caps5 = 15 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2019– | clubs6 = → [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (loan) | caps6 = 6 | goals6 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2012–2014 | nationalteam1 = [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 13 | nationalgoals1 = 7 | nationalyears2 = 2015– | nationalteam2 = [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] | nationalcaps2 = 23 | nationalgoals2 = 12 | medaltemplates = {{Medal|Sport|Men's [[Association football|football]]}} {{Medal|Country|{{fb|BEL}}}} {{Medal|Comp|[[FIFA World Cup]]}} {{Medal|3rd|[[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 Russia]]|}} | club-update = 19:36, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 14:07, 22 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Michy Batshuayi-Atunga''' ({{IPA-fr|mi(t)ʃi batʃu.a.(j)i}}; born 2 October 1993) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]].
He began his professional career at [[Standard Liège]] in 2011, scoring 44 goals in 120 games across all competitions. His 21 goals in the [[2013–14 Belgian Pro League]] made him the second-highest scorer and contributed to his [[Ebony Shoe Award]]. He then transferred to [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] for £4.5 million, helping them reach the [[2016 Coupe de France Final]]. In July 2016, he was signed by Chelsea for £33 million, and scored the goal that won the [[List of English football champions|Premier League title]] in his [[2016–17 Premier League|debut season]].
Batshuayi scored in his international debut for Belgium against [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]] in March 2015. He was part of their side that reached the quarter-finals of [[UEFA Euro 2016]] and third place at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].
==Club career== ===Standard Liège=== [[File:UEFA Euroleague FC Salzburg gegen Standard Lüttich 34.JPG|thumb|left|Batshuayi and [[Frédéric Bulot]] prepare to kick off in a [[UEFA Europa League]] game against [[FC Red Bull Salzburg|Red Bull Salzburg]] in October 2013.]] Born in [[Brussels]], Batshuayi had a nomadic youth career with spells at Evere, Schaarbeek, [[FC Brussels|Brussels]] (twice) and [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] before he joined [[Standard Liège]].<ref name=four/>
Batshuayi made his debut for the senior team on 20 February 2011 in a 4–1 loss away to [[KAA Gent|Gent]], replacing [[Franck Berrier]] for the last seven minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match/_/id/312017?cc=3436|title=KAA Gent 4 Liege 1|date=20 February 2011|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref> Six days later, he made his only other appearance of the [[Belgian Pro League]] [[2010–11 Belgian Pro League|season]], filling in for [[Aloys Nong]] in the last minute of a 3–0 victory against [[KV Mechelen]] at the [[Stade Maurice Dufrasne]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Standard Liege 3–0 KV Mechelen|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/match?gameId=303421|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref>
On 21 July, Batshuayi was an unused [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in the [[2011 Belgian Super Cup]], a 1–0 loss to Gent.<ref>{{cite news|title=Genk edge Standard to win first Super Cup|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=bel/news/newsid=1652485.html|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=UEFA|date=21 July 2011}}</ref> On 15 December, he scored his first professional goal, the only one away to [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] in the last match of Group B during the [[2011–12 UEFA Europa League group stage#Group B|2011–12 UEFA Europa League]] group stage, advancing his team into the knockout stages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2012/matches/round=2000272/match=2007411/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Solid Standard march on unbeaten after FCK win|date=15 December 2011|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref> Six days later, he added two more in a 2–1 win at [[Lierse S.K.|Lierse]] in the quarter-final first leg of the [[Belgian Cup]], although his side lost 5–4 on aggregate.<ref>{{cite news|title=Standard: Batshuayi l'homme du match, au Lierse|trans-title=Standard:Batshuayi man of the match, at Lierse|url=http://www.sudinfo.be/264344/article/sports/foot-belge/standard/2011-12-22/standard-batshuayi-l%E2%80%99homme-du-match-au-lierse|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sud Info|date=22 December 2011|language=French}}</ref> He scored his first league goal on 14 January 2012 to round off a 6–1 home win over [[Beerschot A.C.|Germinal Beerschot]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Standard vernedert zwak Beerschot|trans-title=Standard humiliate weak Beerschot|url=http://sporza.be/cm/sporza/voetbal/Jupiler_Pro_League/1.1195302|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sporza|date=14 January 2012|language=Dutch}}</ref> and ended the campaign with six. He was sent-off as a substitute in a 3–2 loss at Genk on 22 April for stamping on the chest of [[Jeroen Simaeys]], for which the [[Royal Belgian Football Association]] suspended him for four matches.<ref>{{cite news|title=Foot : Michy Batshuayi (Standard) convoqué devant le Comité sportif mardi|trans-title=Football: Michy Batshuayi (Standard) summoned before the Sports Committee on Monday|url=http://www.lesoir.be/59063/article/actualite/fil-info/2012-08-27/foot-michy-batshuayi-standard-convoqu%C3%A9-devant-comit%C3%A9-sportif-mardi|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=Le Soir|date=22 April 2012|language=French}}</ref>
Batshuayi was again sent-off on 25 September 2012 in a 3–2 win at [[Royal Mouscron-Péruwelz|Mouscron]] in the sixth round of the Belgian Cup, having elbowed Benjamin Delacourt within the first half-hour; he was suspended for the next two matches of the competition and fined €200.<ref>{{cite news|title=Le Standard accepte la suspension de Batshuayi|trans-title=Standard accept Batshuayi's suspension|url=http://www.7sur7.be/7s7/fr/1745/Standard/article/detail/1507843/2012/09/27/Le-Standard-accepte-la-suspension-de-Batshuayi.dhtml|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=7sur7|date=27 September 2012|language=French}}</ref> In an interview a month later, he said he felt "destroyed" by the suspension.<ref>{{cite news|title=Batshuayi : "C’était très dur pour moi après Mouscron"|trans-title=Batshuayi: "It was very hard for me after Mouscron|url=http://www.dhnet.be/sports/football/division1/standard/batshuayi-c-etait-tres-dur-pour-moi-apres-mouscron-51b74c52e4b0de6db9785a91|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=DH|date=2 November 2012|language=French}}</ref> He recorded 12 goals in 26 matches over the campaign, including two on 19 May 2013 to decide a 4–3 home win over [[K.S.C. Lokeren Oost-Vlaanderen|Lokeren]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Batshuayi redt Standard tegen Lokeren|trans-title=Batshuayi saves Standard against Lokeren|url=http://sporza.be/cm/sporza/matchcenter/mc_voetbal/2.22186/MG_SP10_SP_I_en_terugmatch_finale_PO_II/1.1632792|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sporza|date=19 May 2013|language=Dutch}}</ref>
[[File:Michy Batshuayi 2014.jpg|thumb|right|Batshuayi playing for Standard Liège during a match in March 2014]] In the [[2013–14 Belgian Pro League|2013–14 season]], Batshuayi scored 21 goals in 34 matches, putting him in second place for the league's top scorer behind Lokeren's [[Hamdi Harbaoui]].<ref name=four>{{cite news|title=Michy Batshuayi: The SpongeBob-loving Spurs target tearing up Ligue 1|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/michy-batshuayi-spongebob-loving-spurs-target-tearing-ligue-1|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=FourFourTwo|date=23 December 2015}}</ref> This tally included a first professional [[hat-trick]] on 15 September in a 4–2 win at [[K.V. Oostende|Oostende]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Batshuayi consolida el liderato del Standard en Bélgica|trans-title=Batshuayi consolidates Standard's lead in Belgium|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2013/09/15/internacional/1379274344_586475.html|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=Diario AS|date=15 September 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref> He was awarded the [[Ebony Shoe Award]] for the season's best player of African origin, ahead of Harbaoui.<ref name=ebony>{{cite news|title=The Belgian Ebony Shoe 2014 goes to Standard Liège’s Michy Batshuayi|url=http://www.benefoot.net/the-belgian-ebony-shoe-2014-goes-to-standard-lieges-michy-batshuayi/|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Benefoot|date=6 May 2014}}</ref>
===Marseille=== On 8 August 2014, Batshuayi signed with French club [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] for a £4.5 million transfer fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhnet.be/sports/football/division1/standard/batshuayi-vers-marseille-53a7a85c3570c0e743403706#.U6dnGeSbi_Q.twitter|title=Batshuayi vers Marseille !|trans-title=Batshuayi to Marseille!|date=23 June 2014|publisher=DHNET|accessdate=23 June 2014|language=French}}</ref><ref name=sky/> He made his debut the next day as Marseille began the [[Ligue 1]] season with a 3–2 win at [[SC Bastia|Bastia]], replacing [[Dimitri Payet]] with 11 minutes remaining. On 29 October, he scored his first goal for the club to open a 2–1 defeat at [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]] in the third round of the [[Coupe de la Ligue]].<ref>{{cite news|title=L'OM éliminé à l'ultime seconde !|trans-title=OM eliminated in the last second!|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/match/334512|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=L'Equipe|date=19 October 2014|language=French}}</ref> He scored nine league goals for [[Marcelo Bielsa]]'s team, despite rarely starting matches.<ref name=four/> On 22 February 2015, within five minutes of coming on for [[André-Pierre Gignac]], he scored twice away to [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]] in an eventual 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news|title=Match nul à suspense à Geoffroy-Guichard.|trans-title=Suspenseful draw at ''Geoffroy-Guichard''|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/match/316426|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=L'Equipe|date=22 February 2015|language=French}}</ref> In March, he added further braces in away victories at [[Toulouse FC|Toulouse]] and [[RC Lens|Lens]] (6–1 and 4–0 respectively), the latter after taking Gignac's place at half-time.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michy Batshuayi leads rout as Marseille refind form at Toulouse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/mar/06/toulouse-marseille-ligue-1-match-report|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=The Guardian|date=6 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BATSHUAYI BAGS BRACE IN MARSEILLE ROMP|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/batshuayi-bags-brace-in-marseille-romp.htm|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Ligue 1|date=22 March 2015}}</ref>
On 23 August 2015, Batshuayi scored his first goals of the season, a brace, in a 6–0 victory over [[Troyes AC|Troyes]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=A|title=MICHEL'S MARSEILLE HIT TROYES FOR SIX|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/michel-s-marseille-hit-troyes-for-six.htm|publisher=[[Ligue 1]]|accessdate=27 August 2015|date=23 August 2015}}</ref> Soon after, club president Vincent Lebrune said, "There is not a single top 15 world club that is not interested in Batshuayi. He is one of the most wanted players on the market. There were a lot of offers for him this summer, but he didn't want to leave. He's proving himself on the pitch, and if clubs want him then they are going to have to pay around €50m."<ref name=four/> By the mid-season break, he had 11 goals from 19 matches, behind only [[Le Classique|arch-rival]] [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]]'s [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]], with Marseille in tenth in the league table and PSG in first.<ref name=four/> Batshuayi finished the league season with 17 goals. He added two more goals from five games in the [[Coupe de France]], one being in [[2016 Coupe de France Final|the final]], where Marseille lost 4–2 to PSG on 21 May 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ibrahimovic nets brace in cup triumph|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/olympique-marseille-vs-psg/2215915/report|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Goal.com|date=21 May 2016}}</ref>
===Chelsea=== [[File:Michy Batshuayi v Burnley.jpg|thumb|upright|Batshuayi in action against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in August 2017]] In April 2016, English [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] were reported as the favourites to sign Batshuayi, having offered a €35 million bid.<ref name=batsman>{{cite news|last1=Atchinson|first1=Jack|title=Profile of West Ham transfer target Michy Batshuayi of Marseille|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10259822/profile-of-west-ham-transfer-target-michy-batshuayi-of-marseille|accessdate=7 July 2016|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 June 2016}}</ref> Two months later, their London neighbours [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] made a €38 million (£31.5 million) bid which would have made him their record signing, while Italian champions [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] were also among the interested parties.<ref name=sky>{{cite news|last1=Trehan|first1=Dev|title=Michy Batshuayi subject of £31.5m bid from Crystal Palace|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11706/10327157/michy-batshuayi-subject-of-163315m-bid-from-crystal-palace|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 June 2016}}</ref> Although Palace's bid was accepted, Batshuayi did not want to make the move, instead engaging with a €40 million (£33.2 million) offer from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], for which he left Belgium's [[UEFA Euro 2016]] squad to undergo a medical.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michy Batshuayi set for Chelsea medical before £33m move from Marseille|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/28/michy-batshuayi-chelsea-medical-33m-marseille|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=The Guardian|date=29 June 2016}}</ref> On 3 July, he signed a five-year deal at Chelsea.<ref>{{cite news|title=Batshuayi signs|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/07/batshuayi-signs.html?extcmp=SOCIA_TW_ENG_ARTICLES|date=3 July 2016|accessdate=3 July 2016|publisher=Chelsea F.C.}}</ref> He was the first signing by their new manager [[Antonio Conte]], and said his aim was to get the team back to winning the Premier League and qualifying for the [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Spence|first1=Liam|title=Chelsea new boy Michy Batshuayi opens up about Champions League hopes and Antonio Conte|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/686719/Chelsea-new-boy-Michy-Batshuayi-opens-up-Champions-League-hopes-Antonio-Conte-Gossip|accessdate=7 July 2016|work=Daily Express|date=6 July 2016}}</ref> Batshuayi added he was eager to work alongside their midfielder [[Oscar (footballer, born 1991)|Oscar]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cannon|first1=James|title=Michy Batshuayi "can’t wait" to convert Oscar’s assists following Chelsea transfer|url=http://www.squawka.com/news/michy-batshuayi-cant-wait-to-covert-oscars-assists-following-chelsea-transfer/715297|accessdate=7 July 2016|publisher=Squawka|date=3 July 2016}}</ref> Batshuayi joined Chelsea for pre-season in Austria, and on 20 July, he made his debut in a friendly against [[Wolfsberger AC]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.goal.com/en/news/1862/premier-league/2016/07/20/25799992/batshuayis-debut-chelseas-bid-for-morata-and-costa-staying-conte- |title= Batshuayi's debut, Chelsea's bid for Morata and Costa staying – Conte wants firepower |publisher= Goal.com |date= 20 July 2016}}</ref> A day later, he scored his first two goals in an 8–0 friendly victory against Atus Ferlach.<ref>{{cite news|title=Blues cruise|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/07/blues-cruise.html?extcmp=SOCIA_FB_ENG|accessdate=21 July 2016|publisher=Chelsea F.C.|date=21 July 2016}}</ref>
On 15 August, Batshuayi made his competitive debut in Chelsea's opening match of the [[2016–17 Chelsea F.C. season|2016–17 season]], coming off the substitutes' bench to set-up [[Diego Costa]]'s late winner in a 2–1 win over West Ham.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/report?gameId=451007 |title=Diego Costa's late winner helps Chelsea defeat West Ham in opener |date=15 August 2016 |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> Five days later, after replacing Oscar, he went on to score his first Premier League goal in a victory by the same score at [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37067781 |title=Watford 1–2 Chelsea: Diego Costa scored the winner for the second game |date=20 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 23 August, Batshuayi made his first start for Chelsea in the [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]], scoring a brace in a 3–2 home victory against [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=Chelsea 3–2 Bristol Rovers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37091061 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 August 2016 |accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref>
On 12 May, Batshuayi came on as a second-half substitute against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] with the score 0–0, with Chelsea needing a victory to clinch the [[2016–17 Premier League|Premier League]] title.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/chelsea-west-brom-premier-league-title-clinch-video-051217 |title=Chelsea can clinch Premier League title with win at West Brom |work=Fox Sports |author=Sports Illustrated |date=12 May 2017}}</ref> In the 82nd minute, he slotted a goal past goalkeeper [[Ben Foster (footballer)|Ben Foster]] to win Chelsea their fifth Premier League title.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39813798|title=West Bromwich Albion 0–1 Chelsea|date=12 May 2017|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]}}</ref> Batshuayi went on to score three goals in Chelsea's final two matches, including the last goal of the season in the 92nd minute of Chelsea's 5–1 win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]]. Batshuayi finished the season with 5 goals in only 236 minutes of Premier League action, equaling a rate of one goal every 47 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/club/chelsea/363/blog/post/3131899/michy-batshuayi-unerring-eye-for-goal-is-earning-young-charge-a-second-chelsea-chance |title=Batshuayi's unerring eye for goal is earning young charge a second chance |publisher=ESPNFC |date=22 May 2017 |accessdate = 23 May 2017 }}</ref>
Batshuayi scored his first Chelsea hat-trick on 20 September 2017 in a 5–1 home win over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in the third round of the [[2017–18 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Aarons|first1=Ed|title=Batshuayi hits treble and Musonda excels as Chelsea silence Forest|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/20/chelsea-nottingham-forest-carabao-cup-match-report|accessdate=27 September 2017|work=The Guardian|date=20 September 2017}}</ref> In a [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League group stage|UEFA Champions League group stage]] match away to [[Atlético Madrid]] a week later, substitute Batshuayi scored the added-time winning goal in a 2–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|last=Henry|first=Matthew|title=Atletico Madrid 1–2 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41379696|accessdate=28 September 2017|date=27 September 2017|work=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 17 January 2018, he scored in a third-round [[2017–18 FA Cup|FA Cup]] win over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on his 50th appearance for Chelsea. The match finished 1–1 after extra time, with the ''Blues'' going on to win 5–3 on penalties.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.itv.com/news/2018-01-17/fa-cup-9-man-chelsea-beat-norwich-on-penalties|title=FA Cup: 9-man Chelsea beat Norwich on penalties|publisher=ITV News|date=17 January 2018}}</ref>
====Loan to Borussia Dortmund==== On 31 January 2018, Batshuayi joined German [[Bundesliga]] club [[Borussia Dortmund]] on [[loan (sports)|loan]] for the remainder of the [[2017–18 Borussia Dortmund season|2017–18 season]].<ref>{{cite |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42890254 |title=Olivier Giroud: Chelsea sign Arsenal striker as Michy Batshuayi joins Dortmund |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref> His debut came on 2 February away to [[1. FC Köln]], where he scored twice and had a third disallowed via the [[video assistant referee]], as he was in an offside position. He also made an assist. The match ended 3–2 to Dortmund as an away victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/5488740/michy-batshuayi-scoring-borussia-dortmund-debut-loan-chelsea/ |title=Michy Batshuayi scores twice on Borussia Dortmund debut following loan spell from Chelsea |work=The Sun |first=Andrew |last=Richardson |date=2 February 2018}}</ref> Batshuayi became the first player to score multiple goals on his Bundesliga debut since the player he replaced at Dortmund, [[Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-tza/news/batshuayi-first-bundesliga-striker-to-score-debut-brace/1t0d8azi51vkm1rezug3i89bjf |title=Batshuayi first Bundesliga striker to score debut brace since Aubameyang |work=Goal.com |first=Thomas |last=Floyd |date=2 February 2018}}</ref> The following week, on [[2017–18 Bundesliga|matchday 22]], he again scored the opening goal against [[Hamburger SV]] as Dortmund won 2–0.<ref>{{cite news|title= Gotze, Batshuayi score as Dortmund sink Hamburg|url=http://www.espn.in/football/report?gameId=487066|work=ESPN|date=10 February 2018}}</ref> On 15 February, he scored twice against [[Atalanta B.C.|Atalanta]] in the round of 32 first leg of the [[2017–18 UEFA Europa League knockout phase|UEFA Europa League]] as Dortmund won 3–2 and took the lead going into the second leg.<ref>{{cite news|title="Delighted" Batshuayi is the talk of Dortmund (and London)|first=Nicholas|last=Mendola|date=15 February 2018|accessdate=16 February 2018|url=http://soccer.nbcsports.com/2018/02/15/delighted-batshuayi-is-the-talk-of-dortmund-and-london/|work=soccer.nbcsports.com|publisher=NBC Sports}}</ref> Dortmund's draw in Italy meant the club progressed to the round of 16, although Batshuayi reported hearing "[[Monkey chanting|monkey noises]]" during the match.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea forward Michy Batshuayi accuses Atalanta fans of racism|agency=Associated Press|date=23 February 2018|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Media Group|accessdate=1 March 2018|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/23/chelsea-forward-michy-batshuayi-accuses-atalanta-fans-of-racism|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301003700/https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/23/chelsea-forward-michy-batshuayi-accuses-atalanta-fans-of-racism|archivedate=1 March 2018|df=}}</ref> In March, [[UEFA]]'s investigation led to both teams being fined for use of pyrotechnics and other crowd disturbances, but Batshuayi's allegations of racism were dismissed. He criticised European football's governing body for their judgement.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michy Batshuayi criticises Uefa for ending investigation into racial abuse claim|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43588304|accessdate=31 March 2018|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 March 2018}}</ref> In a 2–0 loss to [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] on 15 April, Batshuayi injured his ankle ligaments and was ruled out for the remainder of the season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Michy Batshuayi's Dortmund season over, doubt for World Cup with Belgium|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/borussia-dortmund/story/3458854/belgiums-michy-batsahuayi-doubt-for-world-cup-after-injury-ends-borussia-dortmund-season|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=16 April 2018|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref>
====Loan to Valencia==== On 10 August 2018, Batshuayi was loaned to Spanish [[La Liga]] club [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] for the [[2018–19 Valencia CF season|2018–19 season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Michy Batshuayi: Chelsea striker joins Valencia on a season-long loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45148680 |accessdate=10 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 August 2018}}</ref> Ten days later, he made his Liga debut as a 76th-minute substitute for [[Carlos Soler (footballer)|Carlos Soler]] in a 1–1 home draw with Atlético Madrid, then continued that role in subsequent matches in a side possessing [[Rodrigo (footballer, born 1991)|Rodrigo]], [[Santi Mina]] and [[Kevin Gameiro]] as striking options.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Harbord |first1=Oliver |title=Why Michy Batshuayi is struggling to shake off substitute tag after stuttering start in Spain |url=https://www.football.london/chelsea-fc/players/michy-batshuayi-latest-chelsea-news-15113891 |accessdate=7 September 2018 |publisher=Football London |date=5 September 2018}}</ref> On 26 September, he scored his first goal in a 1–1 draw with [[RC Celta de Vigo|Celta de Vigo]], therefore becoming the first player to score in the top leagues of France, Germany, England and Spain in the 21st century.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Guest |first1=Rob |title=The incredible record Chelsea ace Michy Batshuayi has set after scoring his first Valencia goal |url=https://www.football.london/chelsea-fc/players/michy-batshuayi-chelsea-news-latest-15208990 |accessdate=28 September 2018 |publisher=Football London |date=28 September 2018}}</ref>
====Loan to Crystal Palace==== In January 2019, Batshuayi's loan to Valencia was cut short and he joined English Premier League club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on loan until the end of the 2018–19 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2019/february/michy-batshuayi-joins-palace-on-loan/|title=Michy Batshuayi Joins Palace on Loan|website=cpfc.co.uk|date=1 February 2019|accessdate=1 February 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47081617|title=Michy Batshuayi: Crystal Palace sign Chelsea striker on loan until end of season|work=BBC Sport|date=1 February 2019|accessdate=1 February 2019}}</ref> He made his debut on 2 February in a home 2–0 win against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], providing an assist for [[Jeffrey Schlupp]] to score the second goal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Benteke eager to become the new partner for 'Batman'|last=Collings|first=Simon|work=[[Evening Standard]]|location =London|date=4 February 2019|page=59}}</ref> On 23 February, Batshuayi scored his first goal for Crystal Palace in 4–1 win against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.in/football/report?gameId=513571|website=espn.in|title=Crystal Palace rout Leicester to step up pressure on Puel|date=23 February 2019|accessdate=5 March 2019}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:ENG-BEL (28).jpg|thumb|right|Batshuayi playing for [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]]] Batshuayi was eligible to play for the [[DR Congo national football team|DR Congo national team]] through his parents, but in March 2015, he ruled out this option, stating that although his Congolese heritage is important to him, he would rather represent [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caughtoffside.com/2015/03/05/olympique-marseilles-michy-batshuayi-chooses-belgium-over-dr-congo/|title=Olympique Marseille’s Michy Batshuayi Chooses Belgium Over DR Congo|date=5 March 2015|publisher=Caught Offside|accessdate=7 March 2015}}</ref>
Batshuayi made his international debut for Belgium on 28 March 2015 in a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match against [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]]. Replacing [[Christian Benteke]] in the 77th minute, he scored from outside the penalty area three minutes later to seal a 5–0 victory at home.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scholten|first1=Berend|title=Classy Belgium too strong for Cyprus|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/qualifiers/season=2016/matches/round=2000446/match=2013931/postmatch/report/|accessdate=8 April 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=28 March 2015}}</ref> He was selected for the [[UEFA Euro 2016|final tournament]] in France, making his competition debut in the last 16 against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] in [[Toulouse]] on 26 June. With his first touch, he finished [[Eden Hazard]]'s assist for the second goal of a 4–0 victory.<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|title=Euro 2016: Hungary 0 Belgium 4 – Alderweireld, Hazard, Batshuayi and Carrasco goals set up quarter-final against Wales|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/26/hungary-v-belgium-euro-2016-live/|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=26 June 2016}}</ref>
In Belgium's [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2018 FIFA World Cup qualification]], Batshuayi scored once in a 4–3 win away to [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] on 7 October 2017, with the ''Red Devils'' already assured of their place in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|final tournament]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bhardwaj|first1=Vaishali|title=Bosnia-Herzegovina 3 Belgium 4: Vertonghen and Batshuayi on target as Fellaini forced off with knee injury|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/bosniaherzegovina-3-belgium-4-vertonghen-and-batshuayi-on-target-as-fellaini-forced-off-with-knee-a3653036.html|accessdate=31 March 2018|work=Evening Standard|date=7 October 2017}}</ref> Manager [[Roberto Martínez]] named him in the 23-man squad to go to Russia.<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2018: Belgium include Vincent Kompany but Christian Benteke misses out |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44353673 |accessdate=23 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 June 2018}}</ref> In their second group stage match, he came on as a 68th-minute substitute against [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]] and missed several chances before finally scoring the fifth goal for Belgium in a 5–2 victory.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Massart |first1=Simon |title=Batshuayi's perseverance pays dividends |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/batshuayi-perseverance-pays-dividends-2966457 |accessdate=23 June 2018 |publisher=FIFA |date=23 June 2018}}</ref>
==Style of play== A December 2015 profiling by ''[[FourFourTwo]]'' likened Batshuayi for his speed, strength, positioning and link-up play to [[Didier Drogba]], despite being shorter than the Ivorian.<ref name=four/>
==Personal life== Batshuayi is nicknamed "Batsman", a play on the name of the superhero [[Batman]].<ref name=batsman/> His younger brother [[Aaron Leya Iseka]] plays for Toulouse in the same position, coming through at Anderlecht and signing for Marseille on loan, one month after Batshuayi's exit.<ref name=bfm>{{cite news |title=OM : cinq choses à savoir sur Aaron Leya Iseka, le petit frère de Michy Batshuayi|trans-title=OM: five things to know about Aaron Leya Iseka, Michy Batshuayi's little brother |url=https://rmcsport.bfmtv.com/football/om-cinq-choses-a-savoir-sur-aaron-leya-iseka-le-petit-frere-de-michy-1030312.html |accessdate=11 August 2018 |publisher=BFM |date=27 August 2016 |language=French}}</ref>
